Sweet happy Jesus, in the mouth NOW.All of these were amazing, but they must now step aside for the main reason I have come out of reviewing retirement. That reason is the cheeseburger. Good God of all things meat and glorious! This might be the best burger in San Francisco. I shit you not! Not only is it loaded with ooey gooey American cheese (stop and hold your hate roll), but the perfectly cooked patty is filled with crumbled bacon. It's not dry either. Oh no no, it's super moist and amazing and perfectly seasoned and it's, it's just, it's, it's absolutely  oooohmazing!!I know I have a history of falling in love with meat dishes and then leaving them for others, but I can't stop thinking about this Rickybobby burger. It is 4am craving-worthy. It's name your first born after-worthy and it's available at a cute new spot with a slick decor and a warm and friendly vibe.Try this bad boy. Trust. This could become my new favorite neighborhood place! The food is awesome and decently price, and service is friendly. Definitely don't come here expecting to maintain any of those ridiculous "I'm going to start eating healthy" New Years resolutions you made a few weeks ago. Even their salads are pretty rich.My friend and I split the following for dinner:-Bacon burger (Amazing. Bacon is fried, chopped up, and incorporated INTO the meat patty = bacon in every bite)-Beet salad (Minus the fried oysters, just to be 'healthier')-Lobster mac and cheese (Oh boy. SO GOOD. They definitely don't skimp on the lobster, and the dish is baked, so you get a great crust at the top)Since they apparently just got their liquor license, we also ordered some adult libations for the table.Total was ~$40 (minus tip) for everything. Since this place is tiny, and just opened up a few months ago, expect a 30+ min wait if you show up on a Friday or Saturday night. No big deal-- just get your name on the list, and walk a block to a drinking establishment on Haight. This place's clientele has outgrown its tiny interior almost instantly!  There are six or seven communal tables, and our party of three waited 30-45 mins to grab a small section on a Friday night.The food is decadent - comfort food kicked up a notch.  Like mac and cheese? Add some lobster.  Chicken parm?  How about some fresh basil.  They grind bacon into their burger meat, which makes a delicious, greasy mess.  I highly recommend it.The sides of sweet potato tots and fries are quite generous - this is to say sharing two baskets between three people was a futile task.This is probably a solid weeknight spot for me, as long as the wait isn't too long! Food is awesome. Service and wait are terrible. That's all you really need to know. Like at Broken record, the food at Rickybobby is an excellent value. We arrived early on a Wednesday and were able to snag a whole table for our party. Service was a little slow but very friendly. I particularly enjoyed the beet salad - the idea of ranch yogurt seemed kind of disgusting (I normally avoid ranch anything), but it was delicious! Somehow the chicken drums that we've gotten always seem to come ~3/order rather than 1 - not sure why, but I have no problem with it! The pecan pie is really fantastic - some of the best I've had - and the "half" is quite large. When we came it was BYOB, which was nice, but I look forward to giving them more money for alcohol, because I really feel like they're undercharging. A great addition to the neighborhood! Came here with a friend on a Saturday night... bad idea! But luckily the food tasted good, so it was all worth the wait. I've never eaten at the Broken Record... but if this is the type of food they used to serve, I've been missing out! Arrived around 6:50, and we ended up waiting for an hour and thirty minutes. So... if you don't feel like walking around the area... I'd probably come on a weekday.My friend and I shared everything we ordered. If you're uncomfortable with sitting next to strangers, this may not be the place for you... luckily we were seated next to some nice people. Ordered the sweet potatertots, beef and bacon burger, chicken parm sandwich, and the lobster mac n cheese! Sweet potatertots were the first to arrive... I'm not sure if it was because my stomach was starved after eating itself, but it was AMAZING. Plenty of tatertots for 3-4 people... it was the only dish we couldn't finish. Eat it while it's hot, cause thats when it tastes the best... just be careful and don't burn your mouth like I did! But then again... when you're starving, you just don't give a s***! Next up was the beef and bacon burger and the chicken parm sandwich. The beef and bacon burger was really good, especially with the condiments they give you. But the entire time, all I tasted was bacon, but that's because they mix the bacon with the beef. So I guess if you're a bacon fan, you'll love this burger instantly. Oh, and the burger came with a pickle... I know it's just a pickle... but I LOVED THAT PICKLE! It was crunchy, sour, and fresh! I was tempted to just ask for a few more sticks of pickles! The chicken parm sandwich was actually my favorite dish of the night. VERY flavorful and everything blended very well together. I didn't think it was spicy, but my friend thought it was a little spicy. Chicken wasn't dry either... I savored every bite... I was kind of sad when I finished it. Finally, the oh so famous lobster mac n cheese. It definitely was a very CHEESY mac n cheese. I'm usually not a mac n cheese fan, but this was definitely really good. Sure, it was probably clogging my arteries but at least it was worth every bite. They're also not skimpy on the lobster meat either, you get some pretty big chunks of lobster in there. Near the end of the meal though, when I was stuffed and felt like I needed my fatty pants, my friend and I was forcing ourselves to finish the mac n cheese. I'm not sure if it was because I was too full or the cheese was just too much, but I started to get nauseated. Maybe next time we'll just take it to go. Basically the food was awesome. Service, was okay. Like other reviewers said, they probably need one more waiter just to balance everything out, but they're definitely trying. Place is clean. Definitely coming back to try the rest of the menu, but maybe on the weekday so I can avoid my stomach digesting itself again. I had a fantastic dinner here on a cold wintery night, and this place served up just the right level of rich and decadent comfort food with a sophisticated twist.  The wait was a tad long, the tables are communal, and the menu is written on the chalkboard above the kitchen rather than distributed to each patron.  None of these things were that bothersome.  They were also showing some excellent cinema on the wall (read that jean claude van damme classics).  Three of us shared the fries and the sweet potatertots.  Good, standard, large portions.  The entrees really sealed the deal though.  One of us got the chicken parm sandwich which he seemed pleased with.  Two of us shared the lobster mac and cheese and the burger (yes, the infamous partially bacon burger) and both were richly divine.  I thought the mac and cheese was the best lobster mac I'd had in SF.  The sauce was rich and creamy, the corn, spinach, and tomatoes added diversity to the taste, and the lobster was plentiful.  However, some of the claw meat felt overcooked and had a slightly off consistency.  If it had all been tail meat, it would've been a slam dunk.  The burger had the amazing taste of bacon, but the consistency of beef.  I felt content after only eating half because it was so rich.  The servers were nice, though swamped with the crowd.  I was a little disappointed because I asked if we could get the burger with a cheese other than American (there were clearly other cheeses on the menu), but the waiter said we could not make substitutions, though he let us put the ketchup on the side.  That bummed me out a bit, but luckily the burger itself outshone the cheese, so I didn't mind in the end.  I would love to come back and try most anything on the menu, so come here hungry and looking to feel nice and satisfied at the end of your meal. Arrived on Saturday night and scored a table right away! Another 5 minutes and we would've faced a significant wait. Only about 10 large tables line the walls of this small restaurant...so once word gets out I'm sure this place will be packed to the brim.we went all out and ordered: Bacon infused burger, tater tots, chicken drumsticks, lobster mac n cheese, beet salad, grits. For dessert we had the hawaiian bread pudding. BYOB! After we ordered we walked to the liquor store across the street for beer (classy!) and offered one to our server. Interesting concept but it beats paying for overpriced liquor! Food arrived and we were floored by how amazing each dish was. At less than $10 per plate, the portions were more than generous and the servers were chill and friendly. We were tempted to just hang out and drink more beers, but the long line piling up near the door made us feel bad. cannot wait to return to try the rest of their dishes and desserts!!! I loved it when it was being served at The Broken Record and I love it now at Rickybobby.The food is fantastic.  Lobster mac and cheese is my favorite, but the crawfish and grits is amazing as well.  I don't think you can go wrong ordering anything at this place.I'm surprised reading some of the negative reviews, because I've never had bad service here, even when it was INSANELY busy, which leads me to believe that some yelpers tend to be a little bit sensitive....surprise surprise.  Oh well, hopefully they don't come back and take up a seat I could be occupying.If you like good food and a good atmosphere, this is your spot. Too bad, so sad. No, really I am sad. I wanted to like this place, it's about 3 minutes from my apt. and there's this big line and this big hype and there's...the food. Yeah. That's the thing. The food. It's just not very good. The current 4.5 star rating is shocking, truly. Lobster Mac 'n Cheese: Tasted like nacho cheese with un-properly cooked bow-tie pasta. (chewy, crunchy). The lobster was tasty, but I'm fairly sure they didn't make that in house (wink).Beet Salad with Fried Oysters: The fried oysters were tasty, but they had nothing to do with the salad. That is to say, they didn't go together. In fact, nothing in the salad quite went together. I can't even remember what else we got...oh. the Pulled Pork Sandwich. Meh.  It was just, okay. Not much more to say, not much more to it.The stumperS: Our server, who came to our table numerous times asked me my name "for the order."  Why? How bout, table number 3 that you're serving. We clearly weren't going anywhere. Perhaps this is a growing pains issue from a walk-up counter at one location, to a sit-down at the next? This was confusing. Also, they have these big pictures on the wall of pigeons and horses, and landscapes and then - they have a hamburger. It went from hipster to TGIF real quick. Blown up hamburger picture? Wha?Oh, Rickybobby. I haven't even written a review in years but I couldn't sit back and watch 4.5 stars encourage people to eat you. It's simply unfair.My girlfriend says: "I'd go back there, but probably just because they're open late."  Well, it does beat the new Volare pizza. In short: overrated right now. Customer service needs MAJOR improvement. They need takeout, and I won't return until customer service improves dramatically.We came here last Friday (01/11/2013) around 7PM with a party of 3 to check out what everyone had been talking about. Super packed.. alright.. expected. The host walks up and asks us "Are you on the list?" "Nope..." He walks back to the other end of the restaurant and picks up the list and writes our name down and says about 25 minutes. We grab a (crowded) seat at the front and waited.. They were SEVERELY understaffed. The host, who I could tell was a bit frazzled, also bussed the tables and sometimes grabbed water for folks, all while putting people on "the list". Right around 25 minutes (but after folks with same number in their party), we were seated.We look around... and wait. We knew what we wanted to order (the menu was on the far end of the restaurant). A party of three sitting next to us had 2/3 of their food delivered when we sat down. It looked tasty, but one girl didn't have her food. Fast forward to the rest of that party finishing their food, when the other 1/3 of the order shows up.All of this happens.. and we still haven't been given water. Finally, after 20 minutes of being seated at a table, we are given water. I flag down a waiter (who was annoyed I flagged him down), and we order our food. We are starving.Maybe 10 minutes later (not too long), my food (grilled fontina cheese and crab tomato soup) arrived first. My grilled cheese was lukewarm.. soup was warm. $10 for lukewarm grilled cheese was my first thought? I wait patiently, hoping the rest of the food comes out.. no dice. My friends tell me to eat.. I take a bite of the grilled cheese and was very underwhelmed. Slightly burned, lukewarm, and seemingly lacking butter (but I can't confirm it other than what my tastebuds told me). Honestly, my grilled cheese would have been better with Kraft American singles. The tomato/crab soup was fine.. but underwhelming. My meal was *NOT* worth the $10 I paid.Most of our food finally arrived -- sweet potatertots, beef/bacon burger, lobster mac & cheese, and two chicken drums. Each plate was SLAMMED down on the table by our disgruntled waiter. Lovely. Sweet potatertots were generous, pretty tasty, and overall pretty good (I think I was still pissed I waited so long for water and my grilled cheese was crap).  Beef/bacon burger was juicy & tasty but looked NOTHING like the picture on the wall right behind us (who puts a giant hamburger picture that isn't something from their menu?). Chicken drums were loved by my friends, I wasn't impressed; they still say they were fantastic. You be the judge. Lobster mac 'n cheese was very good -- it lives up to the hype. Is the hype worth the wait and bad customer service? No. We ate pretty much everything on the table because we were starving. I was so hungry after waiting so long that I even finished the crappy grilled cheese. Oh.. and guess what didn't show up? The pear salad we ordered. I really wanted Rickyboby to live up to my expectations and the initial Yelp reviews, but they didn't. I have never been there any other time, but the service BLEW MONKEY BALLS on Friday night. Some of the food was good (lobster mac and cheese), others can be dropped (grilled cheese). I hope it improves.. but right now I will not return. I came here yesterday with my boyfriend at around 6:45pm on a Friday night. It was tad bit awkward because it was a full house, but none of the parties had their food yet. Anyways, we were seated right away and the waiter gave us glasses of waters as we squinted our eyes to look at the menu up front. I've never been to Broken Record, but my boyfriend told me that they basically kept the same menu. We settled on the Sweet Potato tater tots, Crab Grilled Cheese with Fontina, and Pulled Pork Sandwich along with some good ol' Anchor Steams to wash it down.Sweet Potato Tater Tots with house made ranch sauce and ketchup - Finally! A restaurant that knows how to do Sweet Potato Tater Tots! The basket was enough to share between 3-4 people and house made ranch was divine! I secretly wanted to take some of their house made ranch home. The tots aren't oily and are oh so good!Crab Grilled Cheese with Fontina and a spicy Tomato Soup with crab - I definitely wish they put  more crab in the grilled cheese! No worries, I found it in the soup! The spicy tomato soup was perfect for dipping or even slurping on. The Fontina cheese tasted more like American cheese, though.Pulled Pork Sandwich - The pork was sweet and SO good! I can't really say much about the bread lol because I just had a bite of the pork.Overall, I'm giving RickyBobby 5 stars. My water glass was constantly being filled, my belly was full, and I am not complaining! Didn't wait too long, and everyone working there was very nice. I got the burger, which was very good.  My bf got the crab grilled cheese which was a miss.  It just wasn't good. The cheese was bright yellow and tasted like american more than fontina.  I felt bad he didn't like it so gave him a few bites of the burger, which he also thought was really good.  They were pretty slammed so our fries and sweetpotatoe tots didn't come out until we were done with the mains.  That usually bugs me but the waiter was very nice and I think they just sell those items so quickly that they couldn't keep up.  I think something else might be a better side rather than ranch like sweet chili sauce, but I might be in the minority there.  Overall good and we'll go back.  Any kinks in the meal were overshadowed by the friendly staff and the burger tastiness! I'll keep mine short and sweet. If the menu sounds like your thing then you won't be dissapointed. Everything is done with great thought and detail. Always exceeds expectations. The Rickybobby kitchen used to be a little pop up in Broken Record. Came here for a new years eve dinner:Lobster Mac & CheeseSweet PotatertotsCrab & Fontina Grilled Cheese with spicy tomato dipping soupOne of the reasons why I followed the kitchen from Broken Record to Rickybobby is because of the lobster mac & cheese. I love the lobster mac & cheese and I think they improved and already perfect thing!Everything is delicious at Rickybobby but I found the sweet potatertots and the spicy tomato dipping soup a bit salty. I am not sure if it was just our dishes or just the day we went (since we went for new years eve so the chef might have been a little happy with the salt). But definitely get the lobster mac & cheese! It has corn, lobster, and spinach! I love it! The only problem I have with Rickybobby is that there are literally three options without meat. Seriously.  Tots. Fries. And a beat salad.  Fortunately, beat salad and the tots are pretty good.  So, come on gents, star a few menu items and make them available vegetarian. PS way better than Roti. As a fan of this crew when they worked their magic at Broken Record I was excited to visit Ricky Bobby which is even closer to home.Though we got there only 30 minutes after they  opened (it was their 1st or 2nd week open) there were already a bunch of people waiting for tables. Good news spreads quickly.I am not sure if Ricky Bobby is still BYOB but they were at this point. Luckily the corner store across the street has a decent beer selection. Come prepared. The staff are very prompt which helps keep things moving at this restaurant but the BYOB can cause tables to linger and finish their 6 packs.Our table split the sweet potato  tater tots for the table and I ordered the bacon cheese burger. I was sad that I couldn't taste much of it because of the cold I had but the texture was great! Also, those in my party that tried it said you could taste the bacon in every bite (it is ground into the beef).  I will be back to revisit this item for sure.My only suggestion for this crew is to bring back the gringo fries!! LOVED it, but I had the biggest food coma I've ever had in my life.  Go easy good people, this place will make you feel like you need to give birth... This place is great! It's like what your mamma used to make but better! Imagine all your favorite the comfort foods with a unique touch. I went with a few friends and we just ordered a bunch of stuff to share which I highly recommend doing because it's difficult to choose. The lobster mac and cheese was delectable, the sweet potato tots were addicting and the beat salad was mouth-watering. Sweet potatortots!!!1 Aahh so worth the hype!! I would normally say $5 is expensive for tatortots but no. Worth it!! I've been dying to try the sweet potatortots ever since I heard about them from Broken Record, but haven't been able to try them due to the chefs moving. They are amazing!!!! I also had the apple salad, which was pretty good for an apple salad :d hahah. If you don't like apples or beets though, and you're vegetarian, just go for the tots ahaha good enough! My friends waited for a super long time, but I was late so I didn't wait as long as they did :}. They didn't seem to mind though, and the staff was superrr nice. Love this place! Make sure to get there early (or at least have somewhere get there early for you)! Same rating but went a second time.1) No longer BYOB.2) Bread Pudding was pretty great - and I don't even really like bread pudding3) Points for service - they forgot to put in our order for lobster mac and cheese. They offered to comp it for us, but we were in a rush so had to pass. I always appreciate the gesture though. Came here on a rainy day over Christmas w/ Janette after tearing up Union Square on ice skates (it wasn't raining earlier). Butternut Squash and Carrot Soup - a special of the day... this was delcious and very creamy. What set this soup up surprisingly was not the heartiness of the soup or sweetness of the carrots, but the season croutons placed on top. The crisp texture and saltiness really complemented the mellowness and added a great texture contrast.Steak and Scallop - another special... New York Steak, scalloped potatoes, and a single seared scallop. The new york steak was ultra tender, but needed a little more seasoning. The sauce was similar to a red wine/beef burgundy reduction with shallots. The scalloped potatoes were creamy but not overly cheesey, as to not overwhelm the flavors. The scallop was perfectly seared. The pricing was actually pretty good (12-13) but I would pay a little bit more for more meat.Burger - of the many bacon burgers I've had, this one sits up there with Hodads. Like Hodads, this is a very simple but well executed bacon cheese burger, where you get bacon in every bite. The bacon is fried and mixed into the ground beef patties. The patties are beefy, seasoned with salt and pepper, and also have the smoky flavor of the bacon. Added with the standard fare of american cheese, house made mayo, and ketchup all sandwiched in a toasted bun, this burger pretty much was AMERICA. Big, simple, tasty as hell, with a don't mess with a classic attitude, and a great price.It looks like they got their wine and beer license, and I really wish they could serve a larger variety of beers, because the food is straight gastropub and deserves a ton of great beers to be served alongside it. Pricewise, this place is great and the taste to cost ratio to me is really high. I will definitely be back to try everything else. I am so glad that Rickybobby finally opened after enduring the few months after the chefs from Broken Record left and decided to make their own restaurant.  In terms of describing this concoction of delicious items on the menu, it would be "high end bar food".I came here on a Thursday night with some friends and this place was surprisingly packed as it is only open for dinner.  This new establishment is a lot bigger than the previous dining area at Broken Record with there being seating for at least 50 people. The servers here are friendly and try to accommodate all parties as quickly as possibly.My friends decided to share the Chicken parm sandwich, lobster mac and cheese, braised chicken, and crawfish grits.  The chicken parm sandwich is definitely a must-have.  The chicken cutlet was perfectly breaded and fried, topped with melted mozzarella, and had pieces of house made sausage on top.The lobster mac and cheese was my favorite; a mouthwatering combination of cheeses, pasta, and fresh tasting lobster baked in a huge bowl with pieces of corn and spinach inside.My friend enjoyed the crawfish grits; a spicy and hearty stew-like mixture of shrimp, crawfish, and grits.  Even for a person who isn't fond of grits, the way that they made their version made me enjoy it.The braised chicken has a nice sweet Asian style glaze to it, but it was pricey at $3 a pop, although we received four even though we ordered two.One item that everyone must try is their bacon burger: it's simply burger goodness to the max, a juicy patty with hints of bacon in every bite. Most of their main dishes range from $5-14 which is totally reasonable.  As of now, drinks are BYOB as they are working on acquiring their liquor license, but that's a plus since there's a liquor store just across the street .I definitely recommend trying this place at least once, with the guarantee that you'll definitely leave satisfied and the urge to try everything on their menu on your next visit. It's 2013! The beginning of a new year. That time when oh so many people make those New Year's resolutions to workout and eat healthy.  On January 2nd, those folks hit the gym and eat a salad. And on January 3rd through December 31st, the gym membership is paid but unused and it's pizza and hot dogs for every meal.  So for me?  I didn't make that New Year's resolution. I went with a friend to the new restaurant from the owners of Broken Record, Rickybobby. Let's get to it and dive into the food:We each ordered:Beef and Bacon Burger $10ground together! american cheese, house mayo, ketchup, onion and pickles on the sideThen we split the following:Sweet Potatertots $5ketchup and house ranchFrench Friesside $2, basket w/ ranch $5Beer and wine is BYOB for right now. But believe they have plans to serve it soon. So the result?  Ok, so maybe I wasn't completely accurate above, I did technically workout that day, but then ultimately destroyed that entire workout by eating the epic Beef and Bacon Burger.  But I didn't make a resolution, so I feel like I'm in the clear.  And even if I had and broken it practically the first day, it would have been worth it.  Because this burger is EPIC!   Here are some quick notes...* The burger was in my top three in the city.* The tots were killer.* The fries, solid.* BYOB worked just fine for the night, with a corner store right across the street.* The atmosphere is fun.* They were playing some fun tunes.* The staff was attentive and super friendly.My advice is throw your healthy New Year's resolutions out the door and go dominate this Beef and Bacon Burger. It is sooooooo worth it.  I don't give out many five star reviews. But they are off to a great start. So here's to hoping Rickbobby keeps up the awesome work!Ok, I'm headed to workout. Until next time.  Good talk. The first time my friends and I tried to come here, there was a huge mob waiting outside. We took one look at the limited seating inside, and decided to try again another day. Unless you show up when the doors open (6PM), expect a line. So determined were we to try the lobster mac n cheese, we found ourselves loitering outside the restaurant at 5:30PM the next day. WORTH IT!!Rating Breakdown:2/2 Stars for Taste --We pretty much ordered the entire menu and everything was delicious. Dishes that really stood out were the Lobster Mac N' Cheese, the Crawfish Grits, and Sweet Potater Tots. I don't usually eat spicy things and I hate sweet potatoes, but Rickybobby turned my tastebuds on their head so that they just didn't know what to do with themselves. The savory creaminess of the lobster mac, the subtle slow spice of the broth in the grits, and the crispy batter on the tots...you simply can't leave this place without trying at least one of these three items. Also, their pecan pie a la mode is crack.1/1 Stars for Value --Everything on the menu is around $10. Portions are generous. Everything came out hot and fresh. The lobster mac was still bubbling when they brought it to our table. I would throw my money at this place any day.1/1 Stars for Customer Service --Don't expect someone to be waiting on you hand and foot at this place. The restaurant is pretty small and is always CROWDED. Waiters are always helpful and try their best to be attentive, but bring someone who isn't afraid to command attention in your party. Bonus star because even though I hate lines, I definitely see myself coming back to Rickybobby. Not a great place for huge parties, but a great place to relax with friends, gorge on great food, and enjoy a cold beer. I love the upscale down-home food hear.  The pulled pork has such great heat from the haberno sauce, without losing the flavor of the pork.We were really impressed with the spicy craw-shrimp and grits.  The sausage in the grits and the heat from the sauce make this so good. How to dull the heat?  Dunk one of the sweet potato tots in ranch and keep going.The pecan pie was a little burnt, but a perfect ending to our meal along with their killer ice cream.  I love having this new joint a few block from my apartment. Hope these guys keep it up!! Rickybobby's chefs used to reside at Broken Record in some part of SF that I never ventured. Once I heard the announcement of Rickybobby's arrival I knew I wanted to try it out for my birthday. At around 8:20pm, on a Friday night, we arrived to a packed crowd of hungry San Franciscans. Three communal dining tables on each side of the restaurant which can seat 6-8 at each and one little extra table on the right. Be prepared to wait if you want to try out one of SF's newest hot spots. Luckily for us, everyone waiting was in groups of 4-8. It was just the two of us, so by the time I arrived back from the liquor store with  24's of PBR and Heineken, we were ready to be sat. Less than 10 minute wait in this HUGE crowd?! Happiness!Shortly after our no nonsense waiter arrived with " Sup? Do you know what you want?"" Beef and Bacon burger ($10), Lobster Mac and Cheese ($12), and Sweet Potatertots ($5)"10minutes later the burger arrived. This, folks, was the highlight of our visit. Is this one of the BEST BURGERS I HAVE EVER TASTED? Without hesitation, YES! The way the ground bacon is molded with the beef and cooked medium was honestly indescribable food porn. 10 minutes after arrived the Sweet Potatertots came. This is enough for 4 people. They were decent. Somewhat bland. We didn't finish them. A lot of food, perfect for sharing, but I wouldn't order them again. Finally the much hyped Lobster Mac and Cheese, with corn and spinach mixed in. We weren't impressed. The cheese tasted like KRAFT, it was slightly watery. It was very much a disappointment. There is much to explore on this menu though, so I am optimistic about trying the pulled pork and chicken parmesan sandwiches. Dumb to give 3 stars or lower when the burger is out of this world, and I haven't fully conquered the menu. Bring plenty of beer with you to drown out a potentially silly dining neighbor....the original group of people we sat with were friendly and pleasant. After they left they sat six tech doofuses with us who complained about everything.  See you again soon, Rickybobby! After reading about this new place on EaterSF a while back, I finally decided that tonight was a good night to venture out on my own and try what was billed as a neighborhood spot.  I found indeed a good neighborhood spot, but certainly one that is probably still working out its growing pains and post-opening jitters.First - the food.  As a single diner, I really was kind of on a mission - I wanted a burger.  And I thought about going to the SuperDuper down the street, but again, new place, why not.  So I came in for the burger.  While good, I don't know if I would necessarily rank it up there on the $10 burger scale, and certainly wouldn't rank it it the top burgers I've had.  The patties, while flavorful, were greasy yet dry, a very odd oxymoron.  The flavor of the bacon did come through in a wonderful supporting role, but occasionally the beef found itself playing second fiddle.  The bun was toastily soft, and held its own well.  The burger is dressed simply with some mayo and onion, with pickled onions on the side.  I would have to say that I probably would've been happier with a little more greenery to balance out the meatiness - even with piling the pickled onions on, and even eating the pickle spear (I don't even like pickles all that much unlike a certain Jersey Shore character), I found myself wishing for more balance.  An hour after eating, I'm still downing water, which makes me think that it may have been seasoned a bit too much.Of course, it's hard to have a burger without some sort of side.  I opted for the sweet potatertots, which are about what you expect.  There was definitely a little more salt on them than expected, but I think it created a nice balance.  Warning though: those things come out crazy hot.Now, as for these growing pains I mentioned earlier - I think the biggest issue is their wait management and service staff.  Let me preface it all by saying that the wait staff is probably as friendly and down-home as can be.  But after arriving, it took nearly 20 minutes of just waiting for me to even get my name taken down on the list.  There's sort of a waiting area just inside the door, but if a crowd gathers, anyone can get lost in it.  Despite trying to flag down a wait staff member/host, it still took a while.  Since there's no host stand, nor any sort of wait focal point, I definitely got lost in the shuffle.  Granted, again, as a single diner, I was seated rather quickly, getting a random seat out among the communal tables.  The wait staff, while friendly, I think definitely had their work cut out for them, and maybe are a bit overwhelmed, with what appeared to be only three servers navigating a dense number of parties, through lots of people milling about.  I'm wondering if just an extra person might help with both the wait list and the service issues.I'll probably need to come back to try some of the more fancy food, like the crawfish and grits and the much-talked-about lobster mac and cheese, but for now, a solid three stars...3.5 for the food, 3 for the service. great atmosphere, great food, really friendly and fast service. the chicken drums were awesome and huge. the kitchen hooked us up too with some extras. lobster mac and the burger were standouts. and the tatertots were fantastic. go to rickybobby! Something about this place is just plain likeable.It's a small menu with a unique artisanal twist to comfort food, but when you can make food this good, a small menu is all you need.  Rickybobby is one-of-a-kind with its food, concept, and atmosphere. I brought my friend from out of town and she couldn't help but notice how this place embodies SF.  Everything we ordered, I can recommend:*Beef and bacon burger -- Beefy and juicy with a hint of bacon flavor melded into the patties to round it all out.  Comes with a pickle and pickled red onions on the side.  A must order for burger lovers.*Lobster mac and cheese -- This came out hot and bubbly with a crispy top.  Spinach and corn complement the farfalle in cheese sauce, and of course, you'll find a few chunks of lobster meat for your eating pleasure.*Sweet potater tots -- A generous basket of sweet tots with their tasty house ranch and ketchup.Next up to try:  pecan pie, crawfish gritsP.S.  Oh so hipster. While I want to keep this place as my little secret, the folks at Rickybobby must know how they're doing everything right!My three girl friends and I ordered about 80% of the menu: pulled pork sandwich, crab and fontina grilled cheese, crawshrimp grits, beet salad, sweet potatertots, fries, braised short ribs (a special), butternut squash soup (a special), and a pistachio ice cream sundae.  The standout at our table was the grits. Magic in a bowl. Also the sundae was dynamite! Actually, everything is delicious. I would love to order the whole menu at my next visit.The service was really great as well! Right when we walked in, they told us they were BYOB and pointed out the bodega kitty corner from the restaurant. The food came out fast and piping hot. Our waiter was nice and not overbearingly attentive. When one of my friends wanted to order a second pistachio sundae, he shared that they were already out (1.5 hours into food service) but offered to hand roll vanilla ice cream into a ball and cover it in graham crackers for us. We declined his sweet offer but damn, how cool was that?Noise level made it hard to hear each other as night went on but who'd want to come up for air and talk when you could be woofing down some yummy food? By far, one of the best burgers I've ever had. The meat just by itself tasted great, moist and rich! My wife ordered the grilled cheese with tomato and crab bisque... Loved it. My friend ordered the short ribs with mashed potato, I'm not a fan of beef ribs, but again, they were heaven.At the end we had the pistachio ice cream and the pecan pie. I have to say these guys really know their stuff, you can taste the love they put to what they make.I had to go to the kitchen to compliment the cooks/owners, something I don't do often, and they definitely deserve it.Kudos! I came here on Wednesday night with a couple of friends and had a delightful experience. I thought the decor was nice, we were seated within five minutes and our waiter promptly directed us to the liquor store across the street for a little BYOB action. The three of us split the lobster mac n cheese, sweet potato tots, chicken parmesan sandwich and burger. The food isn't anything fancy but everything we ordered was super yummy and the bill was $13/person. Whaaaat?! Cute/ fun/ casual yet hip/ good price point... definitely a keeper. Brought to you buy the guys from Broken Record, Ricky Bobby features the same menu they had at BR. At the moment, it's a BYOB place, there is a corner store across the street so super easy.FF and I shared the Bacon burger, Lobster Mac and cheese, the chicken drums and the shaved apple salad .  -Bacon burger was okay, wasn't as good as I remembered from when they were at BR.  The bacon flavor wasn't as strong as before. - The shaved apple salad was good, normal. - the chicken drums ($3 bucks each) was suppose to be a big drum, but when it came out small, the guys brought us out two.  The sauce on the drums were tasty, but the drum that I had wasn't as juicy as I was hoping for and was kinda dry.  Hoping that they are just tweeking this and making adjustments '- the mac and cheese was good, super cheesy.  Most of the lobster meat was claw meat, so if it's the smaller pieces, it dried out in the oven. =TService is awesome.  The waiters are all super nice and seems like they were liking the new place.  I would come back and try the $14 scallops and the $11 shrimp and grits! "Aaaaah, Ricky Bobby! Now we shall dance. And yes, it will be a slow jam." -Jean GirardWhen I read that the Broken Record kitchen decided to start their own place, i suggested this place to meet up with some friends.  We loved the food at Broken Record so we were really excited to try Rickybobby.The 6 of us ordered the following:3 Lobster Mac and Cheese2 Sweet Potato Tots1 Beef and Bacon Burger1 Beet Salad1 Pull Pork Sandwich1 Full Size Pecan PieI ordered one of the Mac and cheese and Tots.  The Mac and Cheese was awesome.  It was freakishly hot for like 20 mins, but damn that was some good mac and cheese.  Not the best I've ever had (The Truffle Mac and Cheese with Lobster from Alexander's Steakhouse in Cupertino) but still awesome.  It had a lovely crust on top, as it should.  The size of the lobster chunks were nice and there was plenty.  The corn adds a nice texture to the dish and the spinach helps in balancing out the richness from the cheese.I'm not a big Sweet Potato fan, but ordered the tots from all the suggestions on Yelp.  They were nice, i still prefer regular tots, but they were nice.  Its just that with sweet potato being softer than a regular potato you don't get the individual little chunks that make up the a regular tot.  It's one of those "i'll take some if a friend orders it, but wouldn't order it myself" type of thingTook a bite of my friend's Beef and Bacon burger and damn that's a bombass burger.  I didn't know how ground the bacon would be but when i had that bite you get that texture from the bacon and wow.  They apparently cook the burger to medium so it was not dried out (the bacon fat probably helps with that as well).  Mos def going to get it next time. My friend's pecan pie was also good.  The crust was amazing as it was flaky and buttery.  Pecan filling was nice and the ice cream was a nice touch.The pulled pork sandwich was good as well.  I really like how they don't fully slice the bread through, allowing the pull pork to stay in the sandwich.  It looks like a pocket full of meat!One thing that we were all sad to not see on the menu were the pulled pork waffle fries.  Really had hope they brought it over from Broken Record. Currently its BYOB so don't forget.  Hope they get their liquor license soon along with a nice selection of microbrews. Amazing lobster mac and cheese, and it travels well to boot! I would venture to say that the food is somehow magically better than before (at Broken Record)! I will be dining here frequently to the chagrin of my waist line. Only down side is that my lady is gluten free and there are virtually no current options for her, perhaps the future will bring some. My girlfriend mentioned that Rickybobby was going to open this past Wednesday, we were there for dinner on opening night. We have been a fan of their pop up kitchen inside Broken Record for years. After circling the neighborhood for parking, we walked in and the host showed us where to sit as we shared a communal table with other diners. The three of us fired out orders like we were eating for 6 people: Pros:Lobster mac and cheeseShaved apple saladBeet salad with fried oystersPulled pork sandwichSweet tater tots Cons: Crab and fontina grilled cheese with a spicy tomato dipping soup - did not taste the crab in here; all cheeseFor dessert, we tried: Pistachio ice cream, graham cracker crumbs with caramelized cherriesHawaiian bread pudding with TCHO chocolate and vanilla ice creamBoth desserts were pretty damn good! Plus it's BYOB so our friend picked up a couple of cans of Bitter American and had a great time with awesome company, endless laughter and conversations. It gets pretty loud inside. They do take credit/debit cards, too. Seating is always first come, first serve. No reservations. I'd come back here again! Thank you sweet tiny baby Jesus for bringing this delicious eatery into my neighborhood! The chicken drums are so damn good that I hope they sell them by the bucket. The $3 piece of chicken was seriously better than some roast chickens I've ordered at fine dining restaurants. And the lobster Mac and cheese is beyond good, and they don't skimp on the lobster! Also tried the bacon burger and sweet potato tater tots, big wins. The opening of Rickybobby's signals an arrival of sorts for the Lower Haight to a true trendsetting culinary neighborhood in SF. Plus this place is super casual and low key, they were even letting everyone byob since they don't have a liquor license yet. If you ain't first, you're last... and Rickybobby's is definitely in first! Here's the deal --James Moisey and Shane LaValley are the best there is. Plain and simple. They wake up in the morning and they cook excellence.Dear Eight Pound, Six Ounce, Newborn Baby Jesus, don't even know a word yet, just a little infant, so cuddly, but still omnipotent. I would just like to thank you for bringing Rickybobby into all our lives and for introducing me to my new favorite burger.Lord baby Jesus, we thank you so much for this bountiful harvest of the juicy delicious Beef and Bacon Burger with the bacon and beef ground together to form the perfect burger with 2 delectable patties, for the the spicy, yummy Crawshrimp Grits with spicy shrimp broth, and loads of crawfish and house sausage, and chicken drums braised, glazed, and sprinkled with sesame seeds and served with house blue cheese dressing. Let us not forget the perfectly cooked french fries and their ranch dressing. We thank you for the genuine and unpretentious service, excellent photographs on the wall, and the chance to watch some of best of awesomely cheesy, awesomely bad, awesomely awesome or awesomely 80s films projected on the wall. I will be back.Amen.Shake and bake!!! I enjoy scouring the city in search of the best burger.  Before hitting up Rickybobby the other day, I had found it at the Broken Record.  Sheer Mastery.  When I learned that the chefs from the Broken Record had moved to the Haight to open their own place, I had to be there.  Though it has a very similar menu to that of the Record, they have somehow managed to improve on what was already near perfection.  You can taste the pride that the chefs have in this place in the food.  Mouth watering deliciousness of indescribable proportions.  I could go on, but you really  have to taste for yourself.Couple this subtle yet distinct refinement with the fact that they now have a waitstaff and a much more comfortable ambiance, and you have one of the best places to go out and eat in all of San Francisco.  Zero pretension, just amazing food.   Other notable dishes are the pulled pork and the lobster mac and cheese.  Really though, just go there and order anything... Eat here. The entire menu consists of comforting, deliciousness and there is no way you will leave the restaurant without a huge smile on your face, and a happy tummy. Come hungry because you will want to try everything on the menu. Went here last night for a casual dinner.   The staff was really sweet and the chefs were chill behind the counter.  Upon being seated I was informed that the chefs want to be out by ten so could we order in the next five minutes? I was like hell yes, honey order what you want i have been drooling about this place opening for awhile.  We end up ordering crawfish and grits, shaved apple spinach salad, a drumstick with some crazy amazing sauce, lobster Mac and cheese and the pecan pie with icecream.  First let me just say there was not one dish that I did not like.  I already love Broken Record but this food just seemed more well thought out.  I thoroughly enjoyed every detail that went into my meal from the warmth and spice in the grits to the crispness in my salad.  Amazing food not crazy expensive and its BYOB.  Yeah I will be back pretty much on a weekly basis...  Big ups to the former chefs of Broken Record for moving closer to my house so I can enjoy you all the time. James and Shane know what time it is !! no matter what you get .. its always made w love and will make you want 2nds !! come here often :) To be honest. Pretty disappointing for opening night. Id like to think that there should be minimal room for errors. I would give this place a 3.5 at best. After reading raving reviews about broken record (an affiliated establishment), i expected ALOT.  While the serving staff was courteous, they lacked experience. For example, after asking for some utensils ( really shouldnt have to in the first place), they aimply walked over and threw a couple of forks on my unfinished plate. Really???? The food was at a questionable 4 as the menu was limited in choices and 2 out of the 4 things were good.  Must try the sweet potato tots and the bacon burger.  The crab and fontina grilled cheese was not great as it was kind burnt and lacked flavor.  The lobster mac n cheese was kinda liquidity and lacked cheesy consisteny. I try to yelp rate as honest as possible, so all in all the food is at 4 and the service is at a 3. But i know that this place will step up its game and become a huge hit. Thanks and have a nice day. # 4 reviewer for ricky bobby. Date & Time:  Friday December 14, 2012 @ 6pmLocation:  Former Rotee LocationDining Companions:  Birthday Boy Jeff, Dolores & MichaelScene:  Couples & Groups BYOB Pack the Communal Tables @ this Hip Spot Serving Up Comfort Food w/ a TwistMusic:  Eclectic Mix of Johnny Cash to Black KeyesDecor:  Instagram Photos on The Walls, ChalkBoard Menu below the Two-Headed Cow.  Bench-SeatingService:  Nice, Friendly, Genuine GuysImbibe:  BYOB for Now.  Izzie'sDevour:  Grilled Cheese,Crab+Fontina Sandwich w/ Tomato Soup, Beet Salad w/ GrapeFruit+Fried Oysters, Crawfish Grits, Glazed Drumsticks, Lobster Mac n' Cheese, Parm Chicken Sandwich, Sweet Potato Tater Tots, Pecan Pie a la Mode, Pistachio Ice Cream SundaeTotal:  $82.38Note:  Brought to You by The People of Broken Record Going to Rickybobby, you will see a bunch of delicious things written on a chalkboard, and be faced with one very simple dilemma: how do I fit them all in my belly? The premise here is simple. You could very well describe it as "comfort food", as it comforts me simply to know that a place like this can exist. There are no pretenses here beyond food that just tastes GOOD. There are items on the menu with a slight twist on a classic (grilled cheese -- with crab and fontina!), simply classic (pulled pork sandwich done to perfection), or legendary in their own right: The Beef & Bacon Burger. Fans of the Broken Record will know of it, as that's where head chefs James and Shane originally conjured it up before recently starting Rickybobby. There are many ways to describe this burger, but I've got my own. It's as if a long-lost manuscript was found, an illustration created by Leonardo DaVinci himself, which diagrammed the exact dimensions and meat-to-bread ratio of an invention he called "The Tastiest Burger". The recipe was lost, passed around from memory, incarnating itself in such modern variants as the In-N-Out Double Double. But this burger is the original recipe, the real deal. The burger (whose blown-up image currently stands as the only signage out front) is kind of a good representation of Rickybobby. No frills food that tastes awesome. I'd highly recommend the crawshrimp grits as an appetizer. You don't have to be familiar with either crawshrimp or grits to know that this is just delicious, and I want more of it, right now. The vibe is super laid back, and it's equally as good of a place to meet up for some food and drinks after work, or to go on a casual date with that special someone. I'm very excited to see how this place develops, and would not be surprised if  the crowds starting piling up with word of mouth. So if my review has done anything to convince you and your friends (and inevitably their friends) to patronize this fine new establishment, then please, save me a seat. And some sweet potatertots. I came here for opening night (last night).For the last 4.5 years, I have been on a quest to find the best burger in San Francisco.  I held burgers from Umami, Spruce, Nopa, Roam, Wayfare, Bix in high regard, but none of them really captured the essence of what I was looking for, UNTIL NOW.RickyBobby has somehow managed to reduce the humble cheeseburger to its very essence: theirs is pure, unabashed american umami.  They grind bacon into the meat, skip the lame veggies (no lettuce and tomato), add grilled onions/mushrooms, put it on a toasty, unique bun, and arrive at a place that is truly incredible.  At last, I can rest in peace.  Go now... I foresee this place getting Yelped to death shortly.
inspec_vio: No thermometers or uncalibrated thermometers Improper reheating of food  [ date violation corrected: 4/2/2014 ]

name: Kitchen Story 0
category: Breakfast & Brunch in San Francisco, CA
review_text: The food was amazing. I had the tilapia sandwich.  It was AMAZING.  My friend had the french toast and it was INSANE.  Like, I would like to eat it every day for the rest of my life until I couldn't fit through doors. I expected more from a place with a massive crowd out front and four stars on yelp.The worst of it was the Bloody Mary, not sure how a brunch spot could ruin a Bloody Mary, but they did. Tasted like tomato juice and too spicy - it wasn't drinkable. We had two sips of them and couldn't bother to try more, and I never leave a Bloody Mary behind.I had the pork belly huevos rancheros. They we're way too over seasoned (pork belly has enough flavor for the dish). Tasted as if they were trying to fit too many flavors in this tiny egg dish. I took a bite of something too strong that stuck with me through the yogurt.The best we had was the yogurt and granola, which, was good but also standard. This place must be riding on its reputation and hype, because it's just not worth the trip. Came here with a large group and the restaurant was very accommodating. Millionaire's Bacon is worth your time. I have tried to come here on several occasions for brunch but the wait is just too crazy. My friend and I cam here late one night for dinner and it was such a PLEASANT surprise! For appetizers we got pumpkin fries and ahi scoops. Pumpkin fries were good, but the ahi scoops were delicious! Seriously, get them, you won't regret it. For entrees, I got the POP belly and my friend got the Castro sea. The pop belly was AWESOME.  I love pork bell in general but this was so good I ate EVERYTHING on the plate. Though I will say the brussel sprouts were pretty salty so I wasn't a fan of those. Otherwise, this place is great. Portions are pretty good and the price is reasonable. Definitely going to come back here for brunch some time soon. I ordered from this restaurant tonight. They were prompt, which was nice, but the food was too expensive to arrive undercooked and spoiled. The Thai tea I ordered was twice the price of any other in the city and it was fermented. Gross. The burger arrived completely pink, even on the edges. The potatoes were good but not exceptional. I would have rather paid half the price for food that I expect to not be any good anyways. I was not expecting dangerous food from such a highly rated restaurant. My bar is not that high for take out, I just really don't want food poisoning. Hooray for bottomless mimosas and a wonderfully prepared California burger. Went into the city and it was nice to have a place to sit down and enjoy brunch with some friends. It was a chilly day and our server was kind enough to let us move from outside to indoors.Walking distance to Dolores Park. This place is the bees knees get anything on the menu with a side of millionaires bacon and you'll leave happy. Had the millionaires bacon and was amazed at how great it was. Came with potatoes, a croissant and some slices of fruit. Perfect way to start my day! Service was bang on to boot. We went with a group of 8 with dinner reservations and were seated promptly.  Asian fusion type offerings were all excellent.  Scallop and Millionaires Bacon sandwich was outstanding.  Good choice of beers as well.  We will return ! Saturday brunch wait time: 40mins (but totally worth it)Food quality: excellent Food price: affordable ~$10-15 per person Seating: indoor and outdoor (with heating)Came here with a party of 4. And here's what we ordered:Ricotta hotcakes with scrambled eggs and millionaire bacon on the side: comes in three pieces of hotcakes topped with fresh mixed berries, honey butter, and maple syrup on the side. the millionaire bacon was candied to perfection. Nice thick slices of bacon. Can't comment on the hotcakes personally but from my friends reaction it looked orgasmically good!Frisco Benedict: I had this plate and this plate comes with chicken and mango sausage, avocado, the poached eggs atop a slice of levain toast and crispy rainbow potatoes on the side with fresh fruits. The poached egg and the chicken mango sausage went perfect together with the fresh avocado! Tasted like a salad actually just without the greens :) Ribeye omurice: a friend ordered this and the expectation was the egg around the rice but it was just sitting on top of the rice which was OK with her. I tasted the rice part..very flavorful but it seemed like it could be better. Also came with crispy rainbow potatoes and a biscuit on the side and fresh fruits.Total price for 4: ~$45 not badAside from the wait time, the food was amazing. Maybe that I was starving but I would come again when given the chance. Even though they're known for brunch, the late night post movie meal was pretty amazing, too. It's too bad their kitchen closes by 10pm or so, but the nice thing is you can make a reservation for dinner.   At first, I was a little skeptical of the Asian fusion style diner food, but everything ended up being amazing comfort food. - Millionaire's Way: thick cut bacon with smoky maple syrup and asparagus. The asparagus was fine, but the bacon was amazing, and I could eat it with anything- POP & IING: I loved the sweet syrupy garlic ginger sauce on the Kurobuta pork belly. We had extra sauce, which we used to dip everything. Arugula holds up well to the strong flavor - "Burgah" Boy: maple syrup wagyu patty, more of the amazing millionaire's bacon, white cheddar, arugula. This was probably one of the best burgers I've had - it just had so much flavor to it - Pad See Ew: typical rice noodles but generous on the chicken, egg, carrots, and broccolini, so it wasn't just a bunch of noodles. The flavor was pretty right on and authenticThey also have beer and wine.  I feel like they would get a lot of business if they were open later to cater to the post Castro bar crowd, but I guess they need to be up and ready for breakfast every day.  I'm so excited we found this place. 3 1/2 stars actually but the millionaire's bacon is good for half a star.  Food is good, nothing special, but good. Prices decent for the city.  Crowd very mix, and loud.  Staff friendly and efficient.  Decor eclectic in a homey kinda way.  Came in on a very busy Sunday morning and had a short 20 minute wait.  By the way, that bacon is a glorified version of the Filipino tocino, just way super leaner.  Though the tocino is far tastier. Kitchen Story is this cute little place on 16th. Because it's a corner shop, you know it's bound to be busy. My good friend was visiting from Palo Alto, and I wanted to make sure I chose a spot that was close to public transportation for her...and also, Kitchen Story was a brunch thing in the past, and every time people went, I had to miss out. I could not let this happen again.Honestly, I had no idea what to expect from this place. From the name itself, the first thing I thought was, "Hmm, I wonder if this is an Asian place." And I was sorta right! Asian fusion breakfast! Who would have thought? The wait was about an hour or so, and we weren't really sure when or how we'd be seated, but it happened eventually, and it was a nice, sunny, Easter-y sort of morning, so it's not like we had anything better to do.The menu was so vast and filled with such enticing options, like okonomiyaki, omurice, and bugolgi burgers...all happily snuggled alongside ridiculously yummy-sounding things like Mascarpone stuffed deep-fried French toast and a bounty of scrambles. I usually have trouble deciding what I want, but I definitely freaked out and ordered randomly by the time they got to me. I ordered a spinach omelette (which I can't find on the menu anymore...hmm) so I could share with my vegetarian friend.These people definitely know how to plate their food. The wait time wasn't too long, especially with all the people during the Easter Sunday rush. Everything was delicious, but what I loved was the biscuit. Oh my goodness, that biscuit! I was so confused, so delightfully confused, at the flavor of this biscuit. At first, it looked like it was going to be one of those bay biscuits from Red Lobster, but with whatever butter they put on it made it taste like one of those scones from Lovejoys. Basically, there was no way this could have gone wrong for me. I left this place feeling pleasantly full.Only downsides were that we were cramped in our table, but again, it was a busy day; and if you're seated inside, it's way too loud to hear anyone anyway. It was hard to hold a conversation with someone sitting directly across from me, and that wasn't fun. I would definitely come back, because I want to try the lunchy part of the brunch menu. I'm down for a wagyu burger or something...just saying. Dear Kitchen Story, Good job.  I went to brunch this morning and with it being Thursday, there was no wait.  I was impressed by the decorations and atmosphere.  It gave it a really intimate and comfortable feel.  Another bonus is that the service was awesome!  They were very attentive and friendly. Now about the food...  I got the millionaire's bacon with eggs.  The millionaire's bacon was very sweet and thick.  I loved it, but I got tired of it pretty quick.  For some reason I really loved the croissant they gave me... and those rainbow potatoes!  I would definitely come back and try everything out cause everything looked so amazing!  Especially those lattes! Amazing food! The French toast is my favorite. Don't forget a side of millionaires bacon! Definitely enjoyed this place. That kooky Millionaires Bacon appetizer is amazing. Never have I spent $12.00 on two pieces of bacon and oh, my gah, it's worth every single penny. I had the fried chicken and the curry sauce was delish!Great service, very friendly, excellent food and awesome location. Will definitely be going back soon. I'm new to the Bay so the whole "bottomless mimosa" is still foreign/amazing to me. There was a solid 45 minute wait - totally acceptable especially with a party of 9, and again bottomless mimosas and you can drink while you wait! I had the pork belly rancheros. Now I love the belly of our favorite ungulate as much as the next guy, and this was legitimately one of the best dishes I have had since moving to San Francisco. The egg was perfectly poached, the kim chi picco was a great balance of spice which complimented the sweet/salty pork belly to perfection. The reason 4 and not 5 - well first of off it wasn't total perfection. The bottomless did have a bottom, and they started to get more orange juicy by the third round. The French Toast while innovative was just a large doughnut. And the millionaires bacon was very tasty, but for 6 dollars a side I would expect more than two slices. Of the nine dishes we had at our table mine was by far the stand out. After looking over Yelp last night for a dog-friendly, outdoor dining, delicious restaurant to eat at for brunch on a day trip today with my boyfriend and our dog, I came across this one! I noticed a ton of the reviews complained about the wait. I went on a Wednesday at 2pm and had no problem with the wait, but I think this is because we were seated outdoors. When I went inside they kinda gave me an attitude about needing to be seated outside because of our dog, but later another couple came with their dog too. I noticed a lot of reviews about having dogs here so I didn't think it would be a problem at all. Food came fast and it was quite yummy! We ordered the bulgogi burger and the chicken mango melt. The bulgogi burger was super yummy and had lots of interesting vegetables on it. The only thing I'd suggest is a little more bulgogi. The potatoes/french fries on the side were amazing! As for the chicken mango melt, that was also really good, but didn't really notice the mango flavoring, which was why my boyfriend was interested in it. I don't think it was very filling and it didn't seem like there was much chicken in there, but luckily we had many more food places to visit later :) i'd definitely come back for sure to try the french toast, Thai tea, and a few other items that caught my eye. This place was a great find! The menu is an awesome mix of different types of comfort food. We tried the pad thai and the fried chicken with coconut curry dipping sauce. I'm pretty sure I drank what was left of the dipping sauce when we were done... Their dessert menu isn't online but it's awesome as well --- we ordered two things, one had chocolate the other did not, both awesome. The portions are quite generous as well. Will definitely return! Best breakfast in San Francisco. If you eat nothing else at this place you must order the bacon. the food is amazing here .. It is a small spot .. so if you go during their busy time expect to wait for a table ... also there is great shopping near by .. With brunch being my favorite meal of any day, I decided to visit this hyped up breakfast joint that replaced a past favorite (tangerine). My group of 3 stopped by around 1:30pm on a sunny Saturday morning and waited approx 30 minutes! Not too shabby considering how intimidating the storefront looks every weekend I've driven past. Food: I ordered the franciscan scramble ($13) w/ cup of berry (add'l $2 which replaced the rainbow spuds). chicken mango sausage, avocado, pepper, but with swiss cheese that engulfed my entire scramble. I probably enjoyed my sides more than the scramble as berries and cheese biscuit w/ honeyed butter was perfect. My friend ordered the omurice- korean dish that basically resembles an omelette with fried rice stuffing- and she was thoroughly pleased so perhaps I'll order that instead.Interior/environment: super cute with both indoor and sidewalk seating available.Service: Nice and attentive! I definitely appreciate attentive staff and nice people, overallOverall: 3.5 stars but i probably wouldn't revisit unless my friends insisted and the wait was less than 30 minutes. I've been wanting to try this place for some time but never got a chance to go or just didn't feel like battling the park chaos around there but this past weekend was different. We originally were suppose to go to another spot for breakfast but seeing the line out the door we opted out and ventured out to seek another place for a good hearty breakfast. So what did we do? We searched Yelp! hahahaWell I guess it was meant to be because we only circled once and the parking gods parted the clouds and provided a rock star parking space right in front of the restaurant. I took it as a sign. It was time to try out this place. hahaMy girlfriend said that it use to be a restaurant called Tangerine which jogged my memory because that was the place where I had my first eggs benedict dish. Anywho that is neither here nor there.Location: Well read the above statement and get an idea. Parking is hard unless you have good parking Karma. :-)Service: Really quick and to the point. We choose to eat outside, which was your usual sunny but windy SF day. In other words it was cold but it was the shortest wait. Food: The food was great! I had the Belly Rancheros that had slow braised Kurobuta pork belly, avocado, arugula, Kimchi Pico De Gallo, spicy guacamole, corn tortilla. I have 3 words for this dish: IT WAS HEAVENLY! Although I didn't taste the Kimchi pico de gallo much but who cares the rest was melt in your mouth goodness.My girlfriend had the Ricotta Hotcakes. Words can't express how delicious these were.Overall the place is great. i love how the check comes on a book hence the name only reason I docked a star is because we didn't know who our server was because we were outside and I wanted to order a cappuccino but didn't know who our server was. Its ok its not a horrendous thing I know it was a busy time.If you are in this area and don't mind the wait, come check out this place. So, the wait time was a little annoying, but then again, we got there right when everyone else thought they should be hungry too. The food was amazing! I got the Mascarpone stuffed deep fried French Toast with chicken mango. It was very filling and very tasty. Our whole group got French Toast that day, and everyone loved their food. I also got a dirty chai while waiting, and some of my friends got bottomless mimosas. Had I not needed to drive, I would have done the same. Alas, it was a good drink. Make sure you get there early! This place is awesome. Service was on point, especially on the bottomless Mimosas, new England burger was life changing, definitely the place to go Asian fusion? lol.. I think I would classify it as Thai style American..The place is really good.. I've been several times now, and can say that not every dish has fit my palate, but there are some pretty awesome dishes here. Millionaire's bacon, French toast, and omelets are all pretty awesome. The side of rainbow potatoes are nice and crunchy and delicious. Today I had the two egg breakfast w/sausage and a side of millionaire's bacon. The main entrée also came with the rainbow potatoes and a biscuit. It was a great start to the day! So the reason I say its Thai style is that it reminds me of the non-Thai breakfast food I can get in Thailand.. First, the scrambled eggs are folder over into a type of pocket (like a half moon giant lightly made tamago). Second, the sausage was a irregularly shaped hand pressed patty. This reminds me a lot of street food and the fish xakes my mom used to make.. Third, a lot of their fried foods are done Thai style.. I'm not quite sure what the difference is.. but I think its just higher heat so it comes out crispier on the outside. I remember having the fried chicken one night and I had a sense of deja vu like I was eating food off a food cart in Bangkok..With all the kudos out there, I will say that I haven't been impressed with everything here.. The okonomiyaki (egg pancake) was really weird. It was not savory and didn't feel very substantial to me at all.. Can't win them all....One random novelty of the place is they clip the bill to a old book when bring it to you..Overall I think this place is amazing.. The wait can get long at times, so go early.. and snag a table outside if you can.. This place is like an Asian fusion gem in Castro!  I loved their brunch.  The millionaire bacon was so tasty- just the right amount of sweetness and saltiness.  Rainbow potatoes is definitely intriguing to the eye but also very appetizing as well- cooked to perfection!  (and I usually don't like potatoes)  I'm certainly coming back here again.  Big portions.  Weekends- take a risk because you may have to wait a long time.  We got lucky and waited about 20 minutes.  Parking around this area is also tough on weekends. I wish I could say the food was amazing but the Truth is that I couldn't even taste the food. I had the coconut latte and it was so hot, it burned my mouth. I couldn't taste anything else. Not the millionaire bacon or the egg on rice thing I had. Not my boyfriends eggs Benedict taco thing. I mean I am sure they were good. They looked good but they tasted like burned taste buds. :/ To date, I've been to Kitchen Story three times - twice for dinner and once for brunch, and the experience has consistently been amazing. The style of the restaurant is Asian flare meets California fresh, and there is both substance and style in the food. Among the dishes I've sampled:- Millionaire's bacon - sweet, salty, fatty, and crisp. A must-have at any time of day (it's on both the brunch and dinner menus)- Ahi tuna salad - fresh fish, mango salsa. Light but filling.- Pork tacos - well-seasoned pork with a variety of fresh salsas- Finger Lickin' chicken - crispy fried chicken with perfectly cooked fries and an amazing curry dipping sauce- Bottomless mimosas - need I say more?The service is impeccable, with frequent refills and quick preparation of food. The staff is very friendly and accommodating.The ambience depends on the time of day - it can get pretty hectic during brunch, but they also have a lovely outdoor seating as well. Dinner has been quieter - a good place to meet a friend or a date. On a weekend, expect to wait 30-50 minutes for a table for brunch. Their turnover is pretty quick and you can order mimosas while you wait for a table, though. All in all this is my go-to place to meet friends for dinner, and I'm always raving about it to others! Fortunately, I came here on a Tuesday and didn't have to deal with waiting in line for brunch.  This is definitely a cute little place with the wood table settings and there's also extra thought put in all of the dishes.  I'm a big believer in "presentation is everything," and this restaurant did just that.  Even when you ask for the check your receipt is delivered to you inside a book, to go along with their "story" theme. Gotta love the commitment. I ordered the Frisco Benedict, and it came with the side of rainbow potatoes.  The potatoes itself was just okay, but the mango chicken sausage was good.  I do wish cholula or tapatio was available, since i'm not big on tabasco sauce but that's just a minor preference thing.  Overall, the service was great the staff was very attentive, and because it wasn't super crowded we got to come in and enjoy brunch without waiting too long.Will come back to try rest of the menu for sure.  French Toast? Millionaire Bacon? Coming for you! :) Great ambiance! Very cozy and welcoming. I liked this place because it was very quick. Tried ribs tacos and finger lickin' ... Both were great. This is truely an amazing place, both for the quality of the food, and ambiance of the eating room.  All the dishes come out of the kitchen with a feel of human touch and refinement.  You really feel this east asian touch of harmonic human nature in the food.  Some japanese places also cary this feeling.The food truly has a unique fusion touch, and it is very easy pick items from the menu that satisfy a balance of meat, vegetables and rice.Note: the kitchen staff is different for lunch and dinner, this review is for dinner. I really like their curry dishes on the dinner menu.  Wine list is good.Brunch: eh.  The Millionaires bacon is good.  Everything else is pretty average.  When I went today, my food came out cold.  The service is average at best .I guess I'm surprised because people line up all day Saturday and Sunday to get in. All I can think of is that old Robbie Williams song, "Millennium" when I see their bacon. I don't eat much meat due to my stomach hating me, but I just HAD to try that stuff. WOAH. That shi cray. Tip: it's easier and cheaper to get if you just order an entree that has it already with it (you have to upgrade for $2 but it's worth it). Also you only need one order. One artery clogged per person, per brunch. That's my limit.The rest of brunch was also sick. (Sick in the "cool" way...not a great food descriptor? Whatev.) I got the Red and Green benedict. I love that I remember the name of the dish after two weeks; means it was THAT good. The boy ordered some sort of egg plus THE FRENCH TOAST. OH EM GEE YOU GUYS. GET THE FRENCH TOAST. It's mascarpone stuffed. It's fried. It's AMAZING. Imagine a light funnel cake stuffed with french toast...but like, without the creepy carnies that serve it to you. Amazing.This was my favorite brunch meal of San Francisco, and we went to 4 places that were all highly rated. Also, The Castro is just so cute. We ended up walking allllll the way to Height and Ashbury and then through Golden Gate Park. Definitely burned up that french toast. But who cares? I would eat that bad boy anytime, anywhere, no regrets. OH EM GEE, BEST BACON EVER!!!If you're like me and know the only way to eat bacon is drenching it in maple syrup, you have to come here for the millionaire's bacon! It's everything you look for in bacon. Sweet, salty, sugary crunchy coated goodness! I dream about this bacon!Deep Fried Mascarpone Stuffed French Toast was meh, the dough/bread was a little too chewy for me. Presentation was really cute though!Ribeye OmuriceOne of the dishes that makes Kitchen Story different from your typical brunch joints. This dish is tasty, hearty, and flavorful. Rice, eggs, and meat with this amazing gravy. I wanted to lick the plate! Love this place! The service is great and the food tasted wonderful. They have a very unique menu but anyone can find what they want on it. The food is diverse and this is a great place to go to especially if you're an SF foodie like me. Kitchen Story was recommended to me by my BGF (brothers girlfriend lol) and fellow Yelper, Kathleene E. Luckily for us, we came on a Wednesday morning so there were about 4 customers inside and 2 hour street parking was a breeze. The space itself is very cute; like my BGF said, it looks like you're in someone's nice, big kitchen. Might I also add that I made a reservation through my OpenTable account and earned a $20 certificate! Ca-Ching! Ca-Ching! (That's my Filipino jackpot sound.) Enough small talk. On to the food. The Mascarpone Stuffed Deep Fried French Toast was good; but it tasted nothing like French Toast, hence the 1 star I knocked off. I love my French Toast, and when I order French Toast, it must taste like French Toast, regardless of what it is stuffed with. But let's be real, what we REALLY came for was the MILLIONAIRE'$ BACON (Ca-Ching! Ca-Ching!) Hubby liked it a lot. It's definitely a nice change from regular bacon. Chewy and sweet. Very yummy.Overall, I enjoyed our food and experience at KS. Thank you, BGF! Will we be back? Maybe for some of that Millionaire's Bacon...Ca-Ching! I loooove French toast but their French toast is amazing!! Try the mascarpone stuffed deep fried French toast with a side of millionaires bacon- perfect combo of sweet and savory goodness! I also tried their Frisco Benedict and the CA burger. The Frisco Benedict was delish, but everything else that we ordered overshadowed it. The CA burger was juicy, flavorful, and the goat cheese just melted in my mouth. I will be back for more yummy goodness. Your tastebuds will def have a happy ending for sure :) Um CUTEST BRUNCH PLACE EVER?! I can't believe we almost didn't make it; when P drove by we saw the line for Ike's overlap with the entrance for Kitchen Story and thought there was a wait. I made him go around so that I could get a better look and yay! We made it! I love mason jars and they served their drinks in the cutest ones. I wanted to take the mason jars home with me haha. We ordered an iced tea and some fruity lemonade. The iced tea was unsweetened and perfectly refreshing while the lemonade was a tad too concentrated that we had to dilute it with water. I ordered the Deep Fried French Toast with Mascarpone filling and a side of Millionaire's Bacon to share. They were both to die for. The French Toast was topped with delicious fresh tangy berries that complimented the sweet mascarpone pudding cream inside a deep fried toast. The bacon was thick and being Canadian, that maple syrup encrusted over it, just got me. Omg I need more. Like, now. First off let me say wow! This place is so amazing! Im pretty sure its Thai owned too! This place is a treasure to San Francisco.  I love having eggs Benedict and Kitchen Story had a variety for me to choose from. How it was deliver was on point. My girlfriend order the Omurice which was bomb! I highly recommend this place to new people. This place will not disappoint. Will be returning! Oh and did i mention they have bottomless mimosas!? :) Damn, man. People on Yelp, you were not messing around about that millennium bacon. So delicious. Sweet but oh so savory. And the wagyu beef in that burger? Totally worth anything. God, I feel like I could eat a hundred of those bad boys. I'm really craving one at this very moment. Juicy, tender, light but filling. Oh man. If it wasn't 18 dollars for just one of them, I'd eat it every day. The rest of the food? The fries were great, crispy and just a touch salty. The seafood was not impressive, sadly. It tasted like light seafood curry. But, it was definitely better than I've had. Great small restaurant, lots of booths and tables. I want to come back for brunch. HOLY BEJEESUS CHRIST !!I seriously dream about their coconut latte !! Everyone should order it !! It's not sweet or strong!!Their french toast is a friend piece of heaven !The wait for brunch is ridiculous, but it is well worth it.I loved this place so much I went back the next week for dinner !!
