(Oh yes, I did !! )The dinner is just as amazing. I ordered the sizzling steak over rice and was barely able to finish it .. but it was just so darn good I had to unbutton my pants . (Yes,  not so classy, but their dim lighting was in my favor )Top of the line service as well.Promise you won't be disappointed. Been here about 3-4 times. Love this place. Kitchen story is legit and great breakfast/brunch spot. I love the fact I can have Thai Ice Tea with my omelette. Bring your friends here! Charming decor (especially at the back of the restaurant), excellent service, and not too loud to enjoy the conversation with your friends. Would give 5 stars if the vegetarian options were more extensive. Oh, Kitchen Story, how I adore thee! People rave about the weekend brunch, and there are long waits to prove it (Millionaire's bacon lives here), but the real secret is dinner, which features delicious Thai specialties, all sorts of curries, and my personal fave, The Castro Tower. Their $18 burger is an umami explosion for the record books. Also, they open for breakfast at 8:00 am during the week, so if you want the brunch experience without waiting for an hour, go during the week. Great place for brunch in the Castro. The eggs benedict was great and the service was as well. I didn't have to wait too long, 5-10 minutes. Came in on a Monday afternoon. No line! Very tasty brunch foods. A little different than most brunch places but couldn't have enjoyed it more! We had the deep fried French toast and the New England burger and both were very good! Deep fried French toast is definitely a must. Service was quick and attentive. This is a tough review to write, mostly because the food was a little unmemorable, but the company and the service was wonderful (and made up for it!) Back to this food thing. None of the many dishes our group tried were bad at all--it's actually the opposite. Everything was tasty, but there was no "ka-pow!" or "Oh jeezus... that's goooooood"... It's kind of hard to explain, but I left there almost forgetting what I had as a main course, which was a tasty pan-fried noodle dish that needed some kick. The service was super since the moment we brought our group in--we did not want for wine or beverages without them asking to refill us first. Plus, were having such a great time that we were being ridiculously loud, but no sass from the staff. We even closed the place down and not a word. These people are probably the nicest ever. I think I might need to try the brunch next time I'm in town, but for now, I'd say Kitchen Story is worth a try! We dinner here for a friend's birthday. Started with pumpkin fries, the split the mango salad with tiger prawns.  For the main course, we had the Wild Salmon, Burgah Boy and the Finger Lickin'. This is such a low key place, and it's comfy & has a homey feel. The food (dinner) was really good overall. If you do not like your food too spicy, tell the wait staff it make it mild or else your mouth sizzling. I'd say though that it's not a $$ place, it's closer to $$$. The prices here are not cheap, you pay more for the artistry & presentation of the food (quality too) vs quantity. Kitchen story is absolutely delicious and surprising. Their menu is a mix of California and Thai.  The atmosphere was relaxed, casual, with a dash of quirkiness (books lining the walls.)  I got the millionaires bacon to start--it was very rich and delicious. Then I got the curry which was also quite good! No complaints here. The food here is undeniably delicious; however, their small portions just don't match up to how much they charge. We loved this place. It more than lived up to its reviews. Millionaire's Way was even better than billed. We also shared Castro Sea and Dancing Queen and both were excellent. If we didn't live in Boston, we'd eat here often! Highly recommend. mimosas are great! brunch is ok. We like Tangerine which was located in this location for years.Now it's Kitchen Story and we LOVE Kitchen Story.  I swear its the same ownership and the food is smartly prepared, plates well laid out and super tasty.  There is ALWAYS a long line on the weekends for brunch.The Mimosa special is a good deal especially if stumbling around the Castro afterwards is part of your plan.The staff are smart in how they pack the place and friendly without being outgoing. Certainly, worth your visit. This is a cute place tucked in the Castro. It was pretty easy to get a reservation on a Saturday.We started off with the Millionaire's Way which we were told is one of their signature appetizers. It was okay but nothing special. I ordered the Dancing Queen. The meat was tasty and so was the rice and we got a kick out of the waiter lighting it on fire. But the beans were cold and bland. The service was spotty - we had a few different servers and could never really figure out who "our" designated waiter was...I doubt we'll be back when there are so many other Castro restaurants with tastier food. came here with a party of three for a casual brunch. got here at 1130 and it was only 10 min wait. after 1130 the lines got longer and got a full house where the wait was over 30 mins. I suggest you come here early to avoid waiting. the service was so so since it was so busy they did take a bit slower for the service. they also ledt the water cup and jar empty.  we also had to flag them for the bill. now onto the food. I ordered the tilapia burger which was reasonable for 12 bucks. the fish abd mango salsa was good. the buns were soft although a bit try. the salad that came with ut was good and not too wet. also the millionaire bacon was a thick slice and it tasted sweet and very good. I like the fat that was on the bacon. they say it takes 5 hrs to anke it. I recommend this. although during brunch it doesnt come with asparagus. I wont be coming here soon unless I crave the bacon other than that nothing too special about their brunch not worth the wait to me. Fun and interesting food. The burger can be overkill esp with the Millionaire Bacon, recommend sharing with a friend. ;) Kitchen Story is officially my favorite brunch place in San Francisco and I will be back for more! :)I came here with my coworker for lunch this week. We booked reservations just in case there was a wait as we had to head back to work after. When we arrived, there was no wait at all and the restaurant wasn't too packed. From what I learned, having brunch on weekdays is way better than having it on weekends because of the long waits. Anyways, I had the Ribeye Omurice which had scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry pepper, spinach, and scallion with demi glazed sauce. It was also served with a croissant and some rainbow potatoes. I love their rainbow potatoes! It has a nice crisp on the outside yet soft on the inside. The scrambled eggs were really fluffy and pretty! It was HUMUNGOUS! The marinated ribeye reminded me of bulgogi. It was very flavorful and tender. Not too salty or sweet. Everything was very tasty and delicious. Really big portions, by the way. Definitely worth the price. I want to be back for their bottomless mimosas one day and try other dishes on their menu. I had heard that Kitchen Story is also the same owner as Sweet Maple. So if I had to compare, I definitely like Kitchen Story a lot more! It's a really cute place that makes you feel at home. There is also a patio for those who want to sit and eat outside. Plus, the food tastes way better at Kitchen Story. One interesting thing is that they give you the bill with a book. Cute and clever, Kitchen Story! Stopped here serendipitously when next-door Ike's was packed. Glad we came. Green Panini, Banmi Panini, Stone Pot made for a perfect late lunch for 3. Seasoning just right, unexpected extra attention to presentation, friendly fast service. No hint of rushing us even though our meal went past closing. Cool. One of my favorite meals in the city. Rustic, laid-back ambiance. Tuna tartar was excellent and we would have been perfectly happy just with the eggplant. What a cute little place! Went here for lunch with one of my coworkers today, and knew exactly what I wanted to order. I originally wanted the ribeye omurice, but I gave up red meat for Lent (sadness) and opted for the Frisco benedict, which is a chicken mango sausage, avocado, cherry pepper and hollandaise. Served on ciabatta and paired with rainbow potatoes, it was presented so beautifully I almost didn't want to eat it. However, it was so delicious that I surprisingly ended up eating the whole thing.I also ordered a thai tea latte, and it had just the perfect amount of foam! They're also known for their millionaire's bacon, but I've had it at Sweet Maple before and I'm not a big fan of the chewy bacon, so I wasn't really missing anything. Classic brunch fare in the heart of the Castro!  Massive juicy artisan burgers, paninis, and of course, breakfast standards, including the all-famous "millionaire" bacon (they even have a poster explaining how it's made near the restroom!)  Definitely going back next chance I get. right when i flew into s.f. the first restaurant we went to was kitchen story. and before i continue the rest of the review... i want to really point out out of ALL the places ive been to in s.f throughout my 4 day trip there.... this was the ONLY place i truly enjoyed. not only was EVERY dish amazing...not just good. AMAZING... but the service was really amazing as well.so to continue..our friend made a reservation there for 13 people in honor of my friends bday. they accomodated us by splitting the bill by two tables and also gave the bday boy a small chocolate cake? but that was really good to. heres a list of the things we ate:APPETIZERS:-Millionaire's Way 12 Try our famous Millionaire's Bacon, grilled organic asparagus and homemade smoky Maple syrup sauce -Ahi Scoops 12 Pan-seared sesame crusted Ahi tuna served with spicy cucumber seaweed salad, crispy yam, ginger and wasabi cream sauce -Crispy Calamari 11 Red curry battered Monterrey squid with spicy pepper, garlic aioli and homemade pickle-"CASTRO Tower" 12 Diced Maguro tuna* ceviche tossed with roasted rice, kaffir lime, lemongrass, diced mango served with crispy chips MAIN COURSE:-POP' Belly $19 Overnight slow cooked Kurobuta pork in five spices, turmeric curry rice, Brussels sprouts with fermented beans sauce -Dancing Queen 20 Grilled Snake River Farm Wagyu Beef Flank Steak, spicy garlic Thai long bean, roasted rice sauce, 151 rum, ginger rice -Panang Curry; avocado, peanut, bell pepper, basil, crispy yam 14There were a few more that other people ordered that I didnt taste... but i promise you you cant go wrong with ANY of these dishes i just listed. everything is so well presented and flavorful..i wish they opened one up in LA!! (hint hint)HIGHLY recommended :D Came here a few weekends ago for the first time!! The place is pretty cute and kind of small, but they have outdoor seating too! The employees are really attentive; my water glass was always full and they even brought over a pitcher because I guess they noticed I was downing my glasses pretty fast haha. The millionaires bacon came out first and oh my god it was so good!! I cringed when looking at the price but wowww. I tried to eat it slowly because I wanted to savor it, but sooner than later it was gone. :( Fyi I was on their Facebook page and I saw that they put a recipe up for it!! Could it be? One day I'll try making it for myself... One day. As for the main dish, I ordered the frisco Benedict, which had chicken mango sausage, cherry peppers, avocado, lemon hollandaise, and a perfectly poached egg on top! The chicken mango sausage was delicious and still stood out through the egg yolk and the hollandaise! The dish also came with rainbow potatoes and fruits. I also got to try a little of the pancakes! I don't know if it was because I hadn't had pancakes in a while or because they were actually good, but I really enjoyed them!! Paired with the blackberries, strawberries, and blueberries, the pancakes were delicious. Coming from a person who doesn't like pancakes that much, I hope it means a lot!Overall this is a great place for breakfast/brunch with good service and yummy food, I definitely recommend it! The only bad part is parking.... Haha. I definitely want to come back for the millionaires bacon.. And to try the marscapone stuffed French toast!!! The wait for any good Sunday brunch in this city is like trying to get into a trendy bar in New York City. 1 hour plus is very normal. Luckily this place will serve brunch till 3pm everyday. I love it here. On a sunny day their outdoors seats are the perfect blend of sun and shade. The service is always excellent as well. Their patio was closed today but we had our dog with us, so they were very cool about opening up the patio for us.The indoor seating is very intimate and good for dates. Also good for a small group of friends. Like all SF hotspots, they are tiny. So I wouldn't roll up with 10 best friends but 2-4 would make a good brunch date.The food is awesome. I had the pork belly benedict today and my husband had the marscapone french toast. Both so very yummy. The bbq pork belly was a fusion dish served on small tortillas and kimchi de gallo. NOM NOM NOM!!!! It is fusion brunch so be adventurous and try all the great finds on the menu. Artichoke watercress benedict is also a win! We love coming here. But if you are here on the weekends, be prepared to wait an hour. For the most part every dish has some type of cheese in it. The lemon French toast was bomb not to mention thee Millionaires Bacon :) NOTE: This a review for BRUNCH!Every weekend my roommates and I always have a hard decision where we want to brunch. This place is right around the corner where we live so we come here pretty often. It's a really great place to brunch on the weekends (haven't come here for dinner) but the prices are kind of expensive and the wait can be pretty long so I wouldn't come here if I woke up late.FOOD: 4.5/5The food here is really really good. Every time I come here, whatever I order it is super delicious and I lick clean the plate. Most of the time I get eggs with some type of meat, either an english muffin or a crumpet (or something like that) and some freshly fried rainbow potatoes with a side of fruit. I wish they seasoned their eggs (they come unseasoned) but that's just a minor gripe. They perfect their Eggs Benedict with their amazing hollandaise sauce and their over-easy eggs are cooked to perfection. Everyone here is going CRAZY over the Millionaire's Bacon but to be honest their Mango Chicken and Pork Belly are absolutely delicious as well and costs much less. Their Millionaire's Bacon is pretty much a big fat slab of bacon covered in maple syrup, thai spice (think spicy honey garlic wings) and sugar making it salty, sweet and spicy all at once. It's really good and everyone should have it once but it's too heavy for me TBH and quite expensive. It only loses the 0.5 because it doesn't blow me out of the water. The flavours are familiar and delicious but it is nothing to scream out about - it's just some really good brunch.AMBIENCE & SERVICE: 4/5 Their Service is excellent. Everything you expect out of a good restaurant - they fill your water, your bottomless mimosas, they're super nice and they give your bill in a nice cute book (which is different every time). The ambience is also very nice and casual, when the sun is out they have a patio seating where it's super nice to sit out. My biggest gripe is the wait though. This has absolutely nothing to do with the restaurant itself but on Sat & Sun mornings, if you come here at peak brunch hours (12-2ish) expect to wait at least 1-2 hours for seats. Here is where I think this restaurant is simply just not worth that amount of time for waiting. I'm not sure if everyone in this area just comes here or everyone just comes to this area to go to this place but it definitely isn't worth 2 hours of waiting. Not to mention the bottomless mimosas so people stick around longer than usual. Come here early if you don't want to wait with the huge crowd.PRICE: 3/5This place is really goddamn expensive. I'm not kidding. It's around 12 bucks not including tax or tip just for a typical 2 eggs, bacon, muffin, potatoes breakfast and bottomless mimosas are a whopping 16 dollars. 16 DOLLARS! That's pretty goddamn expensive for bottomless mimosas. The millionaire dollar's bacon is also pretty expensive too and everyone goes gaga over it. It really isn't worth that amount of money - I mean it's good the first time but I wouldn't consistently come here just cause I don't want to go broke. Everything here runs up $13-$15+ so it's not cheap here, and I don't think the food is worth the amount of money they charge. It's good but not screaming AMAZING (as I said, not worth a 1 hour wait).WRAP 3.75/5I'll round it up to 4 because I really do like this place and I had some great experiences here. The food is fantastic and the service is great. However, there is just a huge wait sometimes and the price is pretty expensive for what they serve. I'd definitely come here a few times but I wouldn't be a regular just because I don't think the food is THAT amazing to wait an hour behind a huge crowd and pay that amount of money for breakfast. Definitely do check it out if you haven't come here before (and especially if you've never had brunch before) just make sure you come early at around 10-11am before the crowd picks up and try the millionaire's bacon. Just don't count me in as a regular just because of the price and the overhype people give it. came here for breakfast after church. like wow, the breakfast is awesome!! ample portions, beautiful plating (which i'm a sucker for since i'm a designer :D), and reasonable prices. apparently a popular neighborhood place with a long queue. waited 1/2 hr for a table but it was worth it. the service itself was pretty quick. definitely will go back to try out their dinner. Kitchen Story is by far our favorite brunch place the past couple of years.  I feel silly not having reviewed it until now.  Maybe I wanted to keep it a secret, even though it's hardly one at this point.When they re-made Tangerine into Kitchen Story, they got everything right.  They ditched the old decor which was stale and lifeless and brought the right modern texture to everything from the table dressing to what adorned their walls.  They kept the Asian fusion concept but changed nearly every dish, while maintaining the gorgeous presentation of the dishes themselves. I have so many favorite dishes from their menu after dozens of visits but the standouts have to be the following:- The Millionaire's bacon - applewood bacon dusted with chili and brown sugar and draped with maple syrup - A MUST TRY- The Mom's benedict - house-made pork wine sausage, meyer lemon hollandaise - quite good!- The Bulgogi burger - a Korean-style marinated rib-eye, mixed green, tomato, scallions, carrots, jack cheese - my mouth waters thinking of this dish- The Ribeye omurice - scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry pepper, spinach, scallion. Demi glazed sauce. - Same meat as the Bulgogi burger but served over a bed of eggs with a sweet, tangy sauce; frickin' amazing.Their Achilles heel is their cocktail menu, it's pretty lacking.  But the food more than makes up for it. My friends and i went here for a group dinner with a reservation a few saturday nights ago. We were a big group, lets say about 15 people. dinner reservation was 8:30, we didnt get seated until past 9. service was a bit slow since they were busy. Other than that the food was yummy. REALLY GOOD BRUNCH. Got 2 poached eggs with millionaires bacon and the French toast with berries, iced dirty chai latte, and a mimosa. The bacon was so damn good.  The French toast too. I was surprised. I'll be back here First time out to SF and this brunch definitely satisfied my foodie nature. The millionaire's bacon is out of this world - I've never had better bacon in my life! I followed up some tastes of bacon with bottomless mimosas and the belly rancheros. Food and drink were 5/5! My only gripe was that our bottomless mimosas were cut short 15 minutes before they officially closed at 3:00 with no warning before we ordered. Got the lemon french toast which came with enough strawberries, blueberries and blackberries. Also ordered  a side of millionaire's bacon, which was really good (believe the hype) but also made me hate myself after finishing it, along with the scrambled eggs for the  complete breakfast option. Service was good and I liked the ambience a lot--lots of natural light, open kitchen and bookshelf lined with old paperbacks. Nice touch to put the bill on an old paperback, I suppose in line with the name. Will have to skip dinner after this hearty, self-indulgent breakfast. The Millionaire's Bacon is, in fact, a thing, one which you will probably order (or sneak a bite from when your starry-eyed dining buddy looks around the room to ensure everyone sees that he ordered it). And it's good, in the same way sex, breathing, truffle oil and Gauguin are good - there exist some indisputable absolutes. Candied bacon belongs on the list.Beyond this cornerstone of their Asian fusion menu, Kitchen Story is anticlimactic. Excepting a fresh, bright Castro Tower - Maguro tuna ceviche Thai'd up with kaffir lime, lemongrass, and diced mango scooped to your fishy face aboard crispy chips - and the fun and funky pumpkin fries, the dishes left me wanting. The star (anise) of any menu should bedazzle, yet the POP Belly muted the slow cooked Kurobuta pork in to a pool of poorly rendered pig fat, turmeric curry rice, and Brussels sprouts with fermented beans sauce that had a severely chemical finish. Zero sweetness, incredibly rich and overwhelmingly fatty, I've had the black hog before and this was no shining example.Other items drew attention, and I soon regretted not opting for the Burgah Boy (a maple Wagyu patty slapped with Millionaire's bacon) or the Big Eye Sandwich (day boat scallops, seared and... slapped with Millionaire's bacon) or anybaconthing elsebacon with bacon on its bacon. I guess the entire experience felt like a culinary petting zoo: scraggly plates milling about a one-trick pony. Good for kids, I reckon. Despite a slow start, the story of my dinner at this restaurant was full of laughs due to fabulous company, delicious food, big wine, and a casual fun environment...Just as sometimes it may take a few pages to connect with a good book, it did take a tad bit longer than ideal to get acknowledged the Tuesday night we were there.  Although the restaurant was slammed when we arrived, so no hard feelings!  Our party of seven decided to share a bunch of appetizers including Millionaire's Way, Fried Pumpkin, Sweet Caroline, the Castro Tower, and Garlic Asparagus.  None of them disappointed.  Neither did our entrees, but I think the highlights were the Pumpkin Curry, Red Curry, Pad See You, and Burger.Our wine glasses and water glasses stayed full thanks to the attentive staff... and we were celebrating a birthday amongst our group, so we did share one dessert and it provided what?  You guessed it... a happy ending!Very clever, by the way, that the check presenter was an actual book... smart thinking, Kitchen Story folks ;)Needless to say, I would not hesitate to return. OMG this places is Awesome first time there Breakfast was so good. It's one of the best breakfast I had in long time :) Came here for a weekend brunch, and it just so happen to be the nicest day in SF.  I ordered the Frisco Benedict with chicken mango sausage, avocado, cherry pepper, topped with meyer lemon hollandaise. It also came with a side of colorful fried potato bites and 2 pieces of fruit. We also ordered a side of the Millionaire's bacon (how can we not when it's raved above and beyond on yelp). I devour the Frisco Benedict, the cherry pepper was loaded with lots of flavor and the avocado goes so well with the bread (instead of your o' fashion English muffin). What surprised me was the chicken sausage that is actually a patty they topped on the benedict. The eggs were poached to perfection, but had a really strong taste of vinegar. The millionaire bacon is sweet and savory. It's not your typical crispy bacon and it melts in your mouth. Brunch didn't disappoint at all, will come back to try other things on the menu like the Belly Rancheros or the dirty chai.... This restaurant has a great vibe to it with outdoor seating, a bar area, and a very efficient staff who happily handed over the most amazing bloody mary I have ever had while we were waiting.The bloody mary was spicy as hell (ordered it extra spicy and they actually listened) with bits of kimchi in it.  It was topped with a variety of pickled and raw vegetables.  I am a bloody mary fan and this was probably the best one I have ever had.  I strong suggest you order it.I ordered the Belly Rancehros, a delicious combination of pork belly, poached eggs, and kimchi and it was definitely amazing.  The burger was pretty good as well but it was difficult to keep together as it disintegrated into a mush of bun, burger, and avocado.We got a side of millionaires bacon which as unreal, a mix of thick cut delicious bacon dusted with spices and maple syrup.Everything here was presented immaculately and the place was very well ran.  I highly suggest getting some breakfast here and if possible participating in the bottomless mimosas. Nice home like setting kitchen throughout the restaurant. The bacon is thick and sweet, tastes just like ham. The mimosas are strong and yummy. I really enjoyed the atmosphere in addition to the delectable brunch. I ordered the mascarpone deep fried French toast and a side of Millionaire's bacon. There was no wait on a Sunday for brunch... Though that may have been because it was raining. It's a close walk to Dolores park... Makes for a good date venue! Kitchen Story, visit #1. We had a group booking for dinner and I'd forgotten to look over the menu beforehand (which never happens). Thankfully I quickly spied Yelp mentions of the "Millionaire's Bacon" and knew I needed something with that in it. I decided to go for a burger under the "Mom's Special" section of the menu and ordered the "Burgah" Boy: Maple Syrup Wagyu Patty, Millionaire's Bacon, Vermont White Cheddar, arugula, super crispy russet wedges, housemade pickle. For an $18 burger I wasn't sure what to expect and was delighted when it arrived - sure, it was massive but I could still eat it without deconstructing it. My only negative comment would be that mine was a little overcooked for medium rare but it didn't cause any problems. The bacon is absolutely delicious - really thick cut, rich and sweet, the flavours of the burger gelled together really well. I also really loved the russet wedges which were cooked perfectly and even though I was really full, I still kept shovelling them in. I ordered a passion fruit iced tea which I expected to be sweet but it wasn't. No drama - I swapped drinks with Flo who had the raspberry lemonade and we were both happy. Service was friendly if a little rushed but there didn't seem to be many people on for the size of the restaurant and how busy it was. There was three tables of groups of around 8 (that's what happens when Yelp CMs hit San Fran for CM Week!) and I think they did the best in the circumstances. Kitchen Story, visit #2. Well, it's not happened yet but seeing as we're staying a block away from here for the next week, we'll definitely be back. We got here just past 10:30am on a Saturday while it was pouring rain so I thought the wait wouldn't be too bad, but we still waited for about 20-30 minutes.  The wait for the food is a bit long too, so allot a good 2-3 hours to brunch here.We all shared one order of the millionaire's bacon.. honestly it was good but I feel like I could pretty closely re-create it at home.  At $6.50 for 2 strips, I thought it was overrated.I enjoyed my frisco benedict.  The eggs were poached beautifully and I really liked the chicken mango sausage.  Really liked the omurice too, if you're craving something on the meatier side. Good ambiance, good food. Not exceptionally great. My friend brought me here and I was oh so pleasantly surprised to find that it was right next to Ike's!This is a cute little brunch place which has a pretty nice atmosphere & decorations.When my friends and I arrived, we waited about 15 mins and were promptly seated in order of arrival. ( this place is pretty organized & has wait-time updates )I ordered the eggs benedict with rainbow potatoes ! AND I loved the eggs, made perfectly like how I love 'em. Pretty runny & good. My favorite part was the rainbow potatoes! They were so delish, they're basically a variety of different potatoes! For those who love potatoes, you're in for a treat. hehe. ( i love potatoes...fries....yumm )We also ordered millionaires bacon, thanks to yelp :p, and it lived up to it's reputation! It's super sweet and THICK. Originally, I thought it was quite pricey for two pieces of bacon, but it's so filling that I could barley finish it. I love sweet stuff, but be warned: it's really sweeeet.I'm basically a regular, love this place! Oh & they give you your receipts in a little book. Hehe, hence kitchen story. Great brunch spot! I think this one was hovering at 4 stars, but what bumped it up to 5 stars is the lack of a wait if you go at a reasonable hour! Brunch in this city can be ridiculously hard to come by - not due to the lack of places offering brunch but because I just really don't want to wait 2+ hours to eat some brunch. Cue Kitchen Story where we walked in around 11 AM and there was NO wait.Favorite part was the millionaire's bacon! I love bacon, so I had to try this out: and YUM. It is a thick cut giant slab of bacon, sweetly glazed and marinated and just beautiful. I liked the asian-fusion decorations and food - sometimes Asian fusion can go very wrong, but they did a good job here balancing the flavors. I had to try the Dirty Chai - chai with a shot of soju and a shot of espresso - it's a perfect drink for brunch. I hope this place stays under the radar just a little longer so I can continue to get quality yummy delicious brunch without an hour+ wait!!! love the bacon and deep fried French toast. The best brunch in a crowded district. I really like this place for brunch! The Frisco benedict is so yummy! The hot cakes and french toast are also really good! The millionaire's bacon didn't fit my taste buds; I know a lot of people like it, but it was way too sweet for my liking. I've been coming here often the past month, which must mean something. Deducted a star because of the service, it's always hard to flag down a waiter. My two friends and I came here Sunday morning and it was packed. The Host was a bit frazzled but told me it would be a 35-minute wait. I didn't believe it based on the huge crowd outside, so I made a quick trip to Tartine for a snack. By the time I got back, they called our name. The host had timed it perfectly!We agreed to sit outside but without heatlamps (which they later told us they'd be installing in a few weeks), and a wind that suddenly picked up, it was freezing. We asked to be moved inside and was told that it would be a short wait. The staff was very friendly and the bottomless mimosas kept coming. By the time they moved us inside, our food was set down in front of us within 60 seconds. I'm not kidding. So well timed.I had the deep friend French toast which is really fried. For real. And it's actually stuffed with mascarpone. I'm emphasizing these things because I've been to other establishments that promise similar things but aren't really fried and hardly stuffed. They nailed it. I made it a complete meal with two eggs cooked exactly as I had ordered and pork sausage which was the right amount of greasy.The millionaire's bacon, as nearly everyone has pointed out, is excellent. I really wasn't expecting such excellence after my mediocre MarketBar breakfast the day before, but I will absolutely be back here. There were many things on the menu that I wanted to give a try. I think I love all things MILLIONAIRE BACON. Yummmmmmm! This place is owned by the same owner as Sweet Maple and Blackwood so the millionaire bacon is gooood! And the wait here wasn't too bad. I do like this story theme they have going here. They give you the bill clipped to a book too! How cute. I usually get a Benedict with millionaire bacon at the other restaurants but today I tried the BLT with millionaire bacon. It was delicious! In case you don't know what millionaire bacon is, it is a thick piece of bacon with a glaze on it so it is sweet. The texture reminds me of beef jerky but more moist. You gotta try it if you haven't! Decor (4 stars)The restaurant is visually impressive and gives a warm homey feeling.  I loved the rustic atmosphere with the driftwood tables, open kitchen, and wide windows that faced the street.  The books stacked on shelves along the wall left me feeling like I was sitting in someone's kitchen/dining room.Food (3.5 stars)We ordered:Crispy Calamari ($11) - We loved the red curry batter used on the calamari as well as their garlic aioli. It was tasty and nicely crisped.  The plate was beautifully presented as well.Millionaire's Way ($12) - Almost the same side dish at Sweet Maple but comes with 3 pieces of grilled asparagus and homemade maple syrup sauce at almost twice the cost. We've only had the millionaire bacon here once, but it seemed a bit smokier and less sweet/spicier compared to Sweet Maples. Personally, we prefer Sweet Maples.Dancing Queen ($20) - The plate is nicely presented and before you actually get to eat, they pour the 151 over your meat and light it on fire. The steak was tender and delicious and didn't need the extra sauce that came with the meal. The long beans accompanies the steak/rice very well. "A" loved the ginger rice.  Pop Belly ($19) - Another beautifully presented dish!  There were 6 slices of pork belly over a bed of tumeric curry rice.  The pork belly was flavorful, but it didn't melt in my mouth.  The tumeric curry rice was interesting.  It had a strong garlic powder taste...guess the chef got a little too heavy handed with seasoning the rice.  I actually wasn't a fan as it left a weird aftertaste in my mouth.Black Sesame Gelato - I was expecting one scoop, but out came three.  It was delicious and very creamy.  The black sesame was on point and I loved that it wasn't overly sweet.  I'm not sure where they get their black sesame gelato, but I'm assuming Bi-Rite Creamery as it's close by.   You MUST order this!Croissant Pudding - This is their take on bread pudding.  It was good.  The salted caramel ice cream and candied walnuts complimented the croissant pudding. Coconut Cream Latte ($5) - This latte would have been a winner if it wasn't so sweet.  It was creamy and smooth.  The coconut flavor was apparent and I liked that it didn't taste artificial.  There were even toasted coconut shreds sprinkled on top.  Thai Ice Tea ($4) - Very sweet!  "A" waited for the ice to melt to water it down a bit and it didn't work. lol!Knocking off a star as the waiter did not check me in when I told him I made reservations via OpenTable.  He acknowledge it when I told him, but then I receive this e-mail stating I was a "no show".  Not cool! #180. The other brunch place was extremely packed and this was another option nearby.  We got here around 10am on a Sunday and were immediately seated.  Sweeet.I got the mascarpone stuffed deep fried French toast (yelp.com/biz_photos/kitc…).  It's so bad but so good for you.  Not super sweet either.  And there was plenty to take home.  I was stuffed halfway through.  Pun intended.Don't mind coming back to this cute little place.__________My 2¢:- First timers: get the French toast.- RSVP to avoid the wait. What is a kitchen story? Is it a tale set in a kitchen? E.g., Ratatouille?Or maybe they're referring to a specific floor of a multi-level building? Specifically, the floor where food prep occur?Or maybe they're referring to the little-known culinary stylings of Joseph Story, US Supreme Court associate justice from 1811 to 1845?*I don't know. What I *do* know is that I have eaten here three (3) times, and each time the food has been exceptional. Get whatever looks good. It's all tasty.*His culinary stylings are little-known because I just made them up. Ate a delicious breakfast here this week.  The atmosphere is lovely and there were only a few people at 8:30am on a Friday.  The service was attentive, but a bit cold (like she wasn't quite awake yet or something). My friend and I had the Frisco Benedict, Millionaire's Bacon, & the Deep Fried French Toast.  All of the food was delicious, however the french toast is quite rich. I enjoyed the coffee ( it wasn't bitter which can be an issue at breakfast places like this). I would definitely return. Yes, the millionaire's bacon alone is worth the visit to this place. Brunch time can be packed, but the last time we were here, we sat outside with our frenchie and enjoyed our brunch with the rare San Francisco sunshine. Fast service, no wait on a Friday a little before 1pm. If I was gonna drop $17 on breakfast, I might as well have gone all out. Got the millionaire's bacon, deep fried french toast, eggs, high cholesterol, and probably an early heart attack induced death. I mean, I used to say Pork Store was an unhealthy breakfast but oh ho ho was I wrong. Not a fan of bacon, but millionaire's bacon is no traditional american bacon - it's sweet, savory, and gives off a texture of fatty beef jerky. Deep fried french toast was the bomb, a terrorist to my body but a delight to my mind and soul, and the mascarpone in the french toast? Sweet baby Jesus! Seriously, add some syrup on the french toast and you will literally have tasted the face of Jesus. The eggs you say? Yeah, they're eggs. They were alright, they're eggs. There was also a woman breast feeding at the table nearby, I didn't say anything, but I did try to take a discreet photo. sooo filling and so delicious =) you can make a reservation here so there was only a short wait! The service was friendly and fast! I was happy because I was running out of time before I had to head to the airport. The wait was short compared to a lot of other brunch places in San Francisco. Ordered the Belly Rancheros and had a Bloody Mary. I was in awe with the how cute the presentation was with both. The Belly Rancheros was sooo goood! Slow braised pork belly, arugula, avocado, spicy guacamole, kimchi pico de gallo, topped with a poached egg, all on top of a corn tortilla. The entree came with rainbow potatoes! I loved how this place has an Asian infusion. The flavors of everything blended so well together. Over all, I was definitely pleased. Fast and friendly service, great ambiance, and good food. Millionaire's bacon, scallop salad, and wagyu beef noodle soup were all good choices, although the bacon was a bit overpriced. The mango sticky rice dessert was really good and I usually don't like sticky rice desserts. I'd come back:) 3.5 stars. Cute place, fast service, food was good, but nothing wow. Ribeye omurice with scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry pepper, spinach, scallion. Demi glazed sauce-hubby got this. He really enjoyed it. I thought it was weird to have rice, but he really enjoyed it. I got egg whites and on the side it came with potatoes that had mushroom, and onion, topped with cheddar cheese. Came with a herbed biscuit that was pretty dry. Millionaire's bacon-really yummy. Went here for brunch for the first time and I think I'm in love. The staff and management were understanding and accommodative when I called ahead to say there was a disabled person in our party. I truly appreciate the efforts they took.Now for the food, oof is it tastey! I may have had quite a few mimosas, but the food knocked my socks off. The stuffed french toast was the best thing I think Ive ever had for brunch. And the staff made sure that your glass never got too low (bottomless mimosas!).This place is worth it, but there is a bit of a wait, but you can start drinking while you wait! Doug and I came here to celebrate our 31st anniversary. We were staying at the Parker House, a B&B around the corner. We were seated right away. Everything looked great on the menu and the staff was very attentive. During the course of our meal I mentioned that this was our anniversary dinner. At the end of the dinner we were presented with a dessert mentioned and told to order one on the house. When the dessert arrived it was served with two flutes of champagne. Needless to say it made our day the way they made us feel so special.Bob.W This is an odd place.  While it claims to serve California cuisine, I found the dinner offerings to be slightly tweaked Asian food.  The dishes were well-prepared, but it wasn't really what I was looking for.  If I want Asian food I'd rather go somewhere that serves authentic dishes.  Not hugely motivated to return.  Maybe the brunch is more compelling.Given the high turnover of restaurants at this address I'll be curious to see what comes next when Kitchen Story's 15-minutes inevitably expire. The hot cakes. You must have the hot cakes. These may be some of the best hot cakes I've had in, well, ever.Really great ambience, fast and friendly staff, reasonable pricing for the quality, and just an overall great venue. My friend was also telling me that the wait time seems shorter than other popular brunch places in San Francisco. After reading the yelp reviews raving about, well, EVERYTHING at Kitchen Story, I was eager to give this place a try. I hauled myself out of bed at the ungodly hour of 8am on a Saturday morning just so my friend and I could beat the rush. We got there around 9:45 (I'm a girl, it was 8am...an hour to get ready is amazing) and even though there was a good amount of people in the restaurant, the bar was completely open and we were seated at a table right away. There was a good mix of asian-flared food and traditional breakfast dishes on the menu. Even though everyone says to get the deep fried french toast, neither one of us was feeling very "sweet," so we each ended up ordering the Belly Rancheros. It was good, but pretty much a taco with shredded pork belly. I know, we probably didn't order the right thing. But I couldn't help feeling disappointed. We also got the millionaires bacon which was delicious. Sweet Maple does the same thing, but I enjoyed Kitchen Story's much more. It wasn't overly sweet and there was a perfect ratio of meat to fat. YUM.I will say parking around here was surprisingly easy. Even when we left at around 10:45am and there was a long line out the door there were still many spots around. I also really liked the ambiance. It has a really homey feel with bookcases all around and crown molding. It really feels like you're eating in someone's living room. Overall, I was disappointed with the food and satisfied with everything else. Nothing was bad, but nothing was great either. And in a town overridden with exceptional brunch spots, I can't say Kitchen Story will be one of my go-tos. Really trendy, fresh from the farm food. The staff was warm and welcoming and the wait isn't as bad as it seems. Parking however, is a bit tough especially on the sunny weekends.They have gluten free and vegan options! I'd been dying to try this place since my cousin told me about the millionaire's bacon and saw the reviews/pictures/etc. on yelp and IG. So my bf and I decided it was time to try this said, millionaire's bacon- and what better occasion than his birthday! We went ahead and made reservations on open table for brunch on Wednesday- we didn't technically need it, but haaay, points for open table! We walked in, and it was the cutest little restaurant ever. It looked like an actual kitchen. Super cool feel to it, and big windows to let natural lighting in. We were seated immediately, and I decided to order the mascarpone french toast with fresh berries on top, and for..I believe (an extra $5), you could make it a meal complete with millionaires bacon and 2 eggs. BF had the athenian omelet with a croissant, complete with a mimosa. Their mimosas are great. Perfect combination of champagne and orange juice. I'll definitely be coming back. TIP: ALWAYS MAKE A RESERVATION &**look for parking a block before 16th,  near the school/preschool place Stopped by this place for lunch with a friend after checking out the reviews on my Yelp App. I remember when this place used to be called Tangerine. I ordered the burger with the millionaire bacon on it and it was the bomb! Pros: Burger was very tastey medium rare way to go! The fries I was not a fan because they tasted like KFC potato wedges. not a fan. The Service here was extremely slow for a Monday (30mins long no joke). The food definitely made up for the service. I will try this place again but I am hestiant on coming over the weekend. I had the deep fried French toast and Millionaires bacon. They lived up to the raves. Delicious!! MIllionare's bacon was Amazing! rest of the food was delicious too! Service was fast and polite. Overall 3.5I had bookmarked Kitchen Story but couldn't recall why.  So read the yelp reviews for a mind jogger.   MILLIONAIRE BACON that's why.  So I knew I wanted something that included the thick sweet bacon slices.  Previously I had it at their sister Sweet Maple restaurant.  I went with the Castro millionaire bacon BLT on ciabatta with a side green salad.  Hubby got their slow cooked pull pork panini ciabatta sandwich with a side of roasted potatoes.  He thought the meat too sweet for his liking. The roasted potatoes were herb seasoned and crispy.  Yummy.My BLT was good but messy.  And the bacon wasn't as snappy as I would have liked.  A side of bacon would have been a better choice.   I ate the first 1/2 sandwich with my hands, slippery and oozing sauce. Then second 1/2 with fork and knife.   Tables are kind of tight, and we had three women on their lunch hour next to us whose voices and conversation was discomforting.  I should have asked to be moved.Parking was somewhat challenging.   We parked on 18th & Sanchez. Ribeye omurice is delightful (as other reviewers have mentioned)!  We also tried the fried French toast, which also does not disappoint.  The line is usually pretty long on the weekends, but the service is fast and efficient.  Would definitely come back again to try some of their more traditional breakfast / brunch dishes. I had the burger and it was flippin' fantastic.  And the calamari was delicious, as well.  The waiters were nice, and I dig the ambience of the place.  I didn't even particularly mind that it was cold outside and every time the door opened a draft came with it.  Man, that was a tasty burger. Excellent fluffy omelets, delicious fatty lacquered bacon, great crispy potatoes (a mix of types), rich coffee, responsive service, perfect berries....what's not to like? I did go early on Sunday, so perhaps that's the secret...get there before the crazy crowds. Came here for brunch with my girls on President's Day at 10:30am and did not have to wait for outdoor seating, indoor seating was a different story (there were already 3 parties ahead of us waiting). The place is affiliated with Blackwood so I anticipated the subtle Asian fusion style - though Blackwood is more Thai inspired and Kitchen Story has more Korean elements. Our feast consisted of the following:Franciscan Scramble: chicken mango, avocado, pimento, mushroom, celery, jack-way too much cheese, it drowned out the flavors of all the other ingredientsFrisco Benedict: chicken mango sausage, avocado, cherry pepper, meyer lemon hollandaise-delicious, the benedict equivalent of the above scramble without the cheese-couldn't actually taste the meyer lemon hint in the hollandaise, but maybe I'm just a little plugged up and off my tasting gameBelly Rancheros: slow braised Kurobuta pork belly, avocado, arugula, Kim Chi Pico De Gallo, spicy guacamole, corn tortilla-the pork belly had the perfect texture and I wish all places had their spicy guacamole-the guacamole wasn't spicy per se, but just a lot more flavorful than the typical green mush you've come to expect from guacamoleMascarpone Stuffed Deep Fried French Toast-in case you cannot tell, me and cheese are not friends so this dish didn't do it for me either since the filling has a plentiful amount of mascarponeAll the dishes came with a colorful side of potatoes and the overall quality of the food is nothing to complain about. "Would you like some coffee?" the host asks, as I'm waiting for my date to arrive. First dates are always nerve racking, and I was wondering if the coffee would make me even more jittery. I decided to drink it anyway.I barely spot my date from afar, and we grab a table.I had the Belly Rancheros. A pork belly dish with fresh avocado, multi-colored potatoes, arugula, and kimchi pico de gallo. My only complaint was that my potatoes tasted cold and salty, so I left them.Overall, the flavors went together well, and complimented each other. Which is what I would have liked to have said about my date, but there was something missing between us. Our chemistry was about as tepid as the potatoes on my plate.The service was good though, and they kept refilling my coffee. Which was good, because I was now lacking the energy to muster up any excitement. 3.5, rounding up.Went here with the old ball and chain for Valentine's Day because we're both terrible at making plans and they still had a table open a couple days before.I would describe the service as sluggish. The ambiance is lovely- there was a small jar-vase of fresh flowers on each table- but slightly patchy. My boyfriend ended up with a copy of the menu that was the same on both sides. The charming book they clipped the check to had been vandalized if you checked inside it.The food experience was totally OK. The complimentary sweet potato chips are somewhere between chewy and crunchy, which is not a great combo, but they were edible. I have a very low spice tolerance, so there are things I did not personally enjoy that people who don't have delicate baby tongues would be fine with. We got the samosas for a starter. The pastry was nice. The sauce with them was very good, but I gave up on it because of the spice issue. For dinner I got the salmon, but requested it with the sauce on the side, because: spice. I was happy with my large chunk of fish and the asparagus it came with. I did try the sauce a little but even without the spiciness, I don't think it would have added a lot.My boyfriend got the tuna salad and enjoyed it. He, by the way, is totally fine with spiciness. The salad was garnished with two long rigid noodlelike things? You do you, Kitchen Story.For dessert we got the "choco cake." It was divine. Admittedly, it's pretty difficult to make a chocolate cake with a gooey chocolate filling not good. It had the same noodle things for decoration, by the way.Overall a totally adequate restaurant, maybe a little overpriced, but I'd be willing to visit again to try more of their menu. Although probably with the sauce on the side. The food was delicious, especially that Millionaire's Bacon. Though I must admit, the service was slow considering that the restaurant wasn't all that busy. There was literally no wait to be seated, and plenty of seating area was available. It would've been five stars for the quality and taste of food, but I just was not as impressed with the service. It took quite a while to order, get the food and even get the check.The waitress was friendly but could use a little more practice and tips on hospitality/service. Decent food, but overpriced. The decoration and the presentation of the dish are very artistic! The BACON is worth eating but a little bit heavy~ Food seemed overpriced for what you get. The servers are nice but not really the fastest. The bacon was good. We came for dinner; you shouldn't. The burger was missing a kick of some sort... or a bite that would cut the meatiness. Just a slight lack in flavor. The fries were good. The chips however, were not. They were accompanied with the bacon wrapped scallop sandwich. The scallop was cooked well and the bacon was overwhelming to the scallop. This place is an ok on my list. I might have thought differently if I tried the brunch instead. Happy Happy Happy. With the exception of my empty wallet (typical for delicious food in SF!!) Kitchen Story is my new found happy place. Our hearts set on brunch in the Castro, the BF and I ventured out to Kitchen Story. The line both excited and frightened us - we were prepared for a 45 min wait - but we got called in for a table in 2 minutes - no joke. Fortuitous perhaps?Atmosphere:  As soon as we were seated I was elated by the cozy and beautiful decor. No detail left unnoticed, the place looked like a catalog picture of pottery barn and was buzzing with laughing, happy groups of fellow brunchers. We had a little two -seater, the place is tight but so aesthetically pleasing you won't notice. The service consisted of several people with a main server. Everyone was kind and efficient. Main vibe is hustle to the max.Food: HOLY S***. Hands Down Best Bacon Ever. Millionaire's Bacon is the best $6.50 you will ever spend. Just do it. I got a coffee (also perfect) and the Athenian Omelette. This came with rainbow potatoes, fruit garnish and the best freakin biscuit you'll ever devour. The basil, cheddar biscuit with sweet butter (?? i think??) was to die for. I would happily trade 2 days worth of calories for this meal. The omelette had a perfect blend of flavor with goat cheese - yesss. The rainbow potatoes are a blend of fancy potatoes and sweet potatoes - simple taste but delicious. I sound a bit too excited about this place, right? But I think my enthusiasm can be chalked up to expecting nothing and getting everything. Seriously, enjoyed every.single.piece of my meal. THAT is a rare find.  Just go. Enjoy your life for an hour and blissfully indulge in this lovely experience. Well done Kitchen Story! OMG. Fusion's finest! Lord knows I love brunch. I also love Asian Fusion. Well, hold on to your panties guys...ASIAN FUSION BRUNCH! Who reached into my fantasies and pulled out a Royal Flush of Awesome? Sweet Christ on a Cracker this place rules. It's small and crowded but hey, that's the calling card of awesome in SF. The staff is accommodating in the face of an endless line of people asking, "How long is the wait?" I was seated quickly and served in an amount of time that even I considered to be fast, and I was really hungry. ;-) GO. Get the Millionaire's Bacon. Thank me later. Delicious bacon. Deep fried french toast was a bit much. I couldn't eat after a few bites. Pancakes were excellent. Had a nice brunch here. I got a basic eggs plate, and it was tasty, and I'm hard to impress when it comes to a plain eggs-and-potatoes brunch. Millionaire's bacon was much better than what I had at Sweet Maple (which was more like beggar's bacon). Had a pleasant wait for our table, mimosas in hand. Sooooo good!! Must get the french toast and millionaires bacon. I have never had anything so good in my entire life. The only thing negative that I have to say, is that we had to wait an hour before we got seated for breakfast. But in my opinion it was well worth it. We came here for dinner last Friday and we were impressed!The ambiance is low key but the food was very good. We ordered the spicy Waygu roll, the ahi tun, the steak with ginger rice, and a noodle soup. Everything was very delicious and unique!The prices were fairly reasonable. I would come back again! Everything - and I mean everything - about this place is suberb. Deep fried marscapone French toast, delicate green tea, beautiful decor, inviting service. I'm not a going out for breakfast person but Kitchen Story changed me. Forever. Is it possible that I haven't rated this place yet?  I've been here many times, for weekend brunch mostly, but once for breakfast and once for dinner, and I love the food.  There is almost always a really super long wait for brunch (think an hour), and parking is horrendous.  But service is friendly and the food options are interesting.  They call it Californian, but there's a definite Asian influence.  For brunch, I love their bulgogi burger and their crab panini.  Large portions and oh so tasty.  Friends have loved their millionaire's bacon, ribeye omurice and mascarpone stuffed French toast (if you don't get this, you will salivate when you see it being served elsewhere).  For dinner, I've had POP Belly (pork belly with yellow curry rice and brussel sprouts), Finger Lickin' (fried chicken breast with curry dipping sauce and russet wedges) and short rib beef tacos with kimchi pico de gallo, spicy guacamole.  For dessert we had a croissant bread pudding with salted caramel Bi-Rite ice cream, and mango sticky rice.  Everything was DELICIOUS.  One of my favorites despite the parking situation. Incredibly rich, delicious breakfast food, highlighted by the Millionaire's Bacon. The flapjacks are equally good and -- I can't stress this enough -- rich. Seriously, if you're looking for lighter fair, or healthy, you might want to look elsewhere. But if you want indulgent breakfast food in a vibrant restaurant with good service, this is the place! This is one of my favorite brunch spots in San Francisco. I love all their eggs benedict dishes and their millionaire's bacon. The biscuit with pork wine gravy is seriously to DIE for. I can't get enough of it. Whenever I have family or friends stopping by, I plan on taking them here.The wait is usually not so bad if you get here early enough. You can come around 10AM and there usually isnt a wait. The only time I did have to wait, it was only for 10 minutes and they served us coffee/tea outside without any charge. This place is amazing! I don't know what to say about this restaurant. I came here with my boyfriend for dinner and was a little bit disappoint with the food. I thought the food will be amazing since the Kitchen Story is related to Sweet Maple, so I had high expectation on Kitchen Story. Maybe I'll try there breakfast/ lunch for a different perspective (hope it will taste better). Came here for my friend's bday dinner and was pleasantly surprised...all the food was so flavorful & good!  I think of this place as a fusion thai restaurant.  We had a preset menu for a large group party.  Right off the bat, the ahi poke salad was very fresh and good!  I immediately fell in love with the millionaire bacon- sweet & salty all in one bite!  And the POP belly - pork belly with curry rice was absolute heaven in every bite!  I couldn't get enough of this dish!  I highly recommend this place if you're looking for amazing food in the city! Delicious, clean and friendlyI came here at 8am with a friend to have brunch (apparently you have to get to these places early to avoid a long wait). I ordered the Franciscan Scramble which comes with rainbow potatoes and a biscuit, which was really delicious. I could have done with less cheese but the avocado and veggies inside the omelette were very delicious! The rainbow potatoes were perfectly roasted (delicious but not overly greasy so it retains its crunch and toasty goodness). I had a bite of the Millionnaire's bacon, which is the most unique bacon I've had! It's a bit pricey for two slices of bacon ($6.50) but if you are a bacon fan, I would recommend it. Overall, I thought the place was really clean and nicely decorated. Service was fine! CasualFriendlyAsianModernCleanDelicious I absolutely love this place. My friends and I are frequent guests and their food is absolutely amazing. But the reason I give this place two stars is because of their service. Almost every time I have been there, the staff has been incredibly rude. The first time we went, the host snapped at me for asking how long the wait would be for a party of 6. Then, one of our friends' plates was not brought out and the waiter said to us that he didn't order anything. We told her politely what he had ordered and she rolled her eyes. No apologies or anything.I went there today with my family and I went up to the host (same person as before) asking to put our name in. As I'm writing our name down, he starts opening the door over my foot and says "you need to move!" There were customers on all sides of me and I was shocked by how short he was about it and that he was forcing me to bump into other customers. We finally got seated and ordered our food, and my sister forgot to order a coffee. We saw our waiter and we tried to get his attention. He looked right at us, and then promptly walked the other way. We then asked the next person who came up to our table to refill our waters and he said "I don't take orders. You have to ask your waiter for that"Honestly, if it wasn't that their food was so great, I would not return. I'm not asking for a whole song and dance, just some politeness from the staff. Decent food, but service not quite up to par with the prices. Came here for dinner.First off, more than half of the dishes on the menu has a deep-fried component. Good if you're craving that kind of stuff, but since I wasn't, I ordered the scallop/beet salad. For $11, it came with exactly two scallops. The underlying beets/greens were nothing special and not particularly tasty. They could have roasted the beets to bring out more flavor.For a main, I settled on the Pad Kee Mow, which was perfectly suitable, similar to what you can get at any Thai restaurant around town. I also tried a bit of the burger, which was quite tasty, as were the accompanying fries. But nearly 20 bucks for a burger is just too much!It was a little hard to summon a waiter to order drinks. Also, water was spilled on one of our party by a clumsy waiter trying to clear plates, who also was dropped a dish as well (fortunately this was not at our table). This is the kind of service I might expect at a divey place in Chinatown, but not at a $20 burger place. Fast, Delicious & DifferentTip: Go around 2pm. It was so noisy and packed but we happened to go towards the end of their open hours and got a seat right away.Ordered the breakfast sandwich with a side of "Millionaire's Bacon". Delicious and fatty. Not good for a diet conscience person, but a fun place in a nice neighborhood. Bottomless Mimosas. Ricotta Pancakes. Millionaire's bacon. Pure glutton but oh so worth it. Great brunch spot to start off before hitting the Sunday Funday trail. The waits can be long but the staff is great and the prices are reasonable. 1st time having brunch here. Customer service was great. Food very beautiful and tasteful. Place is very nice. There's inside & outside sitting. Great service and great food, what more can u ask for. I will be back!!! Perfect spot for a quick dinner. Good prices and friendly staff. We had the yellow curry and ahi salad and both were very good. What a perfect little brunch spot. Not exactly sure what their niche is, but they make lovely brunch! One word of advice though - don't order the oatmeal, it is dreadful. My own fault for trying to be healthy and get some fiber and oaty goodness. The oatmeal is watery and flavorless and completely regrettable. They did bring me brown sugar and milk which did nothing to salvage the flavor. But luckily, I had more than enough other delicious plates to make up for this folly!The millionaire's bacon should be renamed Bacon King Supreme Being of All Bacon Entities. That's how amazing it is. I don't even like bacon. So this speaks volumes. It's sweet, crisp, THICK, and almost unbearably scrumptious.Mascarpone stuffed french toast is FRIED and tastes like a donut french toast. Take that, cronuts! This is cronut extreme! It has mascarpone! Ain't nothing beating this breakfast now. The mascarpone tastes like a rich pillow of heaven in your mouth. I can't get over how indulgent this french toast is, I've never eaten anything so fluffy and fatty and goooood.I got a cheddar biscuit with gravy and the cheddar biscuit was so fat it looked like they gave me two by accident. I'll take it. It was super flaky, buttery, but with tons of flavor and herbs. The gravy on the side was so thick it was almost like its own dish - almost like a soup/stew, really. It was so savory and creamy and wonderful I almost wished I'd ordered gravy with a side of biscuit instead of the other way around.My friends and I got the thai tea latte, green tea latte, and dirty chai. I'm biased, but I think the green tea latte was the best, but you couldn't go wrong with any of them. Best part? Parking took me about 5 minutes on a Sunday morning around 11 and there was NO WAIT for 3 people. Shocker people, there is good brunch to be had in SF without a bleary-eyed wake-up call at 7 am. Easy 5 star review. Checked it out because of the great reviews, love the twist on traditional brunch dishes. They are also super efficient, jam packed place w only 20 min wait. Delicious millionaires bacon and ribeye omlet. Will def go back! I've been here about 3 times now and each time I've been here it's been awesome. Two of those times was for the Bottomless Mimosas. It's $16 per person and it's a pretty good tasting mimosa. The first time we got our own glass pitcher to pour for ourselves but the second time they came by and poured it for us. Not sure what the rules are for Bottomless since everyone of us got it each time. Lunch ends around 3PM and that's when everyone starts clearing out.The food is okay. The Millionaire's Bacon reminds me of Filipino Tosino. It's just bacon that's a little sweet. I think it's worth trying at least one time but I wouldn't pay extra for it to get it on the side.Overall, this is a great place to get good tasting Bottomless Mimosas. The food is just okay but don't think I would be coming here unless it's with some bubbly. Pros:-Great tasting bottomless mimosasCons:-Super busy and a long wait Came and tried the Pad See You with Roast Pork. Delicious! Beautifully garnished and a great portion size. Vegetables were crisp and the pork juicy. Highly recommend this dish. The Francisco Benedict was amazing!Great service and great food! I will definitely come back next time I am in San Francisco! Came here for my birthday brunch in the summer. Think we waited about 20-25 min for a table and were seated outside (it was sunny, yay!). Was heavily contemplating between the omuraisu or an omelet and opted for an omelet with rainbow potatoes. Those potatoes are to die for. The omelet was alright, nothing special. It came with a mini croissant which was kind of burnt, but very buttery. I tried my friend's omuraisu and it was interesting. Had a spicey kick to it. Another friend ordered some melt and it was really good! Will be ordering this next time I come back.Service was accommodating. We wanted to switch to a larger table and they allowed us to do so promptly. Great food, service & experience. Highly recommended for brunch! As other reviewers have mentioned, the millionaires bacon is amazing. Also really love the tilapia burger. Mmm yum... Will be returning when in SF. 1st time at Kitchen Story yesterday. The place was packed but you get seated easily if there's 2. If you have a group of 6 like we did, we had to have everyone there to be seated.All the staff were friendly. They were so patient with us. Everyone was very happy with their brunch choices. I was very surprised how yummy my scrambled eggs was. It was light and fluffy! Awesome texture! I was most pleased with the home fries or the rainbow potatoes. I was expecting they were gonna be lukewarm from being under a heat lamp but it wasn't! It was hot, crunchy and fresh!The bottomless mimosas looked like it was more OJ than champagne but it was still potent! Millionaire's bacon lived up to the hype! It was delish. Folks complain how pricey it is. It takes awhile to prep & cook those as I was told by the staff. Love this place!!! Had dinner here, and it definitely surpassed expectation.   Started with an app of the Millionaire Bacon, served 2 slices with 2 spears of Asparagus $12 (a little pricey for two pieces of bacon, but damn son, that's some bacon).  Thai Iced Teas ordered around and then I had the fried chicken served with curry dipping sauce and my buddy had the burger... we split what we had and WOW, the burger there may be my new favorite food in San Francisco.   The chicken was good too, loved the red curry dipping sauce, had to debate whether or not I was going to stay classy and not drink it straight after the meal was over... I didn't... but I wanted to.   I'll be back, next time with a soup spoon. Came here off a friend's recommendation. Everything was good but the millionaire's bacon is what's going to bring me back. Holy cow. Who would think a fat slab of bacon soaked in syrup would be delicious? Just kidding, that sounds inherently awesome. BUT! I would never have imagined it would be as delicious as it was. If you come here and don't get the millionaire's bacon, then you are a fool who just missed out on a golden opportunity. I really like the food at kitchen story and my order (Ribeye omurice) was great and tasty. But the restaurant was very noisy. This place is owned by the same family that owns Sweet maple and Blackwood restaurants,  and the menu is pretty much the same as Sweet Maple. Food quality and variation gets 4 stars but not the environment. The restaurant is very noisy and tables are close to each other. I understand that the management cannot regulate the noise level but I'm not a fan of having to finish my food fast in order to get out as fast as possible. If you don't mind the noise you can enjoy tasty dishes here. Unfortunately I left with a bad headache. I don't go out to eat as much in San Francisco but if I could, I'll be sure to try out new spots. The "millionaire bacon" was something new to try for those bacon lovers out there. This is a small place and has plenty of parking around the restaurant. I ordered the Ks omelette which was really satisfying because I avoid trying go to eat oily and greasy food and their plate that consist of my omelette, potatoes, and buttered crossaint was really perfectly made. Went for dinner and ordered the burger. Delicious, cooked perfectly. Millionaire bacon on burger was mouthwatering. Burger had a sweet taste to it. Best burger I've had in San Fran so far. My friend had the sandwich with bacon wrapped scallops and it was equally delicious. mediocre food at best, and horrendous service. ..AND a fly flew in my mimosa. When i pointed it out to the server, he had the nerve to glare at me rather than apologize. In short - considering how many great places there are in SF, save yourself the trouble and skip out on this dump. It's not worth your time or  your money. Kitchen story is my go-to place for larger group dinners (just like Jasmine M. said). they're very accommodating about adding people on reservations last minute too!i think the service is nice, but the standout is definitely the interior decor. it reminds me of someone's house/lodge/cabin in the woods, books on the shelves, dark lighting, benches with pillows...my recommendations: Ahi scoops were nice, salmon is pretty good, millionaire's bacon, shrimp currythe reason i don't give this 4 or 5 stars is because i never go around in life 'craving' kitchen story food. it's just good, but not incredible mouth-watering dying. (note: ooh, the brunch pics look good though! maybe i'll come here for brunch one day and add a star!) I've been to Kitchen Story a couple times now and am really impressed with the way they handle large groups for dinner. It's scary easy to make a reservation for a group of 6+... even on NYE. The staff here is super friendly and happy to answer any questions about the menu. Vegetarians: I would recommend a couple of small plates here. They don't really have many veggie entree options, except for the tofu curry which I haven't tried. The Sweet Caroline is totally delicious, as are the potato Samosas. I love the side dish of string beans here- perfectly cooked and sort of spicy. My non-veg friends rave about the Salmon, Ahi scoops, and Shrimp Curry.They don't really allow you to split the bill on multiple cards for large groups, which is a bummer. But, they bring out the bill clipped to an old book- cute touch! Two words: Millionaire's Bacon, One Feeling = HeavenlyKitchen Story is an adorable and cozy restaurant located in San Francisco's Castro neighborhood. I was introduced to this restaurant by a good friend of mine and I have been thankful ever since. To be honest, I have never been more in love with bacon after having my first bite of the Millionaire's bacon. This bacon is absolutely amazing as it is 5x thicker than normal bacon. I fell in love with every delicious piece that entered my mouth. Should you feel a need to order something else besides the delicious Millionaire's bacon, I recommend the following brunch dishes:- Ribeye omurice (scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry pepper, spinach, scallion) - Mascarpone stuffed deep fried French toastFun Fact: You will fall in love with the Millionaire's Bacon. came here for brunch on new years day with a group of 4 because everybody else had ridiculous wait times.  we waited 30 minutes here.  very busy.  decent service.i wanted to try the bacon, but they didn't get my order right.  they gave me the wrong burger and the wrong side.  oh well.  it happens.  the CA burger wasn't that good.  the burger was very thick but pretty mushy.  it didn't have a grilled taste.  avocados made the consistency even mushier.  overall, it could have used more flavoring.  potato wedges were average. I love this local spot. Fresh squeezed orange juice and carrot are very good. The freshly made cheddar and chive biscuits are my weakness. This is probably the best breakfast I've ever had. I had the Athenian omelette and it was amazing!! The goat cheese was such a great touch to already amazing flavors. The potatoes were a great mix of sweet and russet. You'd be a FOOL to miss out on the MILLENNIUM BACON!!! Watch out for those pollenating flowers on the bar tho. That food is TOO sugary.Like everything was covered in caramel sauce. sweet meats, sweet rice, sweet vegetables. their plum sauce was pure tooth decay.my kids got the pork tacos and couldn't eat them, they said they were like boiled meat covered in melted icecream. If you're like us and prefer savory dinners, this place is a diabetic's nightmare. Great service even though we didn't order drinks. Reasonably priced, and the check comes on a paper back book. Great brunch! Bottomless mimosas and delicious brunch food! We had a slight problem with the eggs benedict, eggs were still uncooked on one side but we sent it back with no fuss and they served a new one within 2/3 minutes. Service was already good with everyone jumping in to help but the nice way they handled our food send back (especially cause we hate doing that) made everything even better.. Cannot wait to come back Kitchen Story! Whoops, I did it again. That is, moved to a new city and decided what my favorite restaurant was within 24 hours or so. Seems to be a pattern with me. If only my taste in men were nearly as definitive and accurate.My friend and I were looking for a place to go for NYE, and didn't want to go to a place with a two-hour-wait, nor did we want to hit Taco Bell. We looked on OpenTable and saw we could get in here in an hour... booked it... then went online and saw four-stars on Yelp. Promising. Highly promising.We arrived and went with the highly-reviewed items. The Millionaire's Way (Millionaire's Bacon, grilled organic asparagus and homemade smoky Maple syrup sauce)... POP & Iing (Slow braised Kurobuta pork belly, arugula, spicy ginger sauce)... and for entrees the Finger Lickin' (Chicken) (Fried organic chicken breasts, extra crispy russet wedges, coconut Yellow curry dipping sauce, cucumber salad) and the Dancing Queen (Grilled Snake River Farm Wagyu Beef Flank Steak, spicy garlic Thai long bean, roasted rice sauce, 151 rum,ginger rice).The Millionaire's bacon was the best bacon I've had. Period. The POP & Iing is the second-best pork belly I've had, but if you knew what it was like at Animal in Los Angeles, you'd realize what a compliment that is. It would be like dating my ex and being told that you're the second best in bed. Take it as a compliment. The Chicken in curry sauce wasn't Earth-shatteringly good like the appetizers, but it was delicious nontheless, perhaps in my top ten chicken dishes ever. The Dancing Queen ordered the steak ironically also called the Dancing Queen... and loved it, as did I.As we left we saw signs for the Pajama Brunch the next morning. New Years came and went, we awoke... and... what the hell.We go back and have two eggs with millionaire's bacon, the chicken mango sausage, the Ribeye omurice (scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherrypepper, spinach, scallion. Demi glazed sauce) and the Okonomiyaki (modernyaki) egg pancake (w/ cabbage, scallion, asparagus, carrots, mushroom, red onion). Bottomless mimosas in BIG glasses. Again, everything was amazing, and since it was brunch, totally different than the night before. Though we got the same table and cuter-than-a-Coppertone-baby waiter, Max.Blah blah blah, January 1st passes. An old friend from Oakland hits me up, wants to see my new place. Parks. Looks. We decided to go eat. He says "OMG you're a few blocks from one of my favorite places... let's go there!"You've gotta be kidding me.For the third time in 24 hours, I walk in. Max eyes me suspiciously. Can't blame him. By now it must seem like I'm staking out the place. I needed to get something different this time. I mean, for the love of God. So I went with the Thai menu. Totally different, right? Started with the Crispy Calamari (Red curry battered Monterrey squid with spicy pepper, garlic aioli and homemade pickle) and it was perfect. Then had the Pad Kee Mow (Spicy flat rice noodle, bamboo shoots, bell pepper and basil). I ordered it 7.5/10 spicy, and I swear it was exactly right. Nice kick, not overdone. Just as good as Thai food at a "real" Thai restaurant (meaning solely Thai food). My second friend had the POP Belly (Overnight slow cook Kurobuta pork belly with five spices, yellow curry rice, Brussels sprouts with fermented beans sauce , Spicy ginger sauce), which was a different format of the POP & Iing, and every bit as delicious.I left, vowing that after three meals in a row, I'd not return for at least two weeks. I don't think I'll pull it off. My friend Vanda introduced my friends and I to this place and it was awesome!  I had the french toast with the millionaire bacon, some of my friends had the eggs benedict and a few other dishes (there were 8 of us). All of us cleared our plates and had some sides. Bottomless Mimosas were the choice drink for some of us, I had the bloody mary!  The bloody mary was so good and wanted to order another! I am for sure coming back here.  My suggestion is come earlier than you expect to eat. There were a lot of people waiting and I heard it's usually like this. We waited about 30 minutes. It was worth it.  The staff were nice and service was good.  The crowd of people there were pleasant, a few probably could've pulled their heads out of their *sses... but overall a great environment during brunch.  If you sit close to the door gets a little cold tho.
