Which I forgot about when my food came... :) go go go! I love this place! Great atmosphere and every breakfast dish I've tried is amazing. The marzipan French toast is perfect, rainbow potatoes and a housemade biscuit are tasty sides, and the millionaire bacon is a delicious treat. The service is always helpful but not intrusive, the atmosphere is energetic and pleasant. This place always brings out the best in me.A great way to set the tone for the day. My dish (KC's omelette) was so beautiful to look at. It also comes with a very fluffy egg and interesting spices (lemongrass in it!). I don't care about the biscuit, it needs to be more buttery I think.I ordered the millionaire's bacon just like everyone. It's a really good bacon candy.Space is cramped. Too cramped! They leave a ton of room in the middle of the restaurant and leave no space between tables. Hence -1 star.Parking was difficult, but we got lucky.Go early! With the ever increasing number of restaurants to try in San Francisco, Kitchen Story is one of the few I consistently go back to, and I am never disappointed.  It's no cheap place, coming to an average $30-50 per person for a plate, drinks, tax, and tip, but everything I've had here is delicious and satisfying, definitely worth the cost.If you come after 11am or before 2pm for weekend brunch, be prepared for a wait up to an hour/hour-and-a-half, if the weather is nice.  (Still worth it.) Meet up with some friends here for a post T-day brunch. Overall, was good.  Had the two eggs, biscuit and potatos.  The biscuit was amazing, esp with the maple butter.   May venture to the some of the other items on my next trip out. I try to get breakfast here at least once on every trip I make to San Francisco. Seriously, its that good.My favorite menu item is the Frisco Benedict, which is a scrumptious benedict with chicken mango sausage, avocado, cherry peppers and hollandaise. Friends of mine have tried to take me to other brunch places in SF that they swear by, but I always return to Kitchen Story because it never disappoints. Tell me a story...Well, this is one for Kitchen Story.Chapter 1 - R i s e  &  B r u n c hIt was one of those lazy, morning Sundays, that I pestered my friend to go here for brunch and we both stayed up quite late (3:30am), the night before - a Saturday night.  We beat the crowd and arrived here at 10am.  We basically got about 5 hours of restless sleep.  I was worried, whether it was worth it on grabbing brunch.  It was!Chapter 2 - T i n g l i n g  T h e  P a l a t e From considerate thinking, my friend suggested to be seated at the open bar for the full experience of the kitchen cooking and prepping dining experience rather than the table seatings on the side.  Being the friend, who doesn't like to be bothered in the mornings, he was actually right on that part.  The observation of food entrees that was coming out from the kitchen, was marvelous.  You got to see how they handled the food and what looks delicious to order up!  It was a tease to the palate.  The service was commendable as well - servers reassured us that our entrees will be coming out very shortly, refilled our waters and asked if we needed anything else in the meantime.  They have bottomless mimosas for $16, but I saved my hungry stomach for their sizable brunch plates.Chapter 3 - N o m  N o m  N o mLet's get it started with the Millionaire's Bacon - Served right out of the kitchen, it was still piping hot.   Drizzled with maple syrup and in its own savory, bacon flavor, their bacon was thick, rich and grand!  It suits its name!  Each bite was sensational and a must order item!Frisco Benedict - You can't go wrong with Egg Benedicts!  Their hollandaise sauce and poached eggs were on point.  Their chicken mango sausage, needed more of a flavorful finishing touch.  I like the atypical bread that they substituted with, compared to the usual English muffin.  It gave it a different texture.  In addition, they had different types of potatoes that was served up on the side - taro, yam and the regular white.  They named it rainbow potatoes, which made it all the more creative.Last, but not least of my food entree adventures, was the Ribeye Omurice - I've never seen an Omelette made SO FLUFFY!  Well done!  The glazed sauce Omelette was topped over tossed up marinated ribeye, spinach, scallion mixed rice.  Their biscuit that was topped with a spoonful of generous butter, made this a bit country-styled.  With rainbow potatoes on the side, it was a grand, homely, tasty, unique dish.All in all, when the bill came with a book as a tab cover, I was more than happy to pay for this one - especially when my friend was still tuned out and grumpy from being woken up in the morning!  With their fun delightful, brunch entrees, friendly and attentive service and homely decor, I just needed to tell a Kitchen Story.  It is never The End, but to be continued about more on their other entrees here!Until next time... AH! My new favorite brunch spot in Castro, yes, its you.Despite walking up right smack in the middle of brunch, we were seated fairly quickly. After a glance at the menu I decided on Red and Green Benedict: Spinach, mushroom, roasted tomatoes and mango salsa on levain toast and yes -- it does taste as good as it sounds. Pair that with bottomless mimosas, good company, great conversation and you've got a perfect brunch. Oh and the awesome service to boot.Besides the great decor / vibe of this place, I loved that they give your check in old books. It was a cute little touch and I couldn't help but read a paragraph from the random page they placed it in. I can see how this place could pose a frustration if you have a big party -- luckily it was just us two -- but that wouldn't stop me from dragging the gang here in the future. I don't write a lot of Yelp Reviews - but when I do (sound like a commercial you've seen?) - its because I had an EXCEPTIONAL experience. I ordered the two eggs w/bacon breakfast and it came with what I can only describe as the BEST mushroom gravy sauce & cheddar biscuits I've ever had! I had 1 hotcake on the side and it was soooo light and fluffy and not doughy like many hotcakes I've had in the past. Overall a great experience from food thru service and ambiance. Highly recommend this spot :)! Kitchen Story takes the cake for my favorite brunch place in the city, for practical and subjective reasons: their food is tasty, to be sure, but they're also one of the only good brunch places in SF that have less than a 15 minute during normal brunch hours. Having been here twice now, I've tried the:* Millionaire's Bacon - This is a must, if you're any sort of fan of candied bacon: thick cut, somewhat smoky strips of sweet and savory candied bacon, that go wonderfully with their starchy dishes (see below).* Ribeye Omurice - Fluffy egg omelet over a bed of slightly spicy fried wild rice, rather than the usual rice-in-omelet setup. Tasty, and comes with a biscuit that goes great with their bacon.* Ricotta Hot Cakes - I'd heard of hot cakes before, but had never had occasion to actually try it before. Like pancakes, but less dense, and with a hint of sour cream or something otherwise tart. Not bad on their own, but great when had in conjunction with the bacon.In short, come eat here. Your stomach will thank you for not making it wait. (Just, don't, you know, all of you come, and turn this into all the other brunch joints in SF!)***Accessibility Info***Venue - Plenty of space inside the venue, so seating and maneuvering isn't much of an issue.Bathroom - Didn't try, so no comment. After seeing so many check ins at this place by my friends, I finally made plans with the BF and a good buddy to have brunch here. Located off 16th and Castro, Kitchen Story is just down the street from Market and falls on a corner so you can't miss it.Apparently they serve Asian fusion faire, so I was curious to say the least. We didn't have reservations so we had to put our names down, but like any cool place they let you drink on the sidewalk. Bloody Mary (with sake or soju, as it's beer/wine licensed only), check.We were able to sit down at the bar area and order. Everyone was raving about the Millionaire's Bacon, but unfortch for us, they were out! I ended up ordering the steak omerice (omelet rice) that came with rainbow potatoes. (So that settles it -- Kitchen Story is an amalgamation of Korean, Thai, and "other Asian" cuisine with some American classics.) The BF ordered a sausage eggs benedict and my friend opted for an omelet. The food came out relatively fast and was flavorful, IMO. I had the best dish out of the bunch, so I can't speak for my party. The energy was buzzing and I'd love to come back for their dinner, but would definitely make a reservation this time. I had heard such great things about Kitchen Story from my friend but sadly we both just thought it was kinda okay. I had the ricotta pancakes which were decent and my friend had a scramble with a biscuit on the side. I love a good biscuit but this one was really lacking the layers of buttery goodness. It was on the drier side and even dipping it in the gravy didn't really save it. The millionaire bacon however....saved the meal...it was beyond delicious!I'd like to mention that the service is really great as is the atmosphere so perhaps we just came on a off day. Long wait, ended up sitting outside in 40F weather, and the service was just OK.  That said the food was really solid.  Millionaire's bacon is maybe over-rated, but the biscuit and gravy were awesome. oh yeah!  This place is legit. we got here at 10am on a sunday and we were able to sit right down.  30 minutes later and there would have been a LONG wait.  the staff is on point...attentive, fast and thorough.  very well trained.the drinks came out super fast and the food followed after about 10 minutes. it was crazy fast. we quickly dived in and were super pumped we chose this spot.  we will definitely be back and i highly recommend the frisco benedict.  BAM! The Millionaire Bacon is everything you need in your life and then some. Point. Blank. End of story. Stumbled upon this place last week for lunch and loved it. As soon as I sat down at the table, one of the waiters brought me a glass of water and a pitcher for my table (yes!). The veggie burger was delicious. The staff was very friendly. Nice neighborhood spot. review of dinnerfound this thanks to yelp!we orderedfried chicken - children's plate - yummy! came with rice. (would have preferred some veggies to help children be healthy)Salmon with curry sauce. husband loved the curry sauceside of roti - who doesn't love roti.? it was instantly devoured. seemed like croissant - buttery.bok choy with garlic - LOVED it. had lemon which gave it tang that made it impossible to stop devouring. love it when a restaurant makes me eat veggies! braised meat with asian spices - reminds me of Taiwanese meat with spices. brought back good memories. not so healthy, but oh so yummyGREAT bathroom in that there were lots of hangers and I had my coat, purse. and 2 kids!!they should get a velvet curtain near the entrance to block the cold though... delicious food, good price, attentive staff.  Not skimpy size dishes.  Would definitely come here again and I certainly recommend it!  You can be causal there obv because it's SF, but the ambiance is just nice enough that it could be a good date place. I came here after church service and we had already put our name down before we went into church so we only waited about 10 minutes to get seated.The millionaire's bacon is what I HAD to try and it was really good for the first few bites.......then it got cloyingly sweet and didn't have any spice to even out the flavor profile. I poured some Tabasco on it and made it taste better. Overall, I thought everything was on the sweet side and I have a more savory palette. It was not a horrible experience here but I don't know when I would come back. Guys...at Kitchen Story they give you fried chicken...and then CURRY to dip it in!  This is amazing!  I've officially added curry to my list of Condiments for All Occasions.I wanted to try out a new restaurant on a weekday night and made a reservation for Kitchen Story.  We wandered over and were seated immediately.  I ordered the raspberry lemonade, which was tasty but pretty small (a mason jar filled with ice) (also, can we talk about how sick of mason jars I am?  I can't drink out of these things).My fiance and I shared the samosa appetizer, which was really good - all about the cilantro dipping sauce (I guess dipping sauces are the theme of this review).  I got the aforementioned fried chicken with yellow curry dipping sauce, named "Finger-lickin'" on the menu.  My apologies, but I definitely ate it with a fork!  The Finger-lickin was super super delicious, and my dinner mate looked on it with jealousy.  He had ordered the burger, which he would have been satisfied with had he not learned about the magic of dipping things in curry.The entree portions were fairly hefty, and I was stuffed - sadly, no room for dessert.  The check comes out between the pages of a paperback, which was a cute and creative touch.  I can't wait to come back - maybe brave the wait for brunch some weekend? Visited with a dear friend a couple weeks back, and enjoyed the ambiance, food (presentation was great) and service was superb; definitely coming back, and love this new found gem. My new favorite brunch spot in the city! Kitchen Story is everything you could hope for on a lazy Saturday morning. Great food, a quaint and charming atmosphere, friendly service, and delicious details that make this place very special. I came here specifically for the Millionaires Bacon, but was impressed by so much more. What is Millionaire's Bacon you ask? It's thick-cut bacon that's slow roasted in the oven for 4 hours with maple syrup and special spices. YES - sooo delicious and completely worth the couple extra bucks.I ordered the Deep Fried French Toast, stuffed with mascarpone cheese and topped with boysenberries and strawberries. Super decadent and filling. I had to take half of it home! If you don't want sweetness overload, I highly recommend going with the complete breakfast option where you can add eggs + bacon. And be sure to upgrade to Millionaires! You will NOT regret it. I washed my meal down with fresh raspberry lemonade, which comes in an adorable mason jar and is topped with a sprig of mint and a lemon wedge. It was quite perfect. I'm not exactly sure why this place is called "Kitchen Story." I feel like there's some deeper meaning behind that, but it seemed to all make sense when they brought us our check that was appropriately clothes-pinned to a paperback novel. It's a nice touch. They also have a few cookbooks perched around the restaurant, which adds to the homey feel. Even though it seems to get busy here, I was able to snag seats at the bar with no wait at 11:30am on a Saturday, and by noon, there were open tables available. The bar seating and fast turnout of the food makes this place feel half way between a diner and a restaurant. It's nice and bright inside and a perfect place for a date with your hubby, a catch-up session with a friend, or a nice meal with your family. Definitely coming back! And not just for the bacon! Was not worth the insane wait.  We were seated at the bar for reasons inexplicable - we were three and they wanted to give a table to a group of four who put their name down after us.  Just strange, and indicative of an extremely faulty system.  It's a wonder they have so many customers brave their brunch.Sitting at the bar put me off coming here ever again, especially because the plating station was visible, and their practices were iffy at best.  The person doing the plating used the same rag to clean/dab bacon as she did plates of vegetarian food, spreading the bacon grease far and wide. Our water glasses had thick rings from shoddy dishwashing, and the water smelled of fish.  And having eaten at Sweet maple and Blackwood - the menu here was nothing to write home about.  Left feeling a bit disgusted and overall unimpressed. best bacon ever.  everything is good.  no complains Decided to come in last minute about two weeks ago.Parking was painful and the wait was manageable.  Staff was friendly and service was overall a-okay.  Saturday morning brunch is busy as can be expected so it is what it is.  We had the french toast, the pancakes, the chicken and was it the prime rib omelet?  Something steak omelet.  Everything was satisfactory although the french toast seemed more like a dessert rather than a breakfast meal.  too sweet and seriously deep fried.would likely come back to try other things...  Make reservations though! I love trying new places when I visit SF and Kitchen Story was a hit! I ordered a omelet and my friend got the French toast!! Both extremely delicious!! And of course we both had to get the millionaires bacon!! Cute place, long wait. Came here with a group of 4 for Sunday brunch and waited 50 minutes. We tried a whole bunch of food, the millionaire's bacon, different types of scrambles, ribeye omurice, and the mascarpone stuffed deep fried french toast with fresh berries. The definite winners were the french toast and the omurice. I usually love eggs and the scrambles were fluffy but too much cheese that congealed in a thick layer on top of the eggs. French toast was amazing, glad that we got one for the table to share because I don't think I can finish all that sweetness by myself. The variety of potatoes on the side was a nice cute touch. Would come back to try dinner or for brunch again if we could beat the crowd. We were recommended here by our dear friends and I will say it was ok, nothing to rave about. We ordered the millionaire bacon & that was probably the best thing we ordered. We also got some crab cakes that we nothing special but the salsa served on it was good. My husband ordered the finger licking chicken & it was pretty good, I ordered the pork chop and wished I had of ordered anything else because it was gross to me. Our whole meal was really expensive for the amount of food we got ( 12 dollars for TWO strips of bacon) but the service was excellent. I'd return if a friend wanted to go but I wouldn't request it on my own. Amazing food! I had the Big Boy sandwich (I think that's what it was called...), which had scallops wrapped in their amazing Millionaire's Bacon. Looking forward to my next visit!Update - 01/07/2013:I got a pretty severe case of food poisoning from my visit two days ago. Spent all of yesterday in the ER. I don't pin food poisoning on any restaurant unless I'm sure -- the people who dined with me that night also had symptoms, but not to my extent.I got the spicy tiger prawn soup. I won't be returning here. My first visit, as from my initial review, still stands as a good meal in my memory, but I'm concerned about cleanliness. I was really surprised that the food was so great! although, it could be a bit cheaper. it seems as if fusion always adds another $3 per entrée. (also, it was a bit off putting to get sparkling water served out of a plastic bottle. im all for down home style...but at a down home pricetag. okerrr.)service was superb. waiter was super cute. and our city supervisor was dining at the table down from us! what a special treat! I hear its amazing for brunch too. definitely get the tuna ceviche with avocado and the fried chicken. the bacon is overrated but still quite delish. finally, the portions are generous. a shared app and a shared entrée will do the trick (and save on the bill!) This place has won the title in my little foodie heart as best brunch in the city! It's a really magical place - despite its growing popularity, I've never had to wait more than 5 minutes to be seated, and these were during peak hours too. Crazy! And everyone is so friendly and inviting and warm. It's amazing.Millionaire's bacon. Hell. Yes. I'm not the biggest fan of bacon normally (I know I know, terrible, but meat shouldn't be so crunchy??) but this stuff is thick cut marinated perfection, beautifully glazed meaty glory. It reminds me of Chinese style pork jerky - the sweet and savory combination kills me. Cue drooling everywhere.All of the food is presented so beautifully here, with colorful garnishes and motifs. Brunch food is not always the most attractive, but they really go out of their way here to make everything very visually appealing. It's that extra consideration and attention to detail for every dish that really makes Kitchen Story special. I sat at the counter the last time I was here and the care that the chefs and servers take in making sure everything is presentable is really lovely.  Things I've eaten here include the ridiculous French Toast and a wagyu burger with bacon which was probably the best burger I've ever eaten. I came for dinner once and had salmon, which was unfortunately on the dry side. But that aside, everything else is stellar! Get the 'Dirty Chai' - chai with a shot of soju and a shot of espresso?! It's as good as it sounds and more.They give you your check in old used books. Totally unnecessary but I LOVE IT. Dreamy drooly sigh. The best hamurger I have ever had.  My friends BLT was amazing!  I'm from LA and want to fly to SF just to get a burger now! Came here for lunch with my brother and enjoyed everything we ordered but our Scrunchy Salad. Only because it has mint leaves and a bit gingery taste in it that I normally don't like. Can't really go wrong with any of their orders but I had the Frisco Poached Eggs and loved every bit of it. The potatoes were delicious and came in such a variety such as sweet potatoes, the prole potatoes, etc. Yum! Will be back. Love how they give you the check with a book attached to keep in theme with their restaurant too. Portions are super filling and they serve drinks in mason jars ^_^ I'm sorry to give this place 1star but even though my friend enjoyed his deep- fried French toast, my egg white scramble smothered with cheddar cheese was airplane quality food. It was awful. It was watery and I'm pretty sure it came from a cartoon of egg- whites. My 8year- old nephew can make better eggs than this. Sorry but this place is a brunch no-go for me. Amazing pork shank.  I loved the windows out to the neighborhood, it was off the main beat but close enough to walk to the Castro.  Romantic - yes.  Service was amazing.  Oddly, we were one of only 4 tables of people.  It was a Thursday, so I don't know if that had anything to do with it being a Thursday night.  Had there been more people, the service may not have been as attentive.  Check this place out for sure. This restaurant totally feels like something straight off of pinterest - suuuper classy/home-y, really really pretty. There were not many tables ... but luckily my friend and I came right when they opened for dinner and got a table right away! :) We ordered the: + BIG EYE : scallops wrapped in bacon with really good sweet potato chips and a mango salsa. - Much like the reviews below mention, their bacon is SOOO yummy. + BURGAH BOY: maple patty with bacon and vermont white cheddar. - Also REALLY good! I thought the patty was pretty favorful... or maybe it was the bacon .. either way, it just worked. Good thing both things we ordered were delicious or else we would have not been able to justify the pricey-ness. As good as this place is - it is not somewhere you want to be eating at every night.The dishes were decorated really prettily =D The service was super attentive; I don't think our cups ever reached half empty...AND their bathrooms were clean - ehehhe.  I really want to come back for the breakfast/brunch menu!Although I will mention, it was a challenge to resist Ike's right next door... What a sweet corner (literally) to brunch in the Castro. Have you ever heard of deep fried french toast? I had not until I came here. Oh wait, it's not just deep friend but also stuffed with a mound of mouthwatering mascarpone cheese topped with fresh fruit and sprinkled with powdered sugar. This thing is massive so sharing is encouraged. Get it, you won't regret it! This please is over rated.   I food was so so however... the millionaires bacon was helluva yummy.   The service was not consistent and actually poor.  Place will not last with just 1 great dish and poor service. I totally did not expect this to be a thai fusion place from the reviews.The decor was good, the food was great and the atmosphere was nice. They had a few wines and we had a good time.
inspec_vio: Moderate risk food holding temperature   [ date violation corrected: 5/7/2014 ] Improper thawing methods   [ date violation corrected: 5/6/2014 ] Moderate risk food holding temperature   [ date violation corrected: 5/6/2014 ] Improper thawing methods   [ date violation corrected: 5/7/2014 ]

name: Kitchen Story 1
category: Breakfast & Brunch in San Francisco, CA
review_text: Had brunch here on a Saturday. This place gets pretty crowded, (there was a 30 minute wait or so when we left).  Luckily, we got seated as soon as we got there. Definitely try their hotcakes and french toast - quite delicious. Also, they have something called their Millionaire Bacon. I'd recommend trying it. It actually tastes very similar to Filipino Tocino if you've ever had it. It's basically bacon smothered in maple syrup! The servers were attentive and we didn't have wait too long for our food. I would definitely come back. Had the Frisco Benedict. Excellent combination of flavors. Just wish it was warmer.Service was solid and we were seated immediately for a 10 am Sunday brunch. Everything was delicious!  Our boss took us here for an after work team dinner.  The place was packed on a Tuesday!  Everything was so yummy. Millionaires bacon was amazing, and crispy chicken dish just melted in my mouth. Mahi appetizers...I dont usually get into SF except for work but would live to take my husband here. Great for brunch and for dinner. came here for dinner last night for my lady's birthday. it was a monday evening at 8pm and they were not busy at all. so if youre trying to avoid a line...there is nothing i can say about the MILLIONAIRE'S BACON that hasnt already been said. it was a genuine treat. first you smell the aroma of seared swine wafting from the kitchen. i could bathe in that smell. then it arrives and it is everything you could possibly hope for and more. by itself, it is a treat. together with the asparagus, it is a nice change of taste. very well executed dish.we also had the CASTRO TOWER appetizer, which was very delicious. the fish and avocado were both fresh and plentiful. on top of the wonton chips, they were an amazing combination. i will be ordering this again.for an entree, she had the BURGAH BOY. the wagyu beef was very very very tender and juicy. melt in your mouth. cooked perfectly. topped with MILLIONAIRE'S BACON on a brioche bun. such a treat. the potato wedges are also ridiculously tasty and crispyi had the pad thai with prawns with NO BEAN SPROUTS. cus gwoss. not bad. no complaints. but the other dishes outshined mine by far. next time, i want to try this sandwich that i dont see on the yelp menu. but it was a scallop sandwich topped with MILLIONAIRE'S BACON on ciabatta. that is something i can support.for beverages, m'lady had the fruit punch, which was tasty. i had the last beer on the list - some type of brun (brown) ale. nutty and coffee-tasting. just my type of brown ale. they comp'd the salted caramel gelato since it was m'lady's birthday. that was nice. all in all, we got out of there with full bellies at a cost of $75 (includes generous tip). service was top notch. decor was nice. will definitely be returning to support this fine establishment. THANKS KITCHEN STORY!! I can happily say that I've been here for both weekend brunch and dinner.Brunch:+ Millionaire's way bacon ($12): two thick slices per order. Heavenly. Perfection.+ Artichoke watercress pesto benedict ($13): pure genius concoction. I have never had an egg benedict dish with artichoke or watercress but the combination works. The pesto hollandaise sauce was a nice change to the ordinary hollandaise sauce, too.+ California burger ($14): awesome burger. When the burger arrived to the table, I was shocked at how big the burger was. I couldn't take my eyes off of it! The burger is made of a wagyu beef patty, dressed up with grilled onions, tomato slice, avocado, sprouts, arugula, mild goat cheese, and a light balsamic glaze. If that description does not make you drool, I don't know what will.Dinner+ Millionaire's way bacon ($12): two thick slices per order. Same comment as above.+ Ahi scoops ($12): the presentation was just damn lovely. Each order consists of 4 scoops of seared ahi tuna on top of cucumber seaweed salad, and crispy yams.+ Mango salad with grilled tiger prawns ($12): divine dish. It's light and refreshing - the mangoes were ripe, the prawns were cooked perfectly (glistening but not oily), and the lime dressing gave the salad a tangy taste.+ "Burgah" Boy ($18): I didn't have a chance to try this dish but my friends raved about it. However, I had a chance to try some of the fried potatoes that accompanied the burger. They were crispy and delicious! Addicting almost.+ Green curry with tofu and rice ($12): pleasantly spicy and sweet at the same time. This is probably one of the best green curries I have ever tasted.+ Side of spicy eggplant ($10): YUM. Eggplant done right. Not mushy or greasy. A friend proclaimed Kitchen Story as her favorite brunch spot in the city (having gone here over 10 times) so naturally, I had to check it out.First off, there is free street parking that doesn't involve parallel parking along Sachez! Great start.We were seated almost immediately and our food arrived more quickly than expected as well. I chose the Primavara Omelette which was a beast of an omelette. Definitely filling. The plate also came with a delightful jalapeno cheese biscuit and a beautifully decorated cup of berries. On top of that, we ordered a side of the Millionaire's Bacon..which was PHENOMENAL. It's pricey at $6.50 for two thick slices, but even frugal me would say that it's worth the splurge. Tasted great with my omelette as well as the biscuit.Can't wait to come back and try the bennies and sandos!PROTIP: They take up to 3 credit cards. Had the most wonderful dinner here!  Such a cute spot, servers were spot on and so super nice, and the food was truly excellent.  Lots of gluten free options and great ambiance.  Had the salmon curry, he had the beef soup, shared the ahi cups.  Portions were great and cooked perfectly.  We cannot wait to come back and try more of the menu. Get ready to wait for good food! This place is always packed but they have an excellent brunch.  I am not a fan of pork but I will inhale their millionaire's bacon any day of th week. Lunch and dinner items are pretty good too. They overcooked my burger once but it's okay.. I am a forgiving girl since everything thing else is pretty awesome. The place is very cute and the staff are super nice! We were in town for the day and wanted some brunch, and this place had the best reviews on yelp, so we try it...Really? 4 stars? The service was very awkward, the food was alright, nothing special, the prices were a bit outrageous for the quality of food. I ordered a Bloody Mary and did not finish it (this has never happened before), that's how bad it was. The place was cute and packed.  The servers and host were friendly.  But the service was SLOW.  I had to ask someone to get our sever so we could order because after sitting there for a long while, we still hadn't been approached by anyone. -The coffee was good. -The mimosas were DELICIOUS and strong.  I think they were the highlight of the meal-My Frisco Benedict was absolutely amazing.  The chicken sausage was on point. -My boyfriend thought his Frisco scramble was mehhhh.  He indicated it wasn't bad and got the job done, but nothing to write home about. I'd go there again if it was less crowded.  Glad I tried it though. Terrible experience here. After going through the menu with the waitress to make sure that all food we were served was gluten free (my girlfriend is allergic to wheat) we were served beef that was marinated in soy sauce. An allergic reaction started and we had leave quickly to get Benadryl. She was sick all night and it completely ruined our evening, although a more serious reaction was averted. This place needs to understand that food allergies are not a joke. We tried the Omurice, deep fried french toast, and the millionaire's bacon.First, the omurice comes in a huge serving, I didn't even get to finish it and I eat a lot! so yeah, good price for the size of the serving.The french toast was a little hard to slice. it was okay.The millionaire's bacon reminds me of the Filipinos' tocino. It was good but I suggest getting one order for two people unless you really really love pork.It was a good meal, will def come back! :) Nomnomnom! Boy was I a happy camper after leaving this place. I would say, probably top 10 in my books for brunch places in SF so far. I came here after eating only 2 hours before so I was exactly super hungry, which would've been nice because then I would've wanted to get a different plate without worrying about having leftovers. I decided to order a simple breakfast with two eggs, chicken mango sausage, rainbow potatoes, and their own cheddar biscuit. I decided on the chicken mango sausage because it was different, something I wouldn't get from other places. I really enjoyed them. It came out as a big patty and it had subtle hints of mango. The biscuits were pretty good. I enjoyed the way it was seasoned and texture. I really wanted I order the famous French toast or the omelette but when I saw it come out for other people, I knew it would've been too much food for me. Will for sure come back with a bigger appetite next time. And props to filling our bottomless mimosas before our cups ever got emptied. Thanks! Our daughters took us out for my BD dinner. The restraunt ambiance was nice. However my food was blend. My wife had beef dish which was so salty. When she came home she was having stomachache and threw up all night. This will be our first and last trial for this place. Right after i wrote this review I was having stomachache and diarrhea. Whoever goes there be careful. Kitchen Story is the reason I got a Yelp account.I went to Kitchen Story in September and have been meaning to write this review for the longest time.  So therefore, some details might be fuzzy.  Overall, my first trip to San Francisco did not go as planned.  All the restaurants I intended to try were busy, closed early, or no parking (as I soon learned would be the case for many of the restaurants).  Kitchen Story was a wonderful accident.After searching through Yelp, my good friends who live in San Francisco now but are from Hawaii found Kitchen Story and warned me of the wait.  We had one person put in our name for the wait while we found parking which is an excellent idea.Skip past the waiting since it was crowded but I expected a much longer wait.  The decor is beyond adorable and the wait staff was amazingly attentive.  Word of advice: you will not know what to order if you sit at the counter and watch all the food come out of the kitchen.Get the bottomless mimosas.  Not only are you making your money back by getting three of the glasses filled (yes, this was calculated prior to ordering them) but they are delicious.  Okonomiyaki pancake?  Who would've thought?  It was soooooo good.  Side order of millionaire's bacon?  Why yes.  It was fat and juicy but soft and tender.  I was on vacation so of course pay the extra for something called MILLIONAIRE'S bacon.  I could go into more detail but the fact the place was so good I can recall the amazing-ness of the food months later says enough for me.  The next time I'm in San Francisco, Kitchen Story will be on my list and no longer an unknown discovery thanks to Yelp. Saturday Brunch.  The experience didn't start off very well.  I put my name on the waiting list.  After about 35 minutes, I started to notice that parties arriving after us (of similar size) were being seated.  I checked the waiting list and noticed there was a line drawn through my name.  We were waiting about 3-4 paces outside the front door, and I watched for the host/hostess every time he/she came out to collect the parties.  I informed the host of the situation to which he scribbled a green highlighter over my name on the waiting list.  Later, two more like-sized parties were seated.  I then talked to the hostess.  She and the host conferred, possibly discussing the meaning of green highlighter.  Afterwards, she acknowledged that we would be seated next.  We were finally seated after about a 50 minute wait.  Frustrating.Service: 3 starsFood came out quickly, coffee was regularly topped off.  Waiting list system needs work.Food: 3.5 starsFranciscan Scramble was just okay.  Rainbow potatoes tasted as if sitting out for a while.  Butter croissant turned out to be a dry and flavorless biscuit.  Ribeye Omurice was pretty good with nice flavor.  Millionaire's Bacon was very good.Decor: 4 starsThe place is visually impressive.  It has a clean, homey feel with lots of wood finishes and furnishings.  The tables are tightly spaced and it gets really, really loud during peak dining periods.  Low-talkers beware.  There is also bar seating and outdoor seating with heat lamps.Overall: 3.4 stars (weighted average)If the food had been better, I might have been less annoyed by the wait list experience.  Some places have an off day, so I'm all for giving second chances. 4 starts yelpers? I think not.. They serve sweet potato chips as a starter - mehThe fried calamari was sooo oily - but the aoli was yummyWe ordered the green curry - the guy said it wasn't very spicy - he was wrong! It was SPICY.. so he told us to order something else.. Oh I forgot we also got the roti - ewww it was soo greasy!We then ordered the Pad Thai - it was just ok.. It was pretty packed, maybe they were off last night OR it's so new that people are swarming to try it.. I might give it another try but for brunch next time.. Stay tuned.. The place is very cute, with a lot of rustic wooden furniture.  The staff is super warm and friendly, allowing us to sit before our full party was there, and never rushed us to leave.The food, however, was only okay.  The millionaire's bacon comes with 2 strips for $12.  At a glance, that seems very little for the price.  But its buttery sweetness will soon consume you and you realize that no one needs to eat one whole strip at a time anyway, so there is actually plenty to share for that $12.  It's definitely decadent and something that's quite out of the ordinary, but I don't know if I necessarily would crave it once the experience is over.My cod with bok choy was quite disappointing. I thought I was getting a nice piece of black cod, but the fish I got was mushy and didn't embody any of that magical texture a decent piece of black cod should have.  And there was no flavor to it. The bok choy, however, was really tasty, and went well with a bowl of jasmine rice. Nothing my friends ordered seem so alluring that made me want to try.  Most plates look like what you'd get at a local Thai restaurant but bigger and pricier. Perhaps their brunch option is better. I waited a week to write this review. Why did I wait? Because I really wanted to think about my experience and make sure that I wrote it when I wasn't still thinking about the millionaire's bacon.I'm still thinking about it.Kitchen Story is ridiculously packed, even at 11 AM on a Saturday, which I feel is the start of brunch, but apparently not here. We ordered bottomless mimosas, which were strong and delicious. Because I'm me and I'm not big on breakfast, I ordered the New England burger, which came with a maple syrup Wagyu patty, millionaire's bacon, arugula, and white cheddar. I'm not a bacon fan, but I'd seen so many reviews talking about the millionaire's bacon that I had to try it. And if you have a sweet tooth, which I do, the millionaire's bacon is a dream. Thick cut bacon laced with fatty goodness, basically dripping with maple syrup. It doesn't sound good, but it's like being in a really rich, decadent dream. If you only eat one thing at Kitchen Story, make it the millionaire's bacon. It's worth every single cent of the hype.My burger was pretty tasty, but the star was the millionaire's bacon, and honestly, between the sweetness and richness of the bacon and the maple syrup patty, ti was a little too sweet for me. Tasty, but I definitely needed to take some breaks, and I have a huge sweet tooth.Kitchen Story is a true gem. Just make sure you get there before 11, or you'll be waiting a mighty long time (but it will still be worth it). I love brunch. I love Korean flava. So naturally, I was drawn to Kitchen Story.Definitely a brunch go-to, so go earlier if you, especially on weekends. Kitchen Story is a small restaurant right next to Ike's. Long line corner all day! But with great reason.This rustic, hipstery, asian fusion hot spot has great sweet and savory dishes. My favorites include the Ribeye omurice and the mascapone stuffed french toasts. The ribeye omurice is essentially eggs over bomb ass asian rice with ground beef and other veggie fixings and sauce. The french toast is as sweet as it sounds - would suggest if you get the meal with it to NOT get the millionaire's bacon, unless you down for some quadruple diabetes in yo mouth. The millionaire's bacon is greeeeaaatttt, but caramelized and sweet as ferngully. Get regular bacon or sausage for that palette abalance, if ya naymsayin. Get the millionaire's bacon paired with something else, and I think you'll get the best flava flav out of it. Service is quiet fast, probably because of the crazy rush. Sadly, no reservations for brunch, but they can be made over the phone for dinner.  Hopefully I get to have a chance to try their evening menu as well!An awesome find forsure! I came here about two months ago, but whenever I think brunch, i always think about kitchen story.food is delicious with an asian twist in every dish. I had the frisco benedict with the rainbow potatoes and being a big potato fan, i was even impressed with the crunchy/softness inside texture of the purple potatoes. the benedict was especially good and filling. my gf ordered the french toast and i must've ate at least half of hers because it was so good. However, the main reason I think of this resturant all the time is because of their millionaires bacon. Theres no proper way to describe it except that its the best bacon ive ever had. Im not even a huge bacon fan, (i always pick sausage over bacon) but I would eat this bacon anytime anyday anywhere! haha its really to die for. delicious food. cool vibe. servers are attentive and friendly. cant wait to come back for seconds The East Meets West was awesome; the pork shank was delicious. Don't eat the leaves that wrap around the rice... The tuna cups were also tasty. My dining partner's eggplant was a bit oily.  I want to return for the Mieng salad and famous bacon!It appears as though Blackwood in the Marina is the exact same restaurant and menu, but with a different name.... Have been twice, once for brunch, once for dinner.The service leaves something to be desired, but the food is so consistently good!! Millionaire's bacon is a must-try, no doubt. These guys do brunch right. Fantastically fluffy omelettes with the perfect distribution of filling in every bite (and they don't skimp on extras either). The freshest fruit. I even put away most of my cheddar & chive biscuit, which I usually avoid as they tend to leave my mouth feeling like a drought-stricken field. Very reasonable prices given the quantity and quality of the food, the ambiance, and the service. I'll be back! I am seriously IN LOVE with this place! I ordered the deep fried French toast with scrambled eggs and the millionaires bacon! Mmmmm. The best bacon and French toast I've ever had! The place is lovely with ambience.  I love the decor but of course we came here to try the food.  We had the salmon with curry, salmon was a bit overcooked and curry wasn't spicy; the Pacific cod was good but too peppery; pad see ew was good as my friend has allergies and ordered it without garlic and no MSG and it was sweet which she liked and I had the finger lickin which was tasty and I liked the curry dip as well.  They also served us some yam chips to start us off.  Those were crispy and tasty.  All in all it was good.  I think if I am ever in the area again, I would like to try their breakfast which is what they are known for here. Awesome place for nice relaxing brunch. Love the atmosphere and food. Quiet enough for nice conversation as well. Me and my friend came here for brunch this past Sunday.  It was roughly a 30-35 min wait and we sat at the bar. I ordered the deep fried French toast with eggs and millionaire's bacon. I wouldn't say it was the best French toast I had. The fried part of the toast was a bit too hard for me to chew (I expected more fluffiness). Thebacon was also too sweet for my taste but my friend loved it. My friend ordered the ribeye omelette. In my opinion, it tasted way better than the French toast.  The omelette was perfect (light and fluffy).  The rainbow potatoes that came with it was good as well. His dish also came with rice and ribeye underneath the omelette. Overall, it was a pretty good dish. Since we sat at the bar, we saw a number of dishes that came out. I would definitely come back to try the mom's Benedict and possibly the bulgogi burger. oh.  my.  god.  i loved this place!  yummy food, great service, fun neighborhood.  my girlfriends and i are picky (they are just picky and I'm gluten free and dairy free) and this fusion food left us all happy! i will def be going back. This place was quite tasty and I loved its location - right on the corner of a very residential street... made it seem a lot cozier / quainter. My food was decent but I would HIGHLY recommend the bacon - thick and delicious... you DEFINITELY get your money's worth with that. Dirty chai wasn't too shabby either! Showed up with my entire family who was in town for a wedding and we were thrilled with the service and the food. The burgers were to die for! I also got a scramble that was amazing- white cheddar and spinach. The portions were really large, (which I was thankful for... our family is not from SF, and are used to being stuffed when they leave a restaurant, and they made sure no one left hungry!!!!!). The staff was super sweet and attentive, and I plan on coming back on a weekday to try some of their salads and burgers. Well done Kitchen Story! I came here with a couple of girlfriends on a Saturday afternoon. We waited approximately 15 minutes and were seated at the bar which gave us a prime viewing spot for all the dishes that were served. I ordered the poached green/red eggs with a fruit cup, my friend got the japanese pancake, and my other friend ordered the poached eggs as well. We were very impressed with the quality of the food! It was absolutely delicious. I am loyal to Zazie, but this place is definitely worth going to especially if you live in the Castro/Mission part of town. If you're vegetarian check out the green/red poached eggs -they were phenomenal! I love this place! Came here twice, food was always yummy. Service is always great. Millionaire bacon melts in the mouth. It's definitely not your ordinary bacon! I love their French toast. I'll be back soon!!!! Get any dish with Millionaire Bacon in it. The name should speak for itself. Their egg dishes and potatoes are miraculous. If you're brunching it up, you can beat the crowd if you arrive at 10:30 or earlier. Plenty of counter seating. Amazing millionaire bacon! Amazing mascarpone stuffed French toast! Love the place, the decor.... It's really homee! There fresh raspberry lemonade is really fresh! Def a must....you won't regret it! You might want to go early because it gets quite busy after 10 am on the weekends... The Sweet and I celebrated a friend's birthday here. We liked the menu - a nice mix of flavors and unexpected treats. The Millionaire Bacon is worth the hype - if you like rich, deep, sweet, salty flavor. The asparagus is a nice, fresh, green foil to the bacon. The wine selection is good. We tried a lot of different dishes and were not disappointed.Our only complaint was the dessert - our friend ordered mango & sticky rice. It came in a nice presentation with mango dice on top, but the mango was completely green and not tasty. The Servers took it back, no charge, and were very friendly about it. What makes up for just a little bit above average food? Service & Food Presentation. These 2 elements are ever present in the Kitchen Story. We went here for brunch and I must say that the portions are HUGE! I tried the Franciscan omelet coz it says on the menu "mango chicken". Unfortunately, I have not tasted the mango or any tanginess on it :( My friend ordered the waffles and it's ok. My other friends ordered the burger which according to them is good :). I will still go back here if I need a very filling meal but for taste, I will consider somewhere else. PS- Oh, the bathroom lights I think are loose!! I asked the staff to check it for me and he grabbed a broom and nudged the lights! I keep on praying it won't turn off while I'm peeing!! Lol!!! pleasant service, prices good. food good, not great. noisy. Woohoo! As good as it gets!Millionaire's Way -- I'm still drooling from itSummer String Bean -- light and crunchy with a light dipping sauceI had the pan-seared tilapia -- it had good flavors but it was a little dry, probably wouldn't get it again, but it was plated really nicely.My party got the Finger-lickin' -- I wish I had gotten this. The dipping sauce is like crack.... so when you order it's like "Hi can I get some crack please?"They also got the grilled wagyu beef noodle soup -- you can get it as spicy as you want it. I didn't think the medium was very spicy but as my party said "well you're Korean"... touche friends. the service was amazing, everyone was really accommodating and I'll definitely be back! I've been here quite a handful of times and coming from a picky eater like me, this is a PLUS!Parking: Street, but free if you are lucky.  Wait: decent, about 30 minutes.  You can stare at the people who are waiting in line next door at Ike's and listen to the employees coming out to direct them to "not block the streets."  Entertaining to some extentFood: Well, I am not a fave of bacon (I know, who doesn't like bacon), but I HAD to order the Millionaire's Bacon and see what the craze is about.  ODG (Oh dear God) was it good.  It is like they drenched this pig in sugar, forced it to drink sugar, and roll itself in ...sugar.  It was delightful :-)  I also had their French toast, which I must admit is nothing like the regular French toast one would make.  However, this my friend, was divine.  What else is good, you asked?  The Franciscan Scramble with their colorful rainbow potatoes which is crispy on the outside and soft in the inside.  The chicken sausage, which I think that chicken made some crazy love with that pig from above.  It was sweet, yet salty all rolled up together as one.  Their burgers whichever one you choose off the menu, was ginormous.  You better practice opening your mouth for this (again, don't be nasty).Overall: 4- keep it up, Kitchen Story! Go for brunch - obvi. Just found out from sitting at the bar today that this place has an 100 out of 100 Health Score. Impressive! Their counters are indeed squeaky clean.As for the food: There were three of us today, and we got three different permeations of a veggie sandwich: the veggie burger, the green panini, and the grilled veggie morning melt. All of them were packed with fresh avocados, arugula, bell pepper, you name it...so good, with generous portions of side salad or potato wedges. And of course we had to get a side of Millionaire's Bacon. It's like candy. Do it.I've never tried to make a reservation for brunch before but looks like they take it. We waited about 35 minutes today and had lovely service. Coffee mug never went empty. This place is solid in my book. Went for brunch, previously had dinner here.  Just can't get excited about the place.  Dinner was OK (3-stars), but everything struck us as slightly sweet, where things should be savory.  Even the "famous" Millionaire's Bacon, which admittedly is intended to be a *little* sweet, is just too sticky sweet to be really great.  More like candy dessert than meaty appetizer.Brunch was pretty meh too. I went decadent and got the fried french toast, expecting a french-toast-like item. Instead it was like a hard-fried ball of tasteless dough with some cheesy goo in the middle.  Not dead awful, but I failed to see the appeal (2-stars).  My partner got an Omurice dish; much better, basically a savory and spicy fried rice with egg on top.  Not fully authentic, but pretty good (4-stars).Service first time was very good (4-stars) but it wasn't very busy.  Brunch was busy and service suffered - no coffee refills until the check came, for example (2-stars). Food: 4 starsService: 5 stars (our server was very attentive, knowledgeable, and friendly)Ambiance: 4 stars (as noted by other reviewers, it gets a little loud inside)We went for dinner and had the:- Millionaire's Way: Millionaire's Bacon, grilled organic asparagus and homemade smoky Maple syrup sauce.- Big Eye Sandwich: Pan-seared U-10 scallop wrapped with our famous Millionaire Bacon, Cibatta roll, garlic spread, arugula, avocado, sweet yam chip, Mango salsa and spicy Dijon Mustard.- Wild King Salmon: Pan seared, grilled organic asparagus, bell peppers, basil, red curry sauce, jasmine rice.- Granny in Town: Mascarpone French Toast, Whiskey Chocolate Sauce, Chocolate Ice Cream, and Whipped Cream.- Black Sesame Gelato- A glass of their Pinot Grigio and MalbecI would highly recommend the Big Eye Sandwich, Pinot Grigio, and their Granny in Town.  The Black Sesame Gelato was delicious, but a little heavy.  The only low-light of the meal was the slightly dry salmon.  Otherwise, the food was great and we'll definitely be coming back again! The millionaires bacon should be called the billionaires bacon. Food is delicious. Definitely one of the best brunchs in SF. Worth the wait! Went on Labor Day and there was a line but the tables turned but fast. I went with my partner and we both agree we'll be back.We started with a michelada and bloody Mary. In my humble opinion, the bloody Mary was the BEST I've had so far. Perfect balance of salty, spicy, tomato deliciousness. We had the Bulgogi burger, grilled veggie panini, and shared the deep fried mascarpone stuffed French toast. Both entrees were delicious, but the French toast stole the show and definitely made to share. I can't image how I'd feel consuming that entire portion solo! We definitely left with food babies but enjoyed every morsel. Service was quick and friendly. Millionare's Bacon = worth every penny. Very accomodating of a large group. Friendly and fast service. Delicious food. A must try! I'm not sure if it was just the night my friend and I came in, but for some reason, things either needed to be seasoned more or seasoned a lot less! Salt is crucial! Crucial, I say! Alright, I'll calm down now...The yam chips they give as a starter were delicious. The calamari was also nicely prepared... though it could use a bit more salt. Dipping sauces are crucial, and theirs was on point. My friend's dish, "Finger Lickin'", was finger lickin' good (womp womp). The chicken had a nice batter. I like that they put pickled cucumber on the side to finish off an otherwise heavy dish. For my entree, the "Dancing Queen" ('cause I'm a dancing queeeen hayyy! We *were* on our way to hitting the clubs after dinner. Duh.)... oooof so this is where I thought they went a little crazy with the salt. The steak (which I ordered medium) was more like medium rare, but hey, it was delicious anyway. (Plus one person's definition of "medium" is another person's "rare," right??) The sauce's flavor was delicious: sweet, spicy, and unfortunately over-seasoned. The string beans (which reminded me of a Thai dish) were slightly spicy and cooked well (not too crunchy, not too soft). My favorite on that plate, aside from the meat itself, was the ginger rice. Glorious! "Can you share that recipe with me please? kthxbye!"We liked the ambiance. It was low key with high-brow as well as comfort food. I liked that the menu had some "California" or "New American" foods along with pan-Asian dishes. I'd give it another try -- probably for brunch. That might change my "meh" review of Kitchen Story. What a great place to have breakfast. I remember the old Port Cafe... Then Grub...then Tangerine... Seems like this was the cursed corner for restaurants... I like Kitchen Story. Nice updated contemporary interior. Lots of energy (and noise level) to bring you alive in the morning/early afternoon. Good service, and good food.I had the deep fried mascarpone French toast, with a couple eggs, and that much talked about millionaires bacon... Excellent on all points. Really. I will return to try other features! I've only been here once with a friend for dinner and I look forward to coming back. We came here on a Friday night without reservations and had to wait a bit for us to get seated while they sorted out a problem regarding reserved tables but we got seated in roughly 5 minutes which is more than acceptable and the server was very nice. The decor of the place is also really nice, feels comfy and lighted well enough to not feel like you're eating in the dark but also not so bright that you will be distracted by other customers.We started with the crab cakes and they were really good. It didn't taste like they used very much filler (which is always a big plus). There was two crab cakes (making it great for sharing) with a sauce that I couldn't quite make out what exactly it was but it was delicious nonetheless. The only issue I had with this dish was the particular plating; the arugula was sandwiched between the crab cakes and the mango salsa was on top and the sauce on the bottom. Although the plating looked great, it wasn't very practical when it came to actually sharing it because taking the top crab cake would mean taking most of the mango salsa, then we had to remove the arugula before taking the bottom crab cake which had most of the sauce. Aside from that issue though, it was delicious.I ordered the Burgah Boy while my friend ordered the Finger Lickin' (fried chicken). My burger was cooked to perfection and the potato wedges were surprisingly good. I usually don't expect very much from fried potato sides (fries, wedges, etc.) but man these were good; they were very crispy on the outside and meaty on the inside and seasoned well. The "Millionaire" bacon is definitely unique in its taste in a good way; it was a very thick cut of bacon, a tad salty with a sweetness that compliments the burger surprisingly well. I can't say that I would want to order this burger again because sweet bacon is just a bit odd in flavor for me but it's definitely worth trying if you haven't tried it before. The burger was still good, it just wasn't what I want in a burger if that makes any sense.My friend's fried chicken looked so good, it made me regret getting the burger, yes, it looked THAT good. I didn't try his chicken though but it looked like it was cooked perfect; fully cooked on the inside while still moist. It came with the aforementioned potato wedges as well as a stellar yellow curry dipping sauce. I tried the curry and I was ready to drink it! This is definitely something I would get the next time I come here.My friend also had two glasses of wine that I didn't try and the total came out to about $73 without tip. Over all, I really enjoyed my experience here; the servers were friendly and fast, good food, and good ambiance. Definitely see myself coming back. Kitchen Story is incredibly cute - whoever was in charge of the interior design did a spot on job with all the decor. However the food was just okay, and the service was A for effort, but C for execution. I'll get to that in a second.I went with a big group of friends so we ordered a variety of dishes. Definitely, definitely get the Millionaire's Bacon appetizer. It was probably one of my favorite bacon dishes of all time. You really can't go wrong with bacon and asparagus, ever. The crispy calamari was pretty good too!Now for the mains, I was really disappointed in my mango salad with prawns. It was wayyy too wet and the sweetness of the dressing was overpowering. I was really looking forward to it too :( Mom's coconut soup was amazing though and my friend's spicy eggplant was to die for. But really, you can get amazing eggplant like that for 1/2 the price at a Chinese restaurant. It's funny how once it becomes asian fusion the prices just double.Our server was really nice, and perhaps overly attentive. I don't think he was aware of the etiquette behind pouring wine because he filled our glasses up way too high. It was a bit annoying because a few of us drove and really just wanted a single glass of wine, not an endless glass. This particular way of serving the wine also led to us finishing multiple bottles of wine (3-4) where 1-2 would have been way more than enough. Again, though, I don't think he did it intentionally.Overall, this restaurant was really cute and had a charming vibe. If you're craving a burger, I'd recommend checking it out since our friend who ordered a burger loved it. But if you're looking for a reasonable dinner with friends and wine, this place will be over your budget. If they learned how to pour wine, maybe not. Had brunch here a few months ago and enjoyed it. Very cute decor, and we got right in (although I do believe it was a weekday). Solid eggs benedict, which is one of my all-time favorite dishes so I'm very picky. I'll definitely go back and try some of their other options. I've been to Kitchen Story twice.  Once for Lunch and once for Dinner.  I LOVE THIS PLACE.  For lunch I had the Chicken Sandwich.  It was soooo good.  HUGE piece of chicken and so flavorful.   My mouth waters just thinking about it.I was a little disappointed to see they had a completely different menu for dinner because I was going to order the chicken sandwich again!    But it wasn't available so I ordered the Pad See Ew.   It was some of the best I have ever had.   My friend ordered the Pad Thai and he felt the same way about his dish.I would highly recommend Kitchen Story.... Food was amazing and the service was just as awesome. Great dinner for my girls birthday. Table reservation was ready for us. Must have the castro tower and the coconuy soup!!! The Millionaire's Bacon is like eating steak. I've never tasted bacon quite like it. So freakin good! (See my edit below)Love that they have healthy options here! Egg whites and berry substitutes for potatoes. The potatoes are fantastic though, you can get them in several ways such as rainbow, with cheese etc.Mimosas are fantastic. A great location for a San Francisco Brunch.Edit: We ordered two millionaires bacon orders which is why my recollection based on what was indicated on the receipt was that it was over $12 for one. As the owner states it's $6.50, so this is even better--get two orders! I almost avoided this place because of all the talk of bacon. Luckily I didn't and had an eclectic meal, well cooked and served.  The steak with ginger rice was delicious to the point of eating every grain of rice.  We also shared a  Raw tuna appetizer which was large and delicious.  Everything we got was a hit. Liked the ambiance here, had the maple burger with bacon, holy F. I'll definitely come back. Adorable indoor theme - 1 starEasy parking - 1 starFast & friendly service - 1 starGreat salad/ veggie options - 1 starTantalizing dessert menu - 1 starBEST BURGER IN SF - 1 *million* stars!!   (million to go with the Millionaire's bacon!)I love this spot.  So easy to get to, and off the beaten path.  It feels like a neighborhood gem, and it IS!  Must get:  Tartare Salad, Millionaire's Burger.  It is the BEST - maple, sweet, smokey, crunchy, savory, meaty, juicy.  If you can save room for dessert do it - grandma's french toast is decadently delish. Went there Sunday at 10:00 am - greeted well and immediately seated - and the bus boy brought us a nice bottle of water.   That was the last we saw of anyone who acknowledged us for the next thirty minutes.  The table two down from us who were seated after us received their beverages (coffee and orange juice) and we were again "not seen".   I wish we could say we had a comment about the food but we decided to leave for lack of attention after waiting nearly 30 minutes at the table. Neither the host nor anyone else acknowledged our existence.    I'd have to tell people "don't waste your time" when so many other restaurants provide excellent service and good food. This place is great. Reminds me of sweet maple but I think the food here is a little better IMO.  When the food comes out it looks perfectly assembled, and tastes ever better! Fast facts:-Portions are just the right size...pretty hefty amount.-Millionaire bacon is amazing.  -Omelettes are nice and puffy.-They make really good coffee. Parking: Easy find (for us), it's street parkingYes, waiting list= we visited on a Saturday afternoon, so the wait was about 30+minutes, or more? They didn't call us and we were waiting outside (like the rest that were on the list), and we checked to see how many more ppl ahead of us and they said they did call us. (No they didn't we were near the door!) -_-Sat down and already knew what to order, waiting about 20+ minutes for our order to come. FOOD: Yes it was good, that's why there's even stars here. Otherwise service/wait---Ehh it was so-so. Went in to this place for brunch with a cousin and her friend and the only saving grace for this place was the food; the service was rock bottom.It took our server 20 minutes to bring us water.. so I enjoyed a packet of sugar while we waited. Then my chicken sandwich arrived. I couldn't believe it. The most amazing sandwich I've ever had in my entire life. Could it have been the extra sugary snack beforehand? Maybe, but I let the chef have his day.The rest of our visit was pleasant, spent with great food while the server was absent until the check came.I typically NEVER have complaints about waiting or service in a restaurant so this was the one exception I've ever made. Know what you expect to order before you sit down so you don't have a long wait. Otherwise, enjoy your sugar water! Delicious food. Friendly, funny staff. Millionaires bacon is to die for. Spicy Pad Kee Mao was phenomenal! My wife and I went for a breakfast but lunch menu looked really good as well. I had a berry french toast with scrambled eggs and "Millionaire Bacons." Eggs were cooked the shape of an omelet, which I really enjoyed but most impressive among them was the Millionaire Bacon. It was thick, tender and perfectly cooked and maple cyrup glazed. Definitely the best bacon I've ever had in my life. I'm sort of glad I don't live in San Francisco because this bacon is too addictive.Needless to say, the french toast was excellent also. Would love to make another special trip again. Loved it. Yelped to find somewhere to eat in this area at the right price point and stumbled upon Kitchen Story. We were able to sit right down with no wait (8pm on Monday). Three of us split three entree salads which were fun, creative and fresh. This place is the most delicious breakfast ever!  The staff is sooo friendly and very attentive.  I just had bacon and croissants but the butter they served was tasty and slightly sweet.  Even on a Tuesday it's busy but worth it. Cute space with excellent service. We enjoyed our dinner here very much. It's affordable and laid back. We were able to be seated immediately which was a HUGE plus. The food was fresh and tasty. Often times I find "fusion" to be code for bland, but Kitchen Story's dishes are flavorful with a decent spice level. We will be returning with our next group of out-of-towners! Tried this place for breakfast/brunch.Great local food with an Asian-Fusion twist, Great balance. The Interiors made the eating experience fun and enjoyable. There was a line but it went quick.We will definitely try this place for dinner. This place is decent: affordable and tasty and so close to my house. Potatoes were delicious, fries were yummy, bacon was amazing. However considering they are a brunch place, they need to learn to poach eggs. Mine was overcooked and it seemed too busy to send it back. Kind of ruins a good Benedict when the eggs are not runny. Sad eggs make me sad. Overall: Loved the presentation and flavors. The menu has a fun variety of options, will be going back to try them out. I came here on a Sunday with my sister few weeks ago. It's in the Castro district so it's kind of hard to find parking which kinda sucks. My sister and I arrived to the restaurant around noon and the place was PACKED! Luckily, we got seated pretty fast because we asked to sit by the counter instead of waiting 30-40 minutes for a table. The restaurant itself is a pretty small place but it's not too bad either. My sister ordered Ricotta Hot Cakes and I ordered Frisco Benedict. Man oh man, both of our plates tasted so good!! So, the Frisco Benedict has a chicken mango sausage that were super savory and some colorful potatoes on the side. The Benedict itself was really good too. It was poached egg and mango sausage on top of a piece of bread. Everything looked so fancy and delicious. If you look at the pictures on yelp, basically that's what it is. Looks really good huh?! I really enjoyed it. My sister's dish which was the Ricotta Hot Cakes was also good too. It had a lot of fruits on it and was savory too. Man, looking back at my pictures, I AM WANTING SOME RIGHT NOW!!!! AHHH!! I definitely would love to come back here and eat here again. I would love to try other dishes and some of their sandwiches too!! Awesome brunch spot with great bloody marys. The wait can be a little long but totally worth it. Sweet service. Dorky decor. Mediocre food that leaves little impact. I took a friend from Hawaii and was embarrassed that I had since it wasn't that good. I can vouch for only one item on the menu: The Burgah Boy. It's good! Cutest place ever with a unique Asian fusion menu. My boyfriend took me here for brunch on Saturday around 1:30pm, and the wait was about 10-15 minutes. I loved the ambiance and decor. The walls were lined with old books and little succulents on top of wooden bookshelves. I ordered the mascarpone stuffed deep fried french toast with scrambled eggs and millionaire's bacon for $2 extra. The french toast was 2 thick slices of bread with mascarpone in the center, deep-fried to perfection, and topped with fresh berries. The mascarpone complimented the sweet french toast and fruit. And when you dip that combination in the sweet syrup - heavenly! The scrambled eggs brought out the Asian fusion theme in the dish, and it reminded me of the steamed eggs that Korean restaurants serve as a side. I love steamed eggs, and these were light and fluffy and delicious. The millionaire's bacon was probably the best bacon I've ever tasted, and I usually don't like bacon. They were 2 gigantic thick slabs of what seemed to be pork belly and were covered in a maple glaze.My boyfriend ordered the frisco benedict with rainbow potatoes. The benedict consisted of chicken mango sausage, avocado, peppers, a poached egg, and a light lemon hollandaise sauce. I had a bite and it was so good! The hollandaise wasn't heavy like most hollandaise sauces tend to be. The chicken mango sausage was slightly sweet and was packed with flavor. The rainbow potatoes were very interesting and looked like a combination of purple yam, yellow potatoes, and sweet potatoes. I expected them to taste sweet, but they were actually all savory! They added such nice color to the plate too, which is definitely a plus. The portion was smaller than my boyfriend had hoped for, and I could tell that he was was trying so hard to savor every last bite of his meal.I really enjoyed my experience here. The service is fast and the waiters are friendly. The check comes inside a book, which I thought was the cutest thing ever. I guess I'm just a sucker for all their cute decor, and I can never say no to good food. I'll definitely be back again soon! Solid brunch spot with good food and service.  Two of us showed up on Sunday at noon without reservations and the wait was around 15 minutes.  The Okonomiyaki (modernyaki) Egg Pancake was huge with a nice crust and chewy bite to it.  The flavor was like a green onion pancake (the eggy kind) with a hint of kimchi.  I upgraded my plate to include eggs and millionaire's bacon.  No need to elaborate on the bacon since it gets so much love.  I did quite enjoy the butteriness and half moon shape of their generously portioned scrambled eggs, which kind of reminded me of the airplane breakfasts I eagerly wake up to on long-haul flights.  Didn't realize that it was sister restaurants with Sweet Maple until my plate arrived garnished with the two strange skinny crunchy sticks that I noticed a few weeks prior on my plate at Sweet Maple.  I'd happily eat here again. I should have read the reviews first - it seems the main reason to come here is either a burger or the millionaire's bacon.  I had the KS omelette, which was sub-par diner fare.  The potatoes were good, but really not compelling.  I think Pomelo is much more creative, and Zazie's much more flavorful. I don't understand the four out of five stars overall rating. I have been here on two separate occasions for weekend brunch and my boyfriend and I have been mostly disappointed. I will talk about the "mostly" soon.We have ordered their omeletes and have experienced them as blah. No flavor. Runny. We add salt and ketchup in hopes of something more but still nothing. A few more notes: Coffee is average and tea comes to you lukewarm. However, on our most recent visit, we decided to try the infamous Millionaire's Bacon. It's a whopping $6.50 for two strips of bacon. That is $3.25 for one strip of bacon (oh, hey, I can do math!). Can I just I say "well-worth-it?!" Long story short? Come here for the bacon only. Great brunch, service, ambiance and price. A hidden gem I'm excited to go back to!Had the ricotta stuffed deep fried French toast and shared it with eggs, bacon and potatoes. Both we're delicious, especially enjoyed the potatoes and bacon! This place a was very nice surprise. My friend and I ran into it while trying to search for a breakfast/ brunch joint. It was perfect. They combine the old vintage to a more modern look. I loved it. Everything from their decor to the check holder. Food: was good. I had the egg Benedict and my friend had their famous million dollar bacon. Bacon was tasty but the sweeter side for my pallet but good non the less. The Egg B was perfectly cooked, however, I would prefer it on a hot platter. Atmosphere was great, staff was excellent and again I love the decor at this place. Will definitely go there again. I had no idea this place was an Asian fusion restaurant until I read the reviews after I had already eaten there. The rustic decor makes me think it is an upscale fancy American diner. I don't think anything I ordered had an Asian flare to it. Nevertheless, I did enjoy having brunch here.I ordered an eggs benedict type plate which did come with two skinny crispy Asian noodles on top for garnish or something. I guess that's what made it Asian! The poached eggs were perfect and the sauce was delicious. I opted out of potatoes and got a little cup of berries instead but I was so full from my meal that I barely touched the fruit. My friend had rainbow potatoes with hers and they were super crunchy fried and colorful. It was delicious! The service was friendly and fast and it wasn't too crowded but then again I went on a weekday during brunch. They take reservations which weren't necessary on a weekday but I am sure it'll help on the weekend. Great place for brunch! This review is based on the Franciscan omelet that I ordered.  I came with my boyfriend and we both ordered breakfast entrees.  It seemed as if the timing was off because my food sat under a heat lamp for about 5 minutes before his was ready.  I get that things like this are usual but when my food came it was lukewarm and the "cheese" that was melted on top had turned into a rubbery texture.  The omelet itself was a round circular pile of eggs and then it looked like slices of jack cheese were just melted on top - so no cheese was actually cooked in with the eggs.  The potatoes seemed like they were microwaved or reheated somehow and very oily.  I didn't finish my meal and wouldn't come back here again. Our rating is an average (rounded-up) for the members of Gentlemen's Burger of the Month Club.  Individual member reviews below:"Bring your sweet tooth! The Kitchen Story burger is decidedly out of place in this Thai-fusion restaurant, but the chef knows his way around a patty and a bun. The maple syrup in the patty is decadent but delicious, and the bacon was the icing on top. 4 stars if it were a notch more savory and less sweet."3.5 Stars-Cameron E."Very solid burger and it was obvious they were using top ingredients.  I usually like bacon, but in this case found the Millionaire bacon too sweet. Overall too rich of an experience, after all I'm not a millionaire. Bonus points for good staff and comfortable place. I'd come again, but maybe not for the burger."4 Stars- Paul L."If you are ever undecided between french toast and a burger, kitchen story has the solution for you. they have a long name for it, but i just call it the brunch burger. all of the ingredients were top notch, from the meat to the bun to the fixings...but the maple syrup made for a strangely sweet (and messy) burger. good stuff, if you have a sweet tooth."3.5 stars-Jamie H. Let me just get straight to the point - you don't want to look at the menu, I will tell you right now what you will order:Two eggs with Millionaire's Bacon.Long and thick slabs of bacon all sweet and stuff. And if you're feeling extra thirsty, go for the bottomless mimosa. There's is usually a long wait for brunch especially on weekends, BUT you can start your bottomless mimosa order while waiting. Seating inside and out, but I would prefer inside because it's hella cold in SF for an LA girl. Parking by streets. I enjoyed Kitchen Story so much that I had brunch here two weekends in a row. The first time was during Labor day weekend. The four of us arrived around 11 a.m. and the wait was about 30 minutes. This past weekend, the wait was 10-15 minutes around 10 a.m. If it's a nice day and outdoor seating is available, make sure to sit outside as it makes your brunch experience that much more enjoyable.  Both times I had the Red & Green Benedict, which might be the "healthy" version of all the benedicts -  mushrooms, roasted tomatoes, spinach, and mango salsa on a thick slice of bread, all topped with two perfectly poached eggs and no hollandaise sauce.
