Although there's no meat or hollandaise sauce, this sucker packs a punch of flavors from the tomatoes and mango salsa! I definitely recommend this. $12Two of my friends ordered the Frisco Benedict. Damn, that chicken mango sausage is tasty! It's a flat patty that's spicy, savory, and sweet at the same time. $13. The other friend ordered the ribeye omurice. Not impressed. After reading the description, everyone was expecting a slice of ribeye, but received something like fried rice with small pieces of ribeye mixed in. Definitely not something to order when craving for a a piece of red meat with your eggs. $14If you are craving for meat, order the California Burger. I don't think I've ever had such a silent meal with WL. The only thing I heard hungry man say was, "damn this is good," after taking his first bite. The fries were superb also.  $14 He looked quite satisfied afterwards and mentioned, "if this meal wasn't good, you would've gotten an earful." Disclaimer: if you're like me and isn't a fan of goat cheese, pass on this and order the New England Burger $14 that has the famous millionaire's bacon, which leads to the next delicious item...Millionaire's Bacon. Although the price is quite steep($6.50 for two slices of bacon), this is probably the most delicious bacon I've ever had. Extremely thick cut bacon covered in sticky brown sugar and chili flakes causes an explosion of flavor in your mouth. It reminds me of sticky moist Chinese jerky my grandparents used to buy us. Order from the portion of the menu that has the french toast to add a slice of millionare's bacon for $2.One of my picky eater friends found a HUGE eggshell in his Frisco Benedict, but he was so happy with his order that he let it pass. Both times, there was no complaint on service. My cup of coffee and water were consistently refilled and the waiters passed by so many times that it was no trouble at all to wave someone over. Good coffee and good food is a winner in my book!Coming here on a regular basis can get costly since it cost $24 per person each time around, but I'd definitely recommend Kitchen Story to anyone and everyone who asks for a brunch spot. ahh I return again for brunch with a friend.  I was craving an omelette and thus ordered the K's omelette.   It looked waay better than it tastes.  The sausage bits are microscopic and sparse in this thing. I couldn't really taste it at all.  The asparagus is cut up in small pieces.  The thing is NOT SALTED AT ALL.  In fact I don't think there is any salt in any of the omelettes or eggs.  It is simply just different when you salt something after cooking, and salt it during cooking to incorporate and meld the flavors.  Anyway, better than -too- salty (which happened anyway as I oversalted, but that's my prob :/).  But seriously, salt is the one true seasoning so I am not sure why the chef doesn't do it for the eggs.The pork wine sausage is nice.The bacon was super hella crispy (too much), and a bit too salty. I ordered the ribeye omurice ($14), the main reason I wanted to try Kitchen Story. The rice was served under scrambled eggs rather than inside an omelette. The scrambled eggs were delightfully buttery, and the demi glace was tasty. The jasmine rice with ground ribeye, carrots, peppers, spinach, and green onion had a mild kick, and the flavors reminded me slightly of bibimbap. It was served with a croissant, rainbow potatoes, and fresh fruit, like most of the egg dishes on the menu.The choices at brunch span the full spectrum of breakfast, brunch, and lunch options, from eggs and French toast to burgers and paninis, and a few Asian-inspired dishes here and there. I'd come back to explore more of the menu. The staff and kitchen worked efficiently, and we experienced no inappropriately long delays from when we were seated to when we got our credit cards back. We weren't rushed by the staff either though. Reservations aren't accepted for weekend brunch, and Kitchen Story doesn't seat partial parties. The first time I tried to come here, the wait was over an hour. The second time there was no wait.Nice, well-lit space. Lots of seats lined up on the sidewalk for people who are waiting for a table. Visually, nice restaurant, but when it comes down to restaurants, I really want great food and service.   The service was a bit spotty - frantic help at the front to get a table to changes in waiters who sporadically brought food out - always rushed.   Maybe they should hire more staff.  The table who sat much later than us got their food first.  We did get an apology for the delay.  We ordered the millionaire bacon and was so disappointed - super sweet and not to my liking.  The sweet potato chips tasted like they were cooked in burnt oil that needed to have been changed yesterday.  I had the scallops sandwich and just my luck - it was wrapped in the millionaire bacon!  Waaah.  The scallop smelled fishy so I had my plus one smell it and he was brave to tasted and assured me it was safe to eat.   Positive:  walking distance to Birite ice cream - good way to get over the night. Delicious!  The French toast was unique and amazing, tried the bacon too.. Highly recommend! Just went a few days ago when a friend from out of town was visiting and it worked out really well for our big group.The wait staff was incredibly patient with us, our different arrival times and our many menu-related questions.I got the penang curry and it was really tasty. I was honestly surprised because I tend to have low expectations of places that have menus that sprawl over different cuisines. Usually, restaurants trying to do too much do nothing well, but I think Kitchen Story is surprisingly tasty!We asked for our curries to be extra spicy, and didn't find them to be too spicy, though.  But I can understand them being fearful they'll turn a customer totally read and teary-eyed.Lovely dinner, thanks guys!Also just some background on my rating scale for other reviewers: 5's are rare for me--restaurants that blow me away4 is really good--places i'm very likely to go back and eat more of very often3 is squarely good--a good experience that one should try but that i wouldn't go out of my way to go back for in the next 3 months but would return to if I was in the neighborhood2 is okay--a meal that i won't really remember or recommend others to try1 is badI do plan on going back to try the brunch, though, there's always such a big line and I'm intrigued! Also find that there's such a big variety of things to try on the menu, I'll probably be back for dinner the moment I'm in Castro again. Not only did I have the best bloody mary of my life, but I had the best bacon of my life, as well.  With a name like "Millionaire Bacon," I expected something tasty, but I did not expect to be so blown away by the rich complexity of the flavors.  Look, guys.  I know how bacon tastes.  It's friggin' delicious.  I could eat it every day, and never get sick of it.  But what I ate at Kitchen Story was NOT bacon.  It was MILLIONAIRE bacon, and though I am far, far, far away from becoming a millionaire in actuality, I certainly felt like a million bucks.But please, let me tell you more.  I had some kind of eggs benedict, the name of which escapes me currently.  It wasn't the *best* eggs benedict I've had, but it was certainly up there.  Finally, the atmosphere.  Treat yourselves, guys.  The restaurant is as interesting to look at as the food is to eat.  Five stars. One of San Francisco's Hidden gems. This must be a new personal record, to go to a restaurant four times in the same month. I am thankful for the friend that ditch work to take me to this place. The restaurant is located right next door to the overly hyped ike's place. Their line usually covers the restaurant scaring away any potential guest from coming in.Once you walk in you are greeted by the friendly staff and seated. The decor has nice accents of wood allover and has a cozy cabin feeling. Seats are made from metal and booths are against the walls. Most of the staff are asian (thai i think) you will notice a lot of familiar american items are touched with a little asian flare. Many of the savory items on the menu have a small hit of sweetness like thai food. Ive been here a total of 4 times for brunch. I will be coming back for dinner. I can safely say that this place is definitely a better breakfast place then lunch. The ricotta hotcakes are TO DIE FOR!!!! Other things I recommend are the eggs Benedict's and millionaire bacon are crowd pleasers.This place gets me excited about breakfast again, something i thought was forever gone. The crab panini has an excellent blend of cream dressing that accommodate the crab very well.  helenic salad the shrimp are over cooked but the rest of the salad is good specially the dressing it goes well with the goat cheese Ran through my list of usual places for brunch on Labor Day but couldn't find any of them open, so took a pin in the map of the Castro and ended up at the Kitchen Story. I suppose there is a story behind the name but I never figured it out. They don't take reservations for brunch, so it's put name on list and wait. I think we waited 45 minutes today. There are three places to eat: outside on sidewalk (windy), inside at the bar (barstools), or traditional tables. We opted for an inside table. The service was slow, and the noise level chaotic, probably due to the endless mimosas being served. At times the noise exceeded 110 db. (I had a db meter app on my phone), especially when the woman next to us shouted everything she had to say to the entire restaurant. 110 db is about the equivalent of a lawnmower or rock concert. Too loud for a comfortable brunch. The only alternative would to have sat outside. We should have. Next time, for sure! I understand that dinner is far more subdued (no bottomless mimosas) and enjoyable.To the food:  I had the California Eggs Benedict with chicken mango sausage. It was near perfect. The eggs were just right, the sausage delicious, the Hollandaise exactly right.  My partner had the benedict with pork sausage, equally delicious.Summary: go for the food, bring ear plugs if it's a cold, windy day and you must sit inside. First, let me say that I have no big complains about the food or the service. In fact, they were quite attentive, the food was presented nicely and largely tasted alright (more on that later). So whats the problem? Well, by the time I get around to eating here, I've already read numerous articles about this restaurant and seen dozens of facebook posts...so my hopes were way up by the time I step foot into their door. Needless to say, they didn't quite live up to what I was expecting. The food, I would call them a fancy upper scale thai restaurant that also serves burgers, kind of like asian fusion but definitely more thai than fusion. The yam crisps were good, they were on the house. The millionaires bacon was sinful. The finger lickin chicken was fried to perfection, i loved the russet wedges that came with it and the cucumber salad as well. The wagyu beef though however, was just a tad bit disappointing. Firstly, you would have to think twice about wagyu that costs only 20 dollars. Its not a great cut, and was chewier than the wagyu's I'm use to. It came with a side of garlic long beans, which was delicious, and was on top of a large bed of brown rice, which was wonderfully flavored from the beef juice and maybe even some hoisin sauce. But the beef was a bit overpowering, it tasted too saucy and that took a lot away from the beef flavor that I like. I dont know why they pour rum over it and light it on fire, I dont think it adds anything to the flavor, its all looks. Anyhow, I think the millionaires bacon is worth the stop, but thats about it. The millionaire bacon is awesome if you like bacon and have some tolerance for spicy food. I also liked the French Toast a lot. 3 of us shared 2 entries plus a side order of bacon, and that was more than enough. We went on a weekday at 10am and it was pretty full. I can imagine this place being packed on weekends. Loved the rustic decor. Have to admit I was a bit confused by the concept (Asian fusion is always difficult to execute, especially when the restaurant looks like an American farmhouse). My friends and I stared at the menu and had no idea what to order (burger? coconut broth? rice? salad?); we ended up with a medley of dishes that sorta did, sorta didn't work together.Good news is, I was able to sample several dishes on the menu (sadly not the burger, which for the record looked PHENOMENAL). The coconut broth was creamy and perfect. The famous millionaire bacon with asparagus was show-stoppingly good. My friend had the mango salad with grilled tiger prawns, which was apparently far too wet and not to her liking. I had the calamari ceviche salad with "crispy" wontons -- really fresh fish and great sour flavors, but the wontons were a bit soggy.We were a party of 6, we shared a couple bottles of wine and our bill came out kind of expensive: around $50 each. Would totally have added on a star if it wasn't for the hefty price tag. Overall had a charming time here, it's just not one of my favorites in terms of value. Very impressed.  I finally know how millionaires eat bacon, and what motivates them to succeed. Came here for my very last minute birthday dinner for a party of 8, I believe I made the reservation only hours before. They graciously made the reservation for me.Still though, I had to push their buttons and arrive almost 30 minutes late, nearing closing time. Still, the waiters and staff were understanding and we received great serviced that was not rushed or compromised due to it being closing time. The food was great, not spectacular, but very well-priced.Thank you guys for making it a great birthday dinner for me! :) Good breakfast spot if you are in the neighborhood. Reasonably priced. The millionaire's bacon is solid. Wow, I have to say that I loved the Short Rib Tacos - sweet and savory and tender to the bite, these were a perfect dinner item.  The space is cool and it's always busy, which makes for a lively dining experience.  Some friends had the burger and really liked that too... Awesome place for a late brunch. Ordered the snowed spinach scramble and hubby had the California burger. Everything was delicious. Oh and two orders of millionaire bacon please. This is really why we came, the entrees was to cover a bacon addiction.Going to be super decadent and order take out next time. This way we can order more bacon and say it is for friends:) Arrived on a sunny Sunday afternoon around 1:15pm with a girlfriend.  Brunch ends at 3pm so the wait was not too bad.  Their waiting list had 3 options - outside, inside or bar.  I checked off all 3 since I was starving like a mofo.  But if I had a choice I would def opt for outside seating especially on a sunny day!   So after about 10-15 minutes, we got a seat at the counter bar.  This works out since there was only 2 of us and we can see all the food that comes right out of the kitchen.  We ordered: **Franciscan Omelet $13 - consists of chicken mango sausage, mushroom, celery, cheese and avocado.  The eggs were super fluffy and I love that they have egg white options ($2 extra). Came with house "rainbow" potatoes and croissant. Overall a delicious dish and the presentation was very pretty.  **Crab Panini $14 - grilled crab salad sandwich with arugula and pepper jack with a side salad.  Simple but good. I thought it went really well with the arugula.**French Toast $10 - deep fried ciabatta bread and filled with mascarpone cream. This was just OK- a little too heavy for me.  It actually reminded me of the fried Chinese donut.  2 bites was more than enough to satisfy the sweet tooth.  ***Bottomless Mimosas $16 - Fresh squeezed OJ :) I just want to let folks know that they will not take reservations for large parties; walk-in only. Even if you have 14 people. I find this really troubling because usually if you're organizing a brunch for 14 people, you want to make sure there's space for you to actually eat. So this restaurant should absolutely be taken off the "Good for large parties" list. Amazeballs!!!! Yelpers thank you for finding this place for me! Millionaire way- should be illegal! So amazing!Calamari- if you like fried food this is a must. Spicy Kobe wraps- partay in my mouth!! :) Tuna salad -skip this one but try their beef saladShort rib tacos- all hail the best taco I have eaten in a very long time. This was the star of the night! You must must must eat this! Wine- Sauvignon Blanc was fabulous Service- 6 stars...so honest and knowledgable.  Really warm and welcoming. This place has now become our go to spot for friends who love asian fusion! Huge huge thumbs up!! Sister restaurant of Sweet Maple in Lower Pac Heights.Lovely menu that offered brunch items even after 11am.I only realised that they were the sister restaurant of Maple when I saw "Millionaire's Bacon" or rather, "Billionaire's Bacon" IMO.As tempted I was to order Mom's Special Fried Chicken, I knew I was going to have a heavy dinner that night so I got the Veggie Burger. It had the requisite grain patty, roasted tomato, onion, avocado, spinach, swiss cheese. Wow. I really liked this a lot. Everything was fresh and delicious, one of the best veggie burgers I've ever had. Of course I had to recommend Millionaire's Bacon as a side and I was a teeny bit disappointed that it took so long to get to us. We had pretty much finished our meal and it came at the end, like a dessert but we were so stuffed that we couldn't finish it. Imagine that - not finishing the Millionaire's Bacon. Sacre Bleu! The food here is a little gimmicky, (*Millionaire Bacon*, *Deep Fried French Toast*) but doesn't really deliver on the execution.  Everything sounds really good, but then just tastes OK, nothing special.  The Millionaire Bacon is extremely sweet because of whatever they add to it, which to me kind of ruins the bacon flavor.  It's just a bit sloppy and doesn't really work, and $7 for two (albeit thick) strips is a bit steep.  Also had the San Fran eggs benedict and it was just OK.  The potatoes it comes with are a nice blend, but under seasoned.  This is OK for the sweet potatoes, but then you get a bland mouthful of non-sweet potatoes and it just doesn't work. Came here for a friend's birthday dinner. We got the crispy calamari and string beans. Both over-battered and deep fried with no taste. The ahi spoons were quite good but with a little too much going on a spoon. Hard to eat as well since it's too big to go down as one bite. I got the Mieng Kum salad. The description reads "crispy prawns, spinach, zesty mixture of lime, ginger, onion, roasted peanuts and shredded coconut, caramelized palm dressing." Tasty right? What I got was two shrimp wrapped in lumpia wrappers over a bed of wilted spinach and over dressed with sour, salty fish sauce. No peanuts or onions. It was not worth the $12 I paid. The waitress did not check up on us at all either. Oh well, yet another overpriced restaurant in the Castro that I will never frequent again. DERICIOUS! I've been here 3 times and each of those times was amazing! The service is great, the food is great and the ambiance is wonderful. I highly recommend the Finger Lickin. The combination of the fried chicken and crispy potato wedges dipped in their awesome curry sauce is oh so yummy! Also, the Wild King Salmon is great if you like a little more kick to your food. My friend first brought me here, then I brought my other friends, and they then brought their families! that's how you know it's good :DAlso, they give you complimentary sweet potato chips to nom nom on while waiting for your food! A+ I am a fan of the Millionaire's bacon and loved their deep fried french toast!  One of my very best friend is planning her wedding which will take place in 2013 so we decided to have brunch at Kitchen Story.  Unfortunately they don't take reservations for brunch on weekends but since we got there real early on a Sunday we were seated right away which was awesome! They served their iced teas in cute mason jars.  Service was great and the food arrived quickly.   I love the ambiance of the restaurant as well.  You definitely need to try the Millionaire's bacon and the deep fried french toast. Love this place and will return. food is absolutely mind blowing. So. Tantalizing. Service sucks, very abrupt and for the most part the staff has no idea what's in what. It seems as if they rely on the higher price points to determine their tip and don't care to engage. They need staff who have actually served before. But I keep going back though because the food is AMAZING! Have been here multiple times, and every time is delicious.Burger, tuna appetizer, and the curry were winners. After a rather disappointing car appointment at the dealership (which I will write a review about soon), my sister, mom, and I decided to venture in Castro to try this place for breakfast/brunch. My mom has been here before so she knew what to expect. Perfect timing as we beat the crowd before brunch time. Parking is not hard to find as long as you keep your San Franciscan eyes open and you know how to look for a parking spot as soon as a car pulls out. Ambiance is quite cozy and the server is gracious and friendly. I had the Frisco Benedict which was delicious, although I felt that the toasted bread, as opposed to the English muffin, was a bit heavy for my liking. The potatoes were great though. My sister's Ricotta Hotcakes was DELICIOUS! It reminded me of a mixture of Swedish and fluffy pancakes, only better! And finally my mom had the Athenian Omelet which had goat cheese and oh my God did it taste amazing.  To top it off, I found an even better tasting Millionaire's Bacon right here at this very same place! Yes, that's right folks. I found their Millionaire's bacon to be better than Sweet Maple's because it had a spicy kick to it. I loved loved loved their bacon. Will definitely take the BF here sometime soon. Happy eating! Really nice cafè with hip interiors. Californian/Asian cuisine is apparently a good mix - for breakfast, the eggs with rice and ribeye can be recommended, as well as the Thai Iced Thea - fresh, sweet and creamy. Review base on Brunch only.Was here for brunch with the hubs on a Sunday at 12:#0; and the wait was about 45 minutes.... but the host kept checking in with us which was nice.For Brunch we had:Crab panini - First 5 bites were good... tasty... creamy... and SUPER rich! After the first 5 bites... it was just blah... too cheezy and creamy for my taste.New England burger: Delish! It was really tasty with the millionaire's bacon and maple syrup wagyu patty!  I also enjoyed the pickles that came with the dishes... it's picked with star anise.Would want to come back here and try the dinner items.  Good service good food. Millionaire's Bacon #3, check!Came here for brunch on a Friday.  I was contemplating between the panini and the fried chicken.  I went with the fried chicken because it was under Mom's Special.  I guess cuz Mom's food is always special to the heart and the stomach?  I don't know...  Anyway, I was presented with a big bowl filled with the most crispiest wedges topped with a crispy chicken breast resembling a golden fish.  The millionaire's bacon did not disappoint, as usual. Sooo satisfied with everything! Came here with a friend around 11:30am. Having endured the lines at Mama's, Outerlands, Red Door, etc., I was mentally prepared for an hour+ wait, and we had a bit of pre-brunch to tide us over...much to our surprise and glee, we were seated at a table inside (thank goodness, because it would've been freezing at the non-heated tables outside) by noon. Points already.And the food was delicious. Unexpectedly the rainbow potatoes that came on the side of my Frisco Benedict might've been my favorite part - they were perfectly puffed up and so tasty! And included sweet potatoes, which is always preferable to normal potatoes...the chicken mango sausage on the benedict itself was very flavorful and it all went great with avocado, as so many things do. And I appreciate that the whole thing wasn't drowning in hollandaise, which was also lighter than I've had anyway. My only complaint was that they put it all over a small slice of levain bread, which was difficult to cut through and eat with the rest. Also the eggs could've been a little runnier for my tastes. Saturday brunch can always be really crazy with the long waits in SF. I've been here twice. When we got there we saw a really long line and thought that it would be a long wait. There's actually an Ike's next door, hence the wrap around line. We didn't make reservations and it was 4 of us. We only waited about 15 or 20 min. We shared everything family style. 1) Ribeye Omurice2) Mascarpone French Toast3) Pancakes4) Okonomiyaki Pancakes - favorite5) Green Tea Latte6) Millionaire Baconyelp.com/biz_photos/kitc…Everything was so yummy! It reminds me a bit of Blackwood in the Marina, Asian Fusion type of food. I think this is one of my new favorite brunch places in SF now. ^^ Millionaires bacon! must get! its kinda pricey but its very very good....$6 for 2 pieces or you can add it as a side to one of their entrees for $4....gotta try the mascarpone french toast! one of the best frrench toast i have ever had in the city.... Delicious! Every bite was amazing. We went for a weekday brunch so it was also low key, with great service. I love my morning melt--I loved it more because I can't eat eggs for breakfast and there's rarely a good savory option for me. But this had chicken sausage, roasted tomatoes and was bursting with flavor. The boyfriend had the ricotta pancakes which have been pronounced "best of the trip." So creamy! Too bad I really wanted to like this place!I had their BLT, which was pretty good. The bacon was sliced thick and so juicy, goes perfect with the fresh veggies and the bread. Waiters were polite and friendly too. HOWEVER, when I saw the bill, I was not happy... Including tip, it was $18 and I had ONLY BLT. Is it expensive lunch and I am not sure if it was worth it. (It's kinda hard to imagine what kind of BLT can be worth S18) If you are a deal seeker like me, this is not your place for sure. Outside, the metallic sign touts Kitchen Story as California cuisine, which is arguable. What I do know is that its fresh ingredients, colorful presentation, and creative concepts are executed well and does Asian fusion justice. The new interior has the typical trendy theme of rustic wood tables + metallic trimmings, low hanging lamps over a bar, and the recently popular bookshelf decor (with real books). It's well-ventilated with bay windows and was a peaceful place for brunch for one. Deep Fried French Toast: It's made with ciabatta bread which you don't see often, but it provides a great crunchy exterior and a soft airy interior! Basically two pieces of ciabatta sandwiches the mascarpone cream and is then deep fried. I'm a big fan of deep fried Monte Cristos, french toast, and the like because it encases the filling inside neatly and you never have to worry about it falling out. In this case, the structure was a lot like a cream filled donut. It came with a generous portion of fresh berries and maple syrup. Frisco benedict - I had to get the city's name sake even though no one calls it Frisco if they're from here. It came with this amazing mango sausage patty and freshly sliced avocado. The eggs were small, definitely not your large or jumbo sized eggs, but it looked cute. I find most hollandaise sauces heavy, but their meyer lemon hollandaise was probably the most fantastic thing about this dish. I also loved the side of home fries it came with, they were called rainbow potatoes and consisted of: potatoes, purple potatoes, and sweet potatoes. It's one of those perfectly fried potato sides that people rave about, especially the sweet potato home fries!The service was very attentive and they replaced my fork immediately when I dropped it. They also informed us in great detail about each dish when we inquired. This is quite the neighborhood gem in Mission. Excellent restaurant!  A MUST for any foodie!  This is a quaint restaurant situated on a corner in the Castro District of San Francisco.  Our party of four had drinks, appetizers, dinner and two desserts, all of which totaled approximately $50.00.  Good food does NOT have to be expensive! We came here for the french toast.  We tried both versions that were on the menu but they turned out to be somewhat disappointing.  But if you're here - definitely try the millionaire's bacon! I love lazy Sunday!!  My bf and I had brunch here on Sunday. We got there around 11am and the wait wasn't too bad. We waited for 10-15 min for an inside table. My bf ordered a Classic Benedict ( Mom's Benedict) and I ordered 2 eggs with Chicken Mango ( instead they give me 2 eggs with applewood smoke bacon), also, we ordered a side of millionaire bacon. I found my scramble eggs look very interesting. Instead of scramble eggs style, my scramble eggs was in a omelet style. The eggs were very fluffy and light. Despite the fact that I got smoke bacon instead of apple mango, they mixed the bacon with potato wedge and onion and lots cheddar cheeses. It was way too cheesy. Other wise, it was good!. My bf's Benedict was definitely different compared to the traditional ones. Where there are Hollandaise sauce on top on the poached eggs. The millionaire bacon were good. savory, sweet   and thick slice cut.  I'm not a big fan of bacon but millionaire bacon make me have a second  thoughts . Definitely would go back again to try the other items on the menu. Millionaires bacon is so good! I got the scallops wrapped in bacon on ciabatta bread sandwich, seriously incredible! Had breakfast here on a Saturday, arrived at 9am, no wait. Noticed that the place had started to fill up by 10, although all the outside tables were mostly empty. Menu for breakfast is very good - not too long, variety, and most of the items have twists that give a new taste to many traditional breakfast choices. Food - I had the Frisco Benedict with sausage and avocado. Very good and perfectly prepared. Note that many of the dishes come with potatoes as a side; that can mean many things, so if you're curious, at Kitchen Story it was small cut crispy potatoes.Coffee - strong and rich. Service - friendly and efficient.Atmosphere - Clean, renovated space. Didn't get too loud despite filling up. Nice, lively local crowd. Tool Factor - LOW. No fedoras in sight. No hipsters taking photos of their food instead of talking to their friends. No inappropriate cell phone users (you know who you are).Oh, and yes, the M's bacon is fantastic - sweet, savory, and a little peppery kick at the end. GET THE BLT!!!!Best BLT I've ever had. Hands down. I can never try anything else on the menu ever again because I can't risk it not being as good as the BLT. Otherwise, good salad, fries, a tad slow on the service, but who cares -- the food is awesome! Finding a brunch place in the city without a wait is impossible. My parents were in town with 4 of their friends so I had to find a place for brunch that would accommodate a party of 9. I had many choices, but I settled for Kitchen Story. I've had it bookmarked for some time and I was dying to dry the Millionaire Bacon. My parents got here around 9:30 and surprisingly there was no wait. Only half our party was here, but they were still willing to sit us anyways. I was very surprised considering how packed they get. Everything here is very appealing to the eye from decor to the presentation of the food. I normally stay away from sweet breakfast options, but I was very impressed by their mascarpone stuffed deep fried french toast. It was very light and non-oily; my dad compared it to a Chinese donut. The portions were also perfect. I was full after my meal, but not TOO full where I couldn't eat anything the rest of the day. I would definitely be coming back here again. Side story on the Millionaire Bacon. I first heard about this place because of my coworker and I quote:"I normally don't like bacon, at all. But I went to Kitchen Story and tried the Millionaire Bacon and was dreaming about it at night. Really."Truth. Pay the extra $7 and complete your meal with a side of Millionaire Bacon and some eggs. We were here for a conference and stopped by this restaurant based on a recommendation. The food was amazing. Inventive - creative - great flavors. The ONLY downside is that it took forever to get our food. I think dinner took almost 2.5 hours... But the food is worth the wait. Next time we are in SF, Kitchen Story is a must. A surprising find in the Castro/Mission. I didn't expect it to be so good. I would have given them 5 stars but just a tiny issue with one of dishes, so this is 4.5 stars review.First off, excellent and friendly service. Such a cute little place too. Make sure you make reservations as they fill out fast on the Friday we were there. I guess the food is Asian Fusion. But the only thing you have to know is they have Millionaire's Bacon LOL. Don't be a dummy.. order this appetizer. It's spectacular. We also ordered the Castro tower of ahi tuna which was really good.They have so many good and yummy menu items that I could not choose one! I really wanted the Monterey Muscle scallops burger wrapped in Millionaire's bacon but my partner ordered it aaaghh! It was, not surprisingly, excellent. I ended up ordering Finger Lickin' fried chicken breasts. This is where my tiny issue comes up. The batter they use for the chicken was just not good and quite greasy. Everything on the plate was salty so combined made it taste more salty than it really is. Except for the cucumber salad which was sweet, but the coconut curry for dipping was also salty. Add the potato wedges and it's way too much salt. I actually felt a tiny pain in my tummy maybe from salt attack! I suggest they change the dipping sauce to something sweeter perhaps? A fruit jam? Peanut sauce? Then that dish would be perfection. This is really a minor complaint because other than that it was a fine dish. Overall though we loved our experience at Kitchen Story. Reasonable prices and outstanding food (great presentation also).  Maybe next time we'll just order small plates like the table next to us did because their appetizers all look amazing. We would not hesitate to come back. I came here for brunch on a Saturday. They do not take reservations during brunch so I came in around 1045. The wait wasn't too long, maybe 10-15 at most. While my friend and I waited we started off with bottomless mimosas. They are not skimpy on the champagne so good enough for me! I ordered the mascarpone stuffed deep fried French Toast and am soooo glad I did. The crunchy shell was the right amount without feeling like I'm gnawing on jerky. The mascarpone on the inside was a delightful addition. It gave a nice, gooey consistency and a good contrast with the fried shell. The two slices of bread were easily an inch thick so thank you for that. =) I could have poured that maple syrup on everything on my plate. Lol I went with the meal so also had scrambled eggs and bacon. The eggs were fluffy and had a creamy center so definitely delish. And you can't go wrong with bacon. I would definitely come back again to try the other items on the menu. I am giving Kitchen Story a 5 star (great food and good service).  This is my current favorite restaurant and is reasonably priced.  I have been here for lunch and had to come back another time to sample their dinner menu.  My favorite is the Ahi Scoops (sesame crusted tuna with spicy seaweed, crispy yam, ginger and wasabi cream sauce) - the combination of flavor was bursting in your mouth!  Millionaire Bacon is a must try and so is the Spicy Kobe Rolls.   Hop on over to the Kitchen Story and enjoy your Asian Fusion experience :-). Favorite new little spot in the Mission! Kitchen Story has everything I look for in a great go-to spot:- Consistently delicious food - they offer Asian-fusion done right. FINALLY, a place that gets it! (also check out The House for a fantastic weekend lunch menu)- Easy seating on weekday nights, although I'd recommend making reservations on weekends- BRUNCH!! GOOD BRUNCH!- Decent service- Reasonable prices. Approximately $25-$30 per head if you eat like a normal person- Warm, cozy interior. Like someone's comfortable living room- A few blocks away from Chile Pies, which is one of the greatest dessert places ever. Kitchen Story probably has a delicious dessert menu as well; I just haven't gotten around to trying it.Some delicious items worthy of note:- CASTRO TOWER!!! Lots of delicious spices on yummy chunks of tuna and avocado, served with crispy chips. This is the item that keeps us coming back- Love their curries - they are maybe a bit on the sweet side but the fatty American inside of me likes it that way. Preferably ordered with a side of rice.- Anything served with rice. This is an odd thing to point out, but their rice is REALLY good (coming from a girl that grew up eating rice every night). The white rice is soft and fluffy and if you're feeling adventurous, you should try the ginger rice. Very aromatic - similar to the rice served with Taiwanese Hainan chickenDon't be shy - try whatever sounds good on the menu. I have yet to be disappointed with this place :) The best story here is that the Castro finally has a quality restaurant that is open for breakfast, lunch AND dinner I have been here a few times and it is always a great experience. Come hungry because these meals will fill up even the biggest appetite. To date my favorite dishes are the short rib omurice (sp) and the hot pot.  The coffee alone is worth coming for. Strong and fresh. I'm going back with a group Thursday for  dinner and I am looking forward to trying something new. The restaurant is well designed, has a 100% score from the health department, has an innovative menu and a great staff. It may be priced slightly higher than some restaurants but it is a cut above most neighborhood establishments. One big happy ending for this Kitchen Story. Very Crowded Sunday brunch. We sat at the bar in front of the heat lamps. This gave us a good view of the kitchen and prep areas. Décor was nice and new looking. Bottomless mimosas are truly bottomless. They did not hesitate to give us more each time. (some places in my experience get stingy after a couple of refills) I had the 2 eggs with the cheddar melt potato's. The dish was good, but the potato's were excellent. Mushrooms, and bacon made it sooo good. My friends and I went here yesterday for Brunch and this was my first time here.  And you know the saying.." good 1st impression"?? well, i wasnt impressed.  It took our food more than half hour to arrive!. My eggs werent fully cooked, glad i didnt get sick.  At least not yet...And when our food finally arrived, my food was cold, they miss-placed one of my friends food or the cook did not get his order. He also ordered a side dish of the famous M. bacon, which came first before anyone else' food arrived (weird).  So, we were all waiting for our food to arrive while the bacon sat there $6.50 and all, and got cold and chewy!  $6.50 for 2 pieces of bacon?? REally?? it was good but not that good!  With all that being said, our bill came and they charged my credit card 3x, with different charges! ugh...Not sure if i will go back here again. Like i said my 1st impression wasnt good at all!...and that is My Story! Food = good.  Had their ricotta pancakes with millionaire's bacon.  Millionaire's bacon = heart attack on a plate.  *heart cloggedPrices = moderateService = friendly, efficientBottomless mimosas = awesome and perfect start to my birthday!  $16/ppReservations = get 'em! Overall, I'd be back for brunch or dinner!  Dinner sounds awesome! I love brunch and I love Asian fusion, so Kitchen Story already won me over by combining the two. The atmosphere is extremely pleasant, and the decor has a homey, California feel.I had the mascarpone stuffed deep fried French toast. Typically, I am not a huge fan of deep fried foods, but I decided to give it a try! French toast is one of those foods that you can do so much to, so I was curious as to how this would turn out. It came with one big hunk of French toast that was stuffed with a creamy, but not too sweet mascarpone. The batter on the outside was slightly too much for my taste, but it wasn't oily at all. The fresh fruit and light mascarpone actually paired well with the heavier crust. It reminded me of a donut, but with higher quality and developed flavors.My boyfriend had the ribeye omurice, which was so unique and absolutely delicious. It's rare to find fried rice that isn't greasy and heavy, but they made it perfectly here. The ribeye and veggies in the rice were plentiful, so the ratio of rice to toppings was about even. The scrambled eggs on top were so fluffy, and the quantity was large enough to pair every bite of fried rice with egg. It came with a butter croissant and rainbow potatoes that were both really tasty. There is so much more that I want to try here after my first trip. Kitchen Story is definitely a must-try, classic San Francisco spot! This place was ok--- the decor and ambiance is nice, and it's in a nice neighborhood.  We had good service. The place was extremely loud though, and I had to raise my voice across the table just to talk which wasn't so pleasant.  The thing is--- the food is a bit expensive, and this whole "asian fusion" thing is starting to seem like a gimmick to me.   A lot of their menu was not really fusion at all--- it was  traditional thai food like yellow/green/red/panang curries, thai noodle dish (pad thai), and thai cocunut soup (tom kha) which they called Mama coconut soup or something like that.... and that is OK but I can get great authentic Thai food for cheaper.  Why go to some fancy asian fusion restaurant to get authentic thai dishes with no fusion spin on them?  Where's the fusion?The red curry shrimp--- we asked for medium spice, and it was extremely spicy. I like Indian food and spicy food, but this was a bit much. I think we counted 5 shrimps, which ended up beign 2 shrimp for me when sharing it with my gf.  That was dissapointing, for a $16 curry plate.  That left me with a bunch of sauce and some zucchini.The short-rib tacos were pretty good--- they came LOADED with short-rib meat  and it had some nice mango salsa and kimchi stuff.  The meat was flavorful and good, but $16 for 3 tacos is really expensive.The coconut milk soup was decent, but everything was overpriced and I enjoy getting my Tom Kha even more from my local thai spots like Thep Phanom or Marnee Thai and I don't have to pay so much for them, especially since the soup was nothing out of the ordinary.So ya... It was ok, but the menu is not too special and it's really expensive for regular Asian food. Stopped in at 9 for a lighter fare dinner at the bar. Saw some great stuff coming through the pass. Ordered coconut milk soup, large bowl, medium heat. Just perfect, except twice what I could eat, and for $12, wow great., Chicken was shredded, not diced, onions were obviously pre cooked so they could just be added to the serving at the last minute. Heat just right. My wife had calamari ceviche. Not ceviche, I am sure the squid was quickly poached. Great fish sauce dressing, nice hunk of avocado.  Great spot, open 6 months, need to go back to try more dishes. I was super excited to come and try Kitchen Story for the first time a month ago. I had friends visiting from New York, and thought this would be an appropriate place to have a nice, quiet, sit-down dinner. Although the food was delicious, I didn't appreciate the waiter lying about your mussels being scallops. I ordered mussels and the waiter brought out scallops??? I questioned him, and he proceeded to tell me in broken English that your mussels are scallops? I'm not stupid...and know what the differences are between mussels and scallops. I'm disappointed that the waiter just didn't admit he got my order wrong and fabricated a lie to cover his mistake. I'll come back to Kitchen Story, but have to read the fine print next time. This restaurant exceeded my expectations. After seeing the long lines for Sunday brunch, I was wondering what was the draw to Kitchen Story.  When I looked at the menu, it didn't seem that impressive.]Several weeks later, I made a lunch reservation for a large group. They we able to sit all of us at the time.   The food and drinks were right on par.  Mind you, we all ordered the bottomless mimosas.I shared the fried chicken and the pancakes.  The fried chicken was fried crispy and was tasty.   The pancake, were a disappointment.   The entire dish was a mess fry.No Pun!Overall come for the fried chicken. It is the bomb. Ignore the rest. I've tried to like this place by visiting twice and I'm just not very impressed.  Plus, waiting 10 minutes for a cup of coffee before taking my order is just pretty slow service in general.  It wasn't crowded and it literally took 10 minutes to get water and coffee. Just sayin'... This place is freaking amazeballs. Yes, I said amazeballs! No elaboration needed, just order everything. But you might be looking for some suggestions, so here:Ribeye Omurice-Japanese-style fried rice with ribeye and veggies topped with scrambled eggs and crispy baked rainbow potatoes on the side. I licked the plate. Seriously, licked it right after I scarfed down the buttery and flaky croissant. Mascarpone Stuffed French Toast-Deep fried and stuffed with mascarpone, topped with butter and fresh berries. Really, not enough of a sell? You are crazy.Tilapia Burger-The tilapia filet was juicy and cooked perfectly. Mango salsa could've been the perfect compliment if the potato wedges weren't so damn good.BEC Melt-Bacon, eggs, melted cheddar.. Done. The must, MUST get... Millionaire's bacon. This will change your life. Thick cut bacon with maple syrup glaze. It is worth that $6.50 in your wallet. If I had the means, I would most definitely buy a plane ticket to SF just to eat here. Yes, amazeballs. Went there on a Sunday for brunch and I must say I'm really happy with my decision. The place was packed with a long line outside but being alone I was immediately seated at the bar. I ordered the poached eggs Frisco Benedict and a side of the Millionaire Bacon. Both items are really delicious, yet not a good combination. My bad. The staff was busy but friendly and never rushing so I felt comfortable and welcome the whole time. All in all, I'll be back for more delicious Asian fusion brunch items. Bumped up a star to match the food.  Went back for brunch and the fruit flies were gone.  Were able to get a nice table next to the window and the peeps know this place is good because it was packed even though it was drizzling outside!  So yay! I'm a fan.  And millionaire bacon still rocks it out. We arrived exactly at 7:30 pm for a 7:30 reservation and had to wait fifteen minutes to be seated.  Another party of four was lingering.  The staff apologized.  That said, the service was otherwise exemplary and the food was delicious.  It was my third time eating at this restaurant.  All of the curries are extremely good.  We finally tried the Millionaire's appetizer, and the combination of thick bacon, asparagus, and maple syrup sauce was a treat for the taste buds.  Our out-of-town guests just raved about the food.  Meredith W. It's Sunday morning brunch.  You're sitting at Kitchen Story for the very first time, and you wonder to yourself, "Yelpers of the world, what should I fill my stomach with this beautiful morning?"  The right answer: Millionaire's bacon, but of course.  Thick slices of maple syrup-drenched bacon that's been sitting in the oven for hours at a time?  Yes please.  If you're looking for 'a real meal,' get the red & green benedict.  It's a delicious and healthy option to balance out your please-feed-me-more bacon consumption.  Enjoy. It's a great spot for breakfast. Today was my 2nd visit. This time I took the whole family. 2 adults and 3 kids. Staff was very accommodating. And the food was great. I got the KS own omelet and added avocado. My wife got the Franciscan scramble and my oldest son got the wonderful Mascarpone stuffed deep fried french toast and the two little ones got the Mickey Mouse pancakes. Good size portions. We were hungry from running a 5 k earlier in the morning.  We will return soon! With a complete makeover from being Tangerine, this is what the area needed. Something that was unique, with good flavors, good service and interesting but approachable food. Kitchen Story got it right. The food is fresh, with good flavors/spices, and the service is responsive and appreciative. They are truly glad you are there and they let you know in the way they provide for you. Outdoor seating or indoor with a nice selection to choose from. Have the short rib tacos as they are my staple here! Their wine choices are good both by the glass and the bottle. Very pleased that they have brought some good food back to the Castro area. Once upon a time, Kitchen Story opened. It made extremely delicious dishes, such as the Franciscan Scramble. Now, the Franciscan Scramble, that darling dish, was a pretty mixture of fluffy egg scramble, chicken mango, pimento, mushroom, celery, and oozing jack cheese. But beware of its deceivingly small and light appearance - the most innocent ones are generally the heavy-duty, protein packing fillers that make you want to chase after dragons for exercise.And if that wasn't enough, The Franciscan Scramble is accompanied with the captain of butter croissants and the squires of delicious - I emphasize once again, DELICIOUS - mix of rainbow potatoes: Potatoes, Taro, Sweet Yam perhaps? Worthy of being knighted.The tiny swords, tridents, and spatulas provided at the table may sometimes be of short supply. And the wait for the army of food may be a little treacherously long, coming out in random spurs to your party of eaters. You might end up watching your companion defeat the opponent first before you even begin your own battle.Nevertheless, a story worth telling. I always pass this place on Sunday on my way to my weekend job and there is always a line in front. So this Monday a bunch of us decided to try this place out for lunch and see what the hype was about.My partner and I decided to split the ricotta cheese pancake entrée and a separate fried chicken entrée. They didn't have chicken and waffles, so this would be the next best thing.  I was very impressed with the flavor of the fried chicken. It had a spicy batter that gave it quite the kick. We all had bottomless mimosas which helped move the day along nicely.I would recommend they add chicken and waffles to the menu. That would be a winner. Great ambiance  great service and great food. Happened on it by chance and just loved my delicious red curry. Will definitely visit again. Thai probably main influence but some of the dishes served were like works of art. The lady who had the position of maitre'd was charming and advised me on the preparation of my dish. Thanks for a lovely experience. Wow! What a great restaurant for so many reasons. The dinner menu has great options, portions are large, and all very reasonably priced. Two of us had dinner reservations on the Saturday night of the SF Pride weekend. The restaurant was very busy, and our table was not ready, even though we had reservations. The host was very apologetic, and offered to buy us each a drink while we waited. It turns out he was the owner, and what a great way to lead-by-example for his staff. The restaurant has a very welcoming feel, like you are eating in someone's dining room. And the menu is filled with comfort food. We were so impressed that we came back for breakfast! Another WOW! This will be a place that I return to each time I visit the city. I had a burger here, called the "burgah boy". I sat at the bar forever waiting for my food. I saw burger after burger go by, each time praying that it was my own. When it finally arrived, it was a bit blander than I expected. Regardless, it was absolutely wonderful watching all the beautiful food go by. They really know how to make food look good here. I'm sure much of it is also quite delicious. I really wanted to give this place more stars but I think the only reason that I am not is because the service was not very good. The food came out in a timely manner but none of the servers here are very attentive. Anytime we needed something we had to grab them when they walked by and even after asking for something, they would start to walk away before we were done speaking. The bus boy and host were actually the most talkative and friendly of the staff. I think they should be moved to the wait staff. Okay now on to the food which was the saving grace of our experience. I ordered the California burger because of my obsession with goat cheese and it was pretty good however very messy and drippy. My sister and girl friend both had a sandwich and they were also very messy but I tried them and the flavors were spot on. My mom unfortunately found a very long hair in her eggs and was turned off to further eating. Prior to her discovery though I was able to try her bacon and it was YUM!! Like an explosion of maple in your mouth. So good I wished that I had added a side of bacon to my order.So long story short I would definitely return but would expect to have very stand offish service. I can deal with that if the food is good and here it definitely is. So, it's kind of Thai, kind of New American fusion, kind of modern, kind of traditional.  In case you haven't heard, the thing you must get here is the Millionaire's Bacon.  Extra thick and juicy, and they coat it with something a little sugary.  Money.  Now if you come for breakfast (served 8am-3pm), the thing you want from that menu is the "Belly Rancheros," with Kurobuta pork, which for some reason has not yet triggered a Yelp Review Highlight. My buddy ordered it, and seeing its massive size was planning to eat half of it.  Then we each tasted it.  Holy crap, so good: rich fatty pork with that (not actually spicy) "5 spice flavor" that you get at lots of Asian fusion places.  He ate the whole thing, it was that good.Also, if you come for dinner: from the Thai items, the Pumpkin Curry is baller!  And Mom's Coconut soup is like a really good Tom Kha. Wish I could give 4.5 - the marscapone stuffed & fried french toast was simply the best - WOW - covered in berries and syrup (our add to it), it was heaven sent - started the meal with that along with Millionaires Bacon - the bacon was nice and meaty, good sweet to spice balance and if you love bacon, you'll love it here.  Then we moved on to entries - had the Benedict served atop crusty baquette which delicious - potatoes were nice (might have just quick fried them too to get that crunch).  Highly recommend brunch here I think generally this is a pretty good place in a great cozy space. If you're looking for pretension or the latest trends in food, which are a ridiculous way to review any location, unless it considers itself among the latest trends, then you're going to be disappointed, and you should move along. This place has an eclectic menu; perhaps the drink menu could use some sprucing up, and the servers could be a little more attentive, but overall it is an above-average experience and well-priced.On our recent visit to the Castro we met friends of ours who live nearby and suggested this place. It was not busy (about 30 percent full) for a lazy Sunday evening, and we were seated right away. The server seemed a little overwhelmed with only four tables, but unlike our recent "could-care-less" service experience at Harvey's nearby, he was at least trying. What he lacked in mental faculties he more than made up for in hustle, so he deserves some credit. I think he needs to learn the menu a little better, but perhaps he was new. Nevertheless, he wasn't awful, and he was engaging. (For those of you who remember "Mad About You" in the mid to late 1990s, think Ursula, Phoebe from Friends's sister.)For starters, we ordered the calamari. Nothing impressive but also nothing unimpressive. Only drawback for me was the size of the sauce that accompanied the plate: It was completely disportionate, on the small side. The calamari itself had a nice flavors.Our buddies, "E" & "J," each had a beer, as did I. My hubby wasn't drinking that evening. Being I wanted to try something I can't get in Chicago, I tried the Red Tail Ale from Mendocino. Decent beer. "J" ordered a beer, Big Eye IPA, that about ten minutes later, when we "reminded" the server of our drink order, we found out they did not have. He finally got the Red Tail as well. Again, nothing great but absolutely satisfactory. For dinner, "J" and I both ordered the Castro Sea. A very good dish. It is listed as medium-hot, but I'd call it medium. Definitely had a good flavor and plenty of seafood, along with avocado, and the curry was not heavy at all, just enough to give the dish the "pop" it needed. I definitely would have it again, and "J" agreed, and I would recommend it.My hubby had the "Burgah" Boy, their version of a burger. He really liked it. He must have. I remember seeing it when they sat it down, but ten minutes later when I asked him what he had, he told me, and from his empty plate he really enjoyed it. He never, ever, ever finishes his plate, and he never finishes before me. (He's always telling me to take human bites and that might food is not going to run off my plate.) For him to eat a dish that quickly, and completely, tells me the dish is worth a recommendation. I'm pescatarian, so I didn't try it, and even if I would have attempted I think I would have a few less fingers today. While some reviewers on here have castigated the way the dish is stacked, I think it works for this dish. Again, if you're all about trendy pretension, ask for it deconstructed, but remember this is a dining experience, not a Top Chef episode."E" had the Pad Thai, and he said it was worth getting. He's a big eater but took plenty home.Again, there's no pretension in this place. It is what it is, and what it is, to me, is a very good dining experience. Did it have its hiccups? Of course. However, were those excusable for the overall experience? Absolutely. Like I said earlier, if you're expecting a burger by Tom Coliccio or to be greeted and seated by Padma Lakshmi, this ain't your place. But if you want a meal that's appropriately priced, full of flavor, and portioned appropriately, this is your place. It just felt comfortable, and that goes a long way for me. Definitely recommend. A great spot for a date! Had dinner with my boyfriend a few days back, very glad we made a reservation because it was quite busy.Starters were excellent-,we had the Ahi Scoops which were super tasty and fresh. The samosas were a bit different than we had expected, the dough was quite thick, but good nonetheless.For mains we had the fried chicken and the  beef salad. Both full of flavor and nicely portioned. Atmosphere is classy as well as romantic but still quite trendy and hip. Very reasonably priced and would love to go again and try other unique creations they have! First impressions are lasting impressions.  i had an eggs benedict dish at about 11:30 on a weekday.  Restaurant was not very busy, but the hollandaise was cold and the eggs were hard, not runny as poached eggs should be. I heard so many good things about this place, but.... LOVE LOVE LOVE. This is the place to go for a hearty Sunday funday brunch with a touch of Asian. Perfectly poached eggs. Omurice! Bottomless mimosas! And, I usually don't care too much for the potatoes that come with brunch plates, but the rainbow potatoes here are so delicious! Perfectly crispy and a combination of purple yam, regular yams, sweet potatoes. Unlike any old fashion brunch joint, Kitchen's Story is clean, organized and have a less than ordinary menu. Their food is very delicious and quite inspiring. I had the Chicken Mango Melt, and to this day, I'm still thinking about it every morning. Gosh I can eat this every morning or lunch or whenever. The chicken mango sausages was so delicious and not salty at all like typical breakfast sausages. Layered in between the breads were spinach, tomato and cheese...can't get better combo than that in my book! Ahhh. I want some now. I also tried the Million Dollar Bacon. The dish comes with two thicker cut bacons with maple syrup and some chili peppers. Gosh, I don't even like bacons, but this bacon totally just kill my "I don't like bacon" era. I swear I could eat plates of this if I want to. I was also checking out my friends' plates, and they all look very appetizing, even the one with just scramble eggs and sausage on it. How do you they make something so simple so pretty and appetizing? The scrambled eggs look super fluffy...like super fluffy! I swear I want to learn their secrets to their dish so I can make myself some.All in all, their food get my thumbs up. Service was just okay though, maybe because they were busy or something. But bottomless mimosa takes forever to refill, and we have to keep asking for it...same with water, iced tea, etc. I was surprisingly unimpressed.  The menu is a mix of 1990s-era California fusion (think vertically stacked dishes; raw tuna and fried wonton chips) and pan-Asian dishes.  We had three of the "California" dishes to start:Tuna "spoons" that were fine, but overcooked (I expected them to be raw, and they were really cooked through, which is a waste of good tuna), and effectively tuna poke (good quality raw tuna, but overseasoned).  The third appetizer was "grilled" (tasted and looked sauted) eggplant rounds over a thing of fried goat cheese.  It was a bit too greasy, and there was only three anemic pieces of eggplant for a big chunk of goat cheese.  The whole dish needed an extra texture, and a lot more eggplant.  Overall, nothing bad, but they were all $12 each, which was not warranted.  For main courses, we all had various of the Asian dishes.  I had what would normally be called tom ka gai soup.  It was a large portion, and satisfying enough, but certainly not better than at any ordinary hole-in-the-wall Thai place.  If I closed my eyes, ignored the branding, it'd taste like a normal $6 bowl of soup.  It said organic chicken in the description, and I bet they used better ingredients generally, I simply could not tell.Service was not so good; they messed up one dish (made the wrong curry; we could have sent it back, but decided it wasn't worth the trouble), didn't know who ordered what, served the wrong side dish with one main course, were confused on the appetizer order, and were hard to find to get the check.  At least they refilled the water frequently.Overall: Everything was reasonable, but not worth any price premium over a basic cheap restaurant.  Their burger looked killer though, and I'll probably give them one more try to check it out. I read that Kitchen Story comes from the same makers of Sweet Maple in Pac Heights. I haven't tried Sweet Maple, but my foodie friend Vivian H says it's similar in mediocrity so I guess if you like Sweet Maple you'd like Kitchen Story. * Ribeye Omurice - 2 STARS ($14): scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry pepper, spinach, scallion. Demi glazed sauce. This sounded so amazing and was featured in the paper. It tasted like low quality margarine sprinkled with a bit of low quality beef. It didn't taste Japanese in the slightest. It kind of tasted like airplane food.* Mascarpone stuffed deep fried French toast - 2 STARS ($10): This looked and sounded so good, I had to order it. Unfortunately, it tasted more like an overly deep fried funnel cake, very dry and filled with a low quality overly sweet marscapone cheese that would ruin even the best funnel cake.* Ricotta Hot Cakes - 2 STARS ($10): Perhaps I am not a fan of ricotta pancakes because I didn't like the mushy texture here or at Plow. Eh.* Millionaire's Bacon - 3 STARS ($6.50): I don't really understand the hype around millionaire's bacon, personally it's way too sweet. I guess you could call this the highlight of the meal, an item the owner claims to make the lowest profit margins on. I'd recommend upgrading your meal for $7 to get the eggs and millionaire's bacon (seeing as the bacon side is $6.50 alone).Kitchen Story, Pomelo, Tangerine were huge Asian Fusion brunch disappointments for me; the Mission needs to step up their game. If you're looking for fusion brunch, the owners did a much better job at Blackwood (Thai Fusion WITH amazing happy hour) in the Marina. The food is very good. Overall definitely worth a visit! I edited my review and updated to 5, there is nothing to complain! Cute little place, cozy ambience, superb + tentative service. Two girls, we ordered: mango salad with prawns - fresh but tad too sour; dancing queen (seems like a normal beef and green bean dish) and wagyu noodles. Everything was really tasty but also a bit heavy handed on the salt, its 2 hours after dinner and i'm still thirty as heck. Overall solid eating out options. Would come back to try their super popular brunch menu however =) This was the most fantastic meal that I have had in a while!! I picked this place out of the blue while I was looking for a place to celebrate Dad's day, and I am so glad that I did. This was AMAZING!Starters: Since it was so highly spotlighted on the menu we had to start with the Millionaire's Way bacon. It was thick, sweet tender and oh-so-tasty! It's served on a bed of asparagus and split three ways it gave us enough of a taste. I loved it. We took our 5-year old here and while they have a children's menu, he opted to order off the regular menu. The server was really respectful to our son which I like because often restaurants completely ignore him and expect me to order for him. Instead he took his order and that always makes our son extra happy. For our main meal he had:Mango Salad with Grilled Tiger Prawns - He dove into this salad with enthusiasm and said he really enjoyed it. I tried it as well and it was bursting with flavor. It was a big portion for a kid (actually all of the portions here are on the large side), but he ate quite a bit. I get to take the rest for lunch :-)Castro Sea - I love seafood and I love curry so I opted for this dish, sans green peppers. The table next to me ordered it as well and when I saw it come out I was already salivating. The fish was all cooked perfectly and I really enjoyed all of the different textures. There were crispy noodles, avocados, crisp peppers and soft basil. The sauce was creamy and spicy. I was in love!Grilled Wagyu Beef Noodle Soup - Hubby chose this and the server brought out a giant bowl of beef, noodles and broth. The noodles were soft but chewy, the beef was tender and the broth was spicy and bit salty which I loved. I wanted to eat his meal too! Lucky for us we each had leftovers so I know I can enjoy it tomorrow.I am not usually a big dessert fan and only want to try a bite or two, but today I had the (seasonal) mango and sticky rice and I was literally licking the bowl. I liked it so much I want to get a take-away order of it tomorrow! The cubed mango was served over a warm coconut rice and it was the perfect way to end our meal. I left the restaurant asking "when can we come back?"We were seated in front of the kitchen so I got to see a lot of the meals coming out and truthfully they all looked good. I really want to come back to try the fried chicken which looked amazing and since fried chicken is my favorite food, I am sure I will love it. Our neighbors ordered the Summer String Bean appetizer and they looked good too. So much to try! I might need to come here every day!! Came for a late brunch, left satiated with a smile, and didn't want to eat anything else for the rest of the day because the food was so delicious!My partner and I came for Sunday brunch at around 1:30pm.  Our first time.  It was busy, but they were able to seat us immediately if we sat at the bar, which we did.  The seating outside looked super cute, and I totally would have done that if it weren't for the wind today.  Next time!The service was great, everyone was so pleasant and attentive, but so efficient at the same time, with no hovering.The food was absolutely delicious, especially for the price!  We got the red and green poached eggs (which was to die for, perfectly cooked, with whole, rainbow pearl potatoes, and a mushroom/tomato/spinach mixture that had my mouth water with every bite.  I got the mango salsa on the side.  Next time, it will not be on the side, but right on top of the dish since it was so yummy!We also had the marscapone hotcakes.  WOW.  I loved these!  Not too thick, perfect portion of three, the batter was delightful with a hint of sweetness from the cheese and orange rind, so all you needed was just a few little drizzles of syrup, rather than having to douse the whole thing to get flavor.Anyway, seriously loved this place, and can't wait to come back for brunch again! I absolutely love this place, and I've never even been inside.What I mean is, weekend brunches with the dog is one my favorite things in the world, so outdoor seating at a restaurant is usually a must. I've been here a couple of times, always for weekend brunch, and always seated outside. Even the time we came here and all of the outdoor tables were taken, it was no problem. The staff immediately pulled out a table from the restaurant and created new seating right then and there. Service doesn't get any better than that.Other restaurants will completely forget about their outdoor patrons, but the staff were so attentive and friendly checking on our table and refilling our waters every twenty minutes. The food was phenomenal; I highly recommend the New England Burger and Mascarpone Deep Fried French Toast. All in all, one of my favorite brunch places in the area, and I can't wait to devour the remaining dishes on the menu. I've been here a few times and I've really enjoyed each visit.  The place is very cozy, the portions are large and everything is made rich and flavorful.  For Brunch the Millionaire's bacon was definitely the highlight.  Describing it as thick bacon drenched in maple syrup doesn't even properly describe just how good it is.  As for their dinner menu, the appetizers were all solid and very flavorful, although it seems they .  I was really pleased with the Pad Thai, it had more vegetables than I was expecting and the Tofu was perfect.  I am confused why this was labelled as California cuisine.  It felt far closer to an Asian fusion restaurant. The good:The food! The presentation, quality, and flavors of the dishes were very good. The predominantly Asian cuisine was served on attractive, modern dishes and the chef put a lot of effort into the design and appearance of the food. A very appealing juxtaposition of flavors, colors, and textures, and the quality of the food was excellent. We asked our server for recommendations and she did a great job pointing out and describing a few of her favorites on the menu. We were glad we took her advice! We wished that we had been a bit more careful in choosing distinctive dishes, though, as our appetizers were very similar and shared over 50% of their ingredients. They did a great job with the interior design. It looks clean, modern, and inviting, more luxurious than Tangerine. The not-so-good:The place advertises itself as California Cuisine - right on the marquis - but it is not California cuisine. It's pretty much straight up Asian from the design and language of the menu down to the ingredients and the presentation. False advertising!The front of the house needs serious training. The tables were all set incorrectly with the napkin on the right, and the wait staff seemed generally confused and unorganized. A busser took away parts of my appetizer from my plate while I was in the middle of the dish, and there were a lot of interruptions. Also, when they removed our first course dishes they put our dirty silverware right onto the table, which is gross and surprising for such an expensive place. Which leads to the other big thing, the cost. Two apps, two entrees, and two glasses of wine was $120 including tip. About 25% too expensive for what it is, I'd say, and more than the two dollar sign rating here had led me to expect.Another minor thing is that I cancelled a reservation here a few days ago by phone but the restaurant did not update OpenTable properly so it counted as a no-show for me, which is irritating. I am a conscientious customer and I don't want a black mark on my OpenTable account. I was very impressed and pleasantly surprised.Fusion can be done very wrong or very right, and it this case its right on point. The service is phenomenal and the food is  very fresh, tasty and fits the theme of the restaurant. The fried chicken is very comforting and hearty! The batter they use is thick very crispy and tasty . Portions are worth the price and they have a decent wine menu. Great restaurant for a group because the menu is extensive enough to please everyone. Highly recommend for dinner. Food was fantastic!  The millionaire's bacon was pretty tasty.  I had the Francisco scramble which was more like an omelette than a scramble...but still very good.  Beware, the portions are HUGE.  I only ate half my meal...I felt bad wasting so much, but I couldn't have eaten all that food even if I tried!  The scramble itself was the size of a single deep dish pizza, and then you had a generous side of potatoes and a croissant.  Next time I will try to share with someone.  It really is enough for 2 people. Kitchen Story, where your bill is attached to a book. Space is quaint and cozy. I would recommend making a reservation in advance. I got there at 6pm and found myself pleasantly surprised at how empty it was. It's pretty great to enter a restaurant early on and watch as it fills. Come 7, Kitchen Story was bustling.Our server let my party know that portions were hearty and that we should err on the side of caution when it came to ordering. False. Portions are on the conservative side. I would recommend ordering family style and trying an array of dishes. Their Thai dishes (fried rice, pad kee mao, pad thai etc.) are solid. Kitchen Story is a solid neighborhood find. Would I make the trek just to dine at Kitchen Story? No. Would I stop by if I'm in the area? Yes. Definitely, yes.Parking can be tough, though there are some residential areas nearby so you may get lucky. It's walking distance to a muni station. Just amazing. The decor, the service and the food. Our group of five met for dinner and the food was amazing. We ordered the pacific ocean cod (flakey buttery goodness), the castro sea (spicy and flavorful w capers), the dancing queen (wagyu beef tenderness with fire presentation), garlic asparagus (super tasty), and the de tofu (yum). On top of us groaning from overindulgence, we managed to squeeze in room for desserts. Three awesome desserts: ice cream sandwich w/ millionaire bacon (thick savory goodness), chocolate molten cake with ice cream and another dessert which I blanked out on from food coma.  Intimate space, unlimited ice tea refills, great service and perfect way to end a Friday night in good company. Highly recommend for quality home cooking at affordable and reasonable prices. The food is good, but the service is really BAD. I went there  tonight and my entree came out 25 minutes after everyone else's. No apologizes and no acknowledgment. Just an arrogant attitude that they believed that they were not in the wrong "the kitchen had a problem" as if they had no responsibility for the service. I will not go back because there are so many more options in San Franisoc. The Millionaire's Bacon, the fried chicken, the beef salad were all amazing. Good service, GREAT food. I highly recommend this place. They also serve some free sweet potato chips to you while you wait for your food (I didn't wait long).
inspec_vio: High risk food holding temperature   [ date violation corrected: 12/2/2013 ]

name: Kitchen Story 2
category: Breakfast & Brunch in San Francisco, CA
review_text: You want good food?  Then you must hit up this place!  Kitchen Story is such a nice and cozy spot.  Now for the food.  We ordered the spicy kobe rolls for starters and it was just yummmm.  Now the main dish, we had the finger lickin good fried chicken,  boy burger, and thai fried rice.  i would totally recommend the fried chicken and burger!  The fried chicken came with a curry dipping sauce which made it tasted super good and the burger with the million dollar bacon was just delish!! YUMMMMMMMMM!!!  Millionaire bacon...must get the millionaire bacon...it's soaked in maple syrup and fried.  Super ridiculously horrible for you...but so delicious.I ordered a burger with a salad...I don't even remember what was in it except for the bacon.  That's all I cared about...the bacon.  Did I mention the bacon?Wifey ordered the mascarpone french toast with a side of millionaire bacon.  Geez, it was one of the best french toast dishes I have ever had.  The service was great...the mimosas were bottomless.  Perfecto.Their sister location is out by japantown but kitchen story was definitely the better of the two. The prices were decent...location was cute...the food and service was fantastic.5 solid stars.  Can't wait to come back here again!!! Eggs benedict - Delicious! Their fries are the best I've had in a long time. Not so big on the millionaire's bacon - unless you like soggy and sweet. Diner quality coffee, but very strong! We were actually en route to the restaurant next door but decided to eat brunch here once I saw "Millionaire Bacon" on the menu. Hands down the best tasting bacon I have ever had! The rest of the meal was great, too, especially the eggs (cooked to perfection in butter, not crappy vegetable or seed oils as most restaurants are wont to do), and the fruit salad. And despite being extremely busy that day, the staff was friendly and attentive. I will definitely be back next time I visit San Francisco. My boyfriend took me here for a romantic dinner. Our reservations were on time and the food was beautifully presented. The prices were not bad. The only disconnect was the ambiance. The venue was beautiful and the decor was very quaint. The only thing was that it didn't seem to match the food genre. Either way, it was a beautiful dinner and I can expect to return soon. Nothing but good things to say about Kitchen Story.The decor and ambiance is relaxing. The service was excellent. And the food was very good.  The signature bacon (Millionaire's Way) is awesome. I worried it would be too sweet with the maple syrop, but the taste was flavorful and and balanced.Salads were excellent, as well. Very fresh and tasty. This was always the restaurant I walked PAST to get to Ike's, but my wife convinced me to try it this morning so we went here for brunch. On the basis of many yelp reviews, I got the deep-fried, marscipone-stuffed french toast with two scrambled eggs and millionaire bacon. The meal did not disappoint.  Overall it was one of the riches meals of my life. We got there at about 10:15 and there were still a few tables available (Note: by the time we left at 11:00, the waiting list with 5 deep). The hostess was nice and sat us promptly. The waitress was attentive but not overbearing.
