The food came incredibly quick, and may be a product of their requests for no menu substitutions.I'm not sure what kind of super chickens they have in the back of the restaurant, but my "2 scrambled eggs" were the size of most restaurants' full-size omelettes. They were very buttery (dare I say too buttery?) and cooked perfectly. The french toast was something out of a State Fair, and I mean that in the best way possible. The crust was nice and crunchy while the insides soft and the mascipone for luscious. I'm normally a guy that usually douses his pancakes or french toast in syrup, and I barely used syrup because they were just so damn rich! Finally we come to the millionaire bacon. One principle, I almost didn't get it because it costs $2 more than regular bacon and that just seemed wrong. But boy was it worth it. The bacon itself revivals the best bacon I've ever had at any Midwestern diner. It's thick, its perfectly cooked, and glazed in a bit of syrup. What sets it apart is the extract kick at the end (which I'm guessing was chili powder). All in all, I can feel my food coma kicking in as I finish this review. We will definitely be coming back here for brunch, and based on yelp pictures will also likely try it out for dinner. We L-O-V-E-D Kitchen Story!!!  A pleasant surprise indeed it was!!!! YUM factor of a gazillion!  The four of us (all food lover's) shared 6 spectacular dishes in the very customer friendly, good vibe, nicely done, glad you are here great eats newer place in the hood!!!  I would recommend every dish we devoured.  Millionaire's Way (bacon baby!) what a splendid blend of healthy and not so much, Ahi scoops--my favorite!!!, Castro Sea--yummy, Burgah Boy-delish!, Short rib tacos--at this point I had died and gone to heaven, and Dancing Queen-- for the steak lovers!All truly exceptional in taste, presentation and value.  We can't wait to go back--SOON!  The waiters/servers et al were Fabu too!8 thumbs sky high up and yes indeed, a very pleasant surprise!A big heartfelt thanks to Rob & Dave for the recommendation! My new favorite Asian Fusion restaurant!! The Ahi scoops and short-rib beef tacos are to die for.  The staff was very friendly too! : ) I went there for my bday and they were very accommodating! Also, the decor was very interesting.... LOVE this place!! It was a windy Wednesday night and I met a friend at the bar for a pre-dinner glass of wine. After friendly service and a nice pour, we ended up staying for dinner. We moved to a table at the back, and I really liked the teeny cactus on the table. It was a nice touch (hah). I believe our servers name was Timmy. He was so friendly and helpful! I really thought he was personable and helped me find something that wasn't spicy at all on the menu. I got the bacon burger, while my friend got the Castro Sea full of seafood. We both enjoyed our food. Mine came with crispy wedges, which soaked up all the goods from the burger. YUM. They were a highlight of my meal. So many things on the menu looked delicious. I have heard this is a good spot for weekend brunch, so I'll be back! Asian fusion.Meh. Everything had a deep fried noodle sticking out of it. Cute the first time. Millionaire's Bacon is very meaty and salty-sweet. Definitely a crowd pleaser but me, I like my bacon crispy crunchy so this didn't cut it for me. My favorite thing was actually the ginger rice that came with the tilapia. How the heck did they make it that tasty?? Franciscan Omelette: best breakfast I've had in a long time! Same good food and service as Sweet Maple. Great breakfast. The millionaire's bacon is worth trying. I also had scrambled eggs that were fluffy and buttery delicious. I will definitely go back. great place for brunch! they definitely over decorate the dishes with things such as fried pieces of noodle which have no function except to look pretty. but aside from the excessive decorativeness of it, it's pretty good stuff. hearty portions for decent prices. large windows and a good vibe. i like this place! Great service!Great food!You have to try the Millionaire's Way Bacon!!! It is so good!!!We also had the Finger-Lickin' Chicken and East Feeds West Dinner!Both are very good.Definitely going back and telling friends!!!Wait staff was very attentive and helpful. Hello California burger!  Oh my!  Perfections!  It was a slightly chilly Saturday afternoon, we drove by on our way to Starbelly but the crowd was too packed there and saw that Kitchen Story had outdoor seating and looked cute.  Keep in mind, I have a 16 month old, so it has to be kid friendly and away from the crowds. Although it was chilly from the wind, but I was able to pull up with the stroller and plop down for brunchGreat menu, you know the kind that you can't decide because everything sounds so good.  Was in the mood for breakfast food.  Plates upon plates going by us and I was salivating.  I asked the really nice waiter, what should I get?  He gave me a few popular items frequently ordered by many, I asked him about the steak over rice, he said it is popular but can't say much about it because he does not eat beef.  I told him I was feeling like brunch eggy meal.  What does he recommend?  The California Burger.  Yeah, coming from a guy that doesn't eat beef.  Taking a risk, I went with it.  Man, when it arrived.  My eyes popped out, it looked amazing.  My first bite, in heaven.  Perfectly cooked juicy burger, on a sweet  toasted bun, topped with generous amount of avocado and sprouts, smeared with a mild goat cheese (lovex3).  The potato wedges, they were perfectly fried and seasoned.  It stayed crispy the whole time  and the pickle was also very crunchy and nicely brined.Best part of the meal?  I get to have my burger with a Thai ice tea, strange but it was a good marriage.I have to stay, service was really really good.  3 different waiter coming by asking if we were comfortable, checking on the baby, ask if we were cold and want to move inside, just really sweet staff.Can't wait to go back with more friends, that way I can try everything else they have. so good! must try the fried chicken with mushroom sauce. Beef omurice! stuffed ricotta French toast is a must too!! WOW!Amazing food.  Very unique menu. Wonderful service.I had the best breakfast ever in SF this weekend.Make this a destination for breakfast or brunch you will be delighted.Cheers,J Although we live near here, we only decided to have breakfast here at 9am because the line at Brenda's was already 20 deep.  We were relieved to find it uncrowded but not empty at this time.  We both ordered the Marscarpone French Toast, one with eggs and "Millionaire's Bacon".  I ordered coffee.  It was so strong and bitter even with cream that I had to have a spoonful of house raspberry jam to make it until the mains were served.  Plating was impeccable.  The Marscarpone French Toast is kind of huge, really just a big fried filled doughnut, most reminiscent of funnel cake.  The bacon is interesting but would be nicer unsmoked.In short, I'm still curious about the other food but not really impressed.  Benedicts are usually the morning choice going out so I'd still like to try that. Pretty trendy. I don't think the quality of the food quite matched what they were charging, but lines were short, decor was nice, presentation was nice and service was excellent.Specifically, I got the KS omelet with berries and a cappuccino. The cappuccino was very good, but the omelet was disappointing. I suspect there were better choices though. The ricotta pancakes are so silky and delicious.  I didn't like their eggs or chicken mango sausage (too much sodium!) though.  A solid brunch choice, and the servers are so nice and attentive. But the quality of food is much better at my fave brunch place in Noe Valley. Amazing food & service this is a great restaurant. I think this is my new fav restaurant in SF! Will definitely be going back! One of the rare times that I just walked in somewhere before checking it out on Yelp, but thankfully it was this place. Got the Original Clay Pot, so freaking good. Perfect amount of food, unique and delicious. Scoped out some of the other dishes being served and everything looked really good. Millionaire's bacon was a treat indeed. Thick cut and caramelized but too spicy for me (I am very sensitive). Ricotta cakes were lovely - not too dough-ey and nicely topped with berries. Frisco benedict was ok; the bread was a little too over-toasted but the chicken apple sausage was nice combined with the avocado slices and poached eggs. The side of "rainbow" potatoes (mix of gold, russet, purple) was decent if not a tad salty. Solid brunch fare. This place has huge portions.  My friend and I only got salads which were tasty and filling, but we both admitted to drooling when we saw their other dishes.  Will come back for brunch and dinner to try everything else. I get kind of hangry when I have to wait more than 30-45 min for brunch, so I was pleased to find a place within walking distance in my neighborhood (just don't call it the Mastro, please!) where there wasn't a ridiculous wait, plenty of tables both indoors/outdoors, eye-catching decor and a solid Asian Californian inspired menu. On two separate visits for brunch and lunch, I enjoyed the Frisco eggs benedict with perfectly poached eggs coated in a lemony hollandaise, Mascarpone stuffed french toast and the spicy beef salad with tangy lime dressing. All were excellent and beautifully plated, although I think the salad was a touch over-dressed so it may be advisable to get the dressing on the side next time...Ooh, and the side of crispy rainbow potatoes were excellent as well (potatoes should always have fluffy insides!). I also find it delightful that they serve wine on tap and bottomless mimosas ($18), which are a lovely option for boozy brunch with the ladies. An excellent alternative to the weekend madness over at Mission Beach Cafe! I saw a huge brunch crowd here on the weekend, so I came back later in the week to try it for breakfast.  I ordered the mascarpone-stuffed, deep-fried french toast.  The presentation was great - it looked spectacular.  But it was delivered with a steak knife that turned out to be essential.  There was an overly-thick and hard crust on the outside than was challenging to cut through and a little greasy.  Looks: 10, Taste: 3. Most trendy breakfast places in SF leave me thinking "what's all the hype about?".  Not Kitchen Story; this place delivers!They have delicious food, great service, and although it's crowded, you still get seated in a timely manner. Both my wife and I loved our dishes. Marscapone French toast with perfectly fluffy eggs and bacon and a unique and tasty spin on steak and eggs dish with potatoes and a croissant. I can't wait to go back.  We sat at the bar and saw a number of dishes at the service window that we want to try next. You know how hard it is to get a reservation for a large group in SF?  Well, this was one of the rare places in the city that would take a reservation for 7.  I researched this place and made the reservation based on reviews.  It's been a couple of weeks since I was there so I forget exactly what I ate but for an Asian fusion restaurant the food was good!  I do remember finishing my  entire plate and everyone else enjoying their food as well.  Some had wine and some had bubbles.  My friend who is a local found this new establishment pleasing (I think he said it used to be Tangerine).  The staff was helpful in keeping our water glasses full.  Our server was very attentive to our needs.  I would love to come here again. Delicious and superb service.  Love it! A new brunch place serving breakfast until 3pm? Why thank you very much, I will be there! And I was and it was good.The prices are Castro and San Francisco sized that is to say on the high end with everything being 8-14 dollar and most over 10.So if you are ok paying that much for breakfast then this a good choice. There was plenty of tables free on a weekday afternoon. The menu has mix of so much from  jook inspired to dishes to fried chicken and burgers. We stuck to the breakfast side of things with the Ribeye omurice (14)scrambled eggs over jasmine rice, marinated ribeye, carrots, cherry-pepper, spinach, scallion.Demi glazed sauce. It wasn't what I was expecting but it was good. It was scrambled omlet seved over fried rice with bit of streak in it and gravy poured over everything. It was a huge portion and served with great potatoes. The French Spouse had the Artichoke watercress pesto benedict(13) bacon, artichoke, tomato, pesto hollandaise without the bacon. This not your typical benedict with the hollandaise with lighter, but it was super tasty and again a huge portion.The servers seem to be the same folks as when it was Tangerine and the service was good. The remodel is quite nice and it's a bright space that should be ok for ASL speakers and for the hard of hearing. It's wheelchair accessible. Burger with maple syrup & bacon & amazing potatoes.....enough said! Many people have been suggesting that I'm missing something great by not checking out Kitchen Story, so here goes and I'll start with the burger itself which was truly great.  Tall, filled with an acre of sprouts and fashion designer greens with a steak knife plunged into the heart of the matter, this burger is a sight to behold and before taking my first bite I tried one of the extra crispy potato wedges, and they're perfect albeit scarce on the tired white restaurant issue platter.  A child's handful of bright red pickled veggies rounded out the presentation.  First bite showed the thoughtful burger concept in play here, touches of avocado, the melted white cheddar, the ripe, fresh tomato, the herbed mayo and a trace of balsamic glaze, all between a dense, toasted artisan bun and I experienced burger ecstasy and it became a burger I'll be returning for as long as they hold true to the current content and execution, it's truly top notch in every way.  The physical restaurant has had many incarnations and this one is almost a neutral design, simple, clean and understated as in a lack of ego perhaps by these owners.  Service was charming as well as professional and putting it all together, Kitchen Story is a win, win, winner.  Check was presented on a truly forgettable paperback novel, Bonita Faye by Margaret Mosley,  with and old fashion clothespin holding the check to the book, bravo for the little things in life. The brunch is excellent!I've also had the "Finger-Lickin" fried chicken with curry: Yum!The burger is pretty fantastic, but I just don't think it's $18's worth of fantastic.Very friendly service, nice decor, I'll keep on coming back! First off, I would like to say that this place had high hopes of being 5 stars for me. What went wrong: My party was 4. They brought out 2 of my party's brunches then made us wait 20 minutes until the 3rd plate came out and then finally brought mine another 15 minutes later. I'm not sure what place expects their customers to each 35 minutes between one another but that was pretty unacceptable to me. We were there to eat together, not eat, wait a half an hour and then wait around until the rest of the party ate. I had the Frisco Benedict. Unfortunately my eggs were fully cooked through. They put hard boiled eggs on top of my Benedict- not an ounce of yolk to be had. The waiter apologized and said he'd be back right away with some poached eggs for me and that I should just continue eating. Guess what? He forgot. I can deal with poached being completely cooked but don't promise to bring me something then just not follow through. After waiting 10 minutes and realizing they weren't coming I simply finished. The last I saw him was when he brought us our check. What they did right:The bottomless mimosas were awesome. From the food I did have, it was quite tasty. 2 of my party had the french toast and the millionaire bacon- it was delectable. I might consider trying this place again, but I had such a bad experience, I probably would rather go elsewhere where they actually care. This place is awesome. We've gone there twice now. Everything we ate was cooked perfectly and presented in such a fun way. We ordered: -Millionaire's bacon- OMG, make sure you order this-Ahi tuna scoops- very fresh-Finger lickin' chicken- great yellow curry sauce and fried chicken-East meets west- I think that's what it's called. the pork falls off the bone and the rice and cucumbers are fantastic-Pumpkin curry- this was pretty good, but I'd choose the above stuff before I ordered this again.The staff is super friendly too. We will definitely be back again. Went to dinner with a friend last night. We split the Millionaire appetizer, which was very good. My piece of bacon was a little on the spicy side for me but was still very good.   I had the black cod with bok choi. It was delish.  My friend had the short ribs (I think) tacos. The meat was very tasty. I also ordered the Burgah to go for my BF. who loved it. He was very happy. Service was pretty good although it table was so far back I felt like I was sitting in the supply area. I would go again for dinner and would like to try brunch. Bottomless mimosas!!!And the brunch was delicious!! Wanted to order everything from the menu...Service was friendly and they take reservations!! The brunch was not only beautiful but so super yummy. Good job!Perfect poached eggs. If you think that Kitchen Story (stupid name by the way) has a story to tell...think again. Listen to my story and heed notice. It will all end in tears! And those tears are Mine!My friend Kristy and I were contemplating on a place to have brunch in our neighborhood. We've pretty much tried everywhere else and wanted something a little different. She suggested Kitchen Story and was like, "hmmmm, not to sure about that place? Isn't it basically a new Tangerine? Right?" We both contemplated Kasa but ended up saying what the fuck! Why not? Let's give it a chance. First mistake.The place was pretty busy and it seemed promising. The brunch menu was a mish-mash of Asian/fusion brunchables and the like. Asian Brunch. How bad could it be? Second mistake.We were seated relatively quickly (at the bar) and our waitress was prompt enough. Her English wasn't the best and this showed in the way we had to rephrase our questions to the various items on the menu. For example, my friend Kristy wanted a side of avocado but was told NO, they don't do that. OK? Well then, never mind.Only to find out 5 minutes later that they do sell sides of avocado. We found this out by looking on back of the menu under the sides section. HUH? I guess we were not clear enough. Third mistake.I then inquired about the Okonomiyaki plate. Now get this...they charge $11.00 for this plate and then an additional $5.00 to add on an egg and bacon or sausage or an additional $2.50 ($17.50?) for their millionaire bacon. Seriously?!?!? So I asked if I could just order an egg, I didn't need any meat on top of my Okonomiyaki anyway. She said NO, I have to order the egg with the meat. OK? Well then I'll take a side of eggs (2 eggs @ $3.00) for the top of my Okonomiyaki. Fine, this should be good. I've had this dish numerous time and I know what to expect. Yum...I'm excited! Fourth mistake.FUCK! Was I wrong! What arrived was a DEFLATED, DEAD LOOKING, NAKED CORPSE of a Okonomiyaki on the counter before me! I thought it was a joke at first. They must of forgot the fixings? It must be arriving on another plate? WRONG! Fifth mistake.I was fucking annoyed! No, I was pissed! Really? There was absolutely nothing on top of my "seafood pancake"! No garnishes what-so-ever! No cabbage! No Carrots! No katsuo Bushi! NOTHING, except (now get this) a few (6 strands) alfalfa sprouts, a slice of a strawberry and a slice of an orange with a tin ramekin of their (spicy mayo). Wow! They saw me coming. What a RIPP-OFF! I was really disappointed.Remember, we were sitting at the bar. So we could see everything that was coming out of the kitchen. Every other thing that came out of that kitchen looked good. Looked substantial. Looked alive. My plate looked DEAD! Kitchen Story was obviously trying to up-sell this dish. An extra $5.00 to add on to what normally comes with this dish? MAJOR CROOKS! Needless to say, when the waitress finally (yes finally) came by to check on our meal, I let her know that I was disappointed. She did not ask why and/or even inform the management about my albeit small predicament. So, when I caught the manager's attention I had to let her know that I was very dissatisfied with my meal and if they are going to serve Okonomiyaki that they should at the very least throw some chopped cabbage or carrots or something just to keep it from looking so DEAD! Of course she tried to justify the dish by saying that there were chopped veggies in the Okonomiyaki and that's how it comes. Blah, blah, blah. Really, excuses? Save it lady! I didn't even want to be comped. I just wanted the management to know and to tell the owner that they were serving a poorly executed dish at a disgustingly high price-point. I think I was beating a dead horse (which I should have ordered, anything would have been better then the shit they just served me). The manager just did not seem to care. Final mistake.I will never come to this restaurant again and I will tell anyone who is willing to listen, the reasons why. If I could give less than one star I would. This place is too expensive for what you get.Poor to adequate service and a cavalier (at best) attitude towards any constructive criticism. Next time we are going just around the corner to Kasa @ 18th and Noe. Just had brunch here with my daughter--sooo good!  People were waiting, not surprising as it was Sunday noon on a perfect warm day.  Wait for an outside table was a half hour but we were seated inside in less than ten minutes.  Extremely nice floor manager, extremely nice and efficient wait person.  I had a scramble with millionaire's bacon; she had the stuffed french toast.  Everything was really beautifully presented and beautifully cooked.  My eggs were just perfect, better than I can make myself.  The bacon is a treat if you have never had it--others have called it bacon candy and that is a good description.  My daughter's french toast was very good but she will probably go back to the Benedict she had last time.  Our favorite component was the potatoes though.  Crisp on the outside, fluffy on the inside.  They were still delicious at the end of the meal when they'd cooled--I don't know how they did that but they were the star of the show.  Oh, and bottomless mimosas were fun.  Unlike some places, our glasses were refilled every few minutes.  Yummy food, great experience-we will be back! Excellent brunch and no wait.  Enough said. Mascarpone French Toast with Millionaire's bacon were great unique breakfast.  That's why the ratings are high.The Ribeye Omurice was good but my expectations were a little too high.  We were hoping it would blow us away but it didn't.  It was much likely healthier than HRD Coffee Shop's BBQ Pork Scrambled Eggs over rice but wasn't as tasty.  Will definitely return as this place is very promising, Really great meal.  The calamari and the Spicy Kobe Rolls were some of the best apps I've had in a long time, and the "Dancing Queen" Wagyu Beef was delicious. Service was great too. Definitely coming back soon! This is a great addition to dining in the Castro.  And, the price is moderate. The food has been uniformly good on the three visits I've made, and the service was excellent. Kitchen Story is restaurant that serves California cuisine with a touch of influence from Asia.  The owner Steven Choi is originally from South Korea, as well as bioengineer with passion for food.  He confessed that there's a lot in common between bioscience and cooking, they both require recipes. His invention, "millionaire's bacon" has attracted the attention of the Food Network and brunch goers alike.  It's something I regret not tasting while there; however, it will definitely end up in my belly in the future.The restaurant is located in the Castro neighborhood, so it's no surprise it's stylish, a modern and yet very cozy decor with earth tones used throughout. The ambiance sets the tone with high expectations for the cuisine.  But not to worry, the dishes were exceptional and delivered flavors that are foreign and lacking at most brunch establishments.  For example, I absolutely adore the KS's Own Omelette, which incorporates pork wine sausage, lemongrass, asparagus, bell peppers and soy sauce. I have never tasted an omelette this different and so complex in flavor.  Who would think soy sauce would be such a great partner with eggs.  The ingredients tasted fresh and the eggs were super fluffy.  The rainbow potatoes were equally delightful; the three types of potatoes were perfectly roasted, crunchy with soft interior, and without the common grease accompanying them.  The butter croissant finalized the dish, but ended up leaving the restaurant with me.  The coffee was also brewed to dark perfection.  I definitively have no complaints and only accolades for this place.The staff did not deduct from the experience and if anything complimented the decor and dishes with their professionalism and attentiveness.  My java and water were always full without requests and the food was delivered piping hot.  By the way, they offer free internet, just need to ask for the passcode, as they change it frequently to prevent the local building residents from enjoying free internet in their residence.I shall return as soon as feasibly possible!!!  The millionaire's bacon and the egg pancakes will be part of the next kitchen story. We came here this morning for brunch! Let me just start by saying that we finished everything on our plates. Everything! And that never happens. Our order: -Deep fried french toast: I was a bit off put by how dark the breading was, but it was still very good nonetheless. I liked the fruit it came with and the mascarpone was just enough to make it moist, but not overwhelming. I liked this one more than my boyfriend, but he's not too partial to sweets. The stick garnish is deep fried spaghetti! -Millionaire's bacon w/ two eggs: great bacon! They're just like short ribs! Thick cut with a bit of sweet and spiciness. The spiciness is what really made it special to me. The eggs were done well and the croissant, well...that could be improved, but I know it's not the star of the dish. The rainbow potatoes weren't very crunchy, but I liked the idea of them. The coffee was good and the service was okay. Sometimes it was a bit spotty. Like, we asked for more coffee and didn't get any, but then a person other than the one we asked noticed we needed more, so it was brought over. Then, we asked for the check and it took a while to get there--longer than I would have expected, especially during the morning when they should be trying to turn tables over. My water was refilled many times, which was nice though. Although, one thing that could be improved, is the bathroom situation. There are two bathrooms, I went to the one on the left and the top of the toilet tank was off, making for something unsightly. It wasn't overtly "dirty" but it really didn't have a clean feeling and made me uncomfortable :/ Overall, it was a good meal though and I'm glad to have tried it. Short story, we booked through open table 8 days ago for a table for 6 at 9:45pm. We were refused entry or service with one member of our group arriving at 9:43pm (but not checking in?) and the other 5 arriving at 9:47/48pm. We were told "there is no restaurant in America that takes people at 9:45pm if the restaurant is closing at 10pm and the guests are expected to leave by 10:30pm". Get a new manager and new servers, change your attitude - how unfortunate as my friends and I loved getting brunch at Blackwood in the Marina. Long story: There were 3 people in our party who had just come in from Philly and New York, one arriving directly from SFO and there was one other on his way out of the country later that evening. I had organized a booking at a restaurant that was willing to take a party our size that late at night specifically because of all the logistics. I thought I planned it all out - the restaurant is 5 minutes from my apartment, little did I know what was to follow.My friend from the airport arrived at 9:43pm and stood outside, the remaining five strolled in to see her in a conversation with someone from the restaurant at the door. Turns out this guy doesn't understand what Open Table reservations are, and that if they close their kitchen at 10pm they shouldn't take reservations electronically past 8:45 or 9:15pm, simple as that. This guy was outraged that we would even consider doing what we did - show up at a restaurant to eat food at the specified time of our reservation. Ridiculous - was really looking forward to the food, but this guy needs to at least acknowledge that this was a mistake on their part and they would correct their Open Table settings on their end, or follow up with people who reserve past a certain time. Pathetic. We were lucky that Chow was open and were able to have a relaxed hearty meal there. Walked in here without a reservation around 8pm on a weekday and had no wait to sit at the bar. This place isn't huge but they have a decent amount of seating as long as your party isn't large. Nice modern decor, and friendly service.Started off with a 1554 which is one of my favorite dark beers, haven't seen it in a restaurant for a while so this was a nice plus. They also brought us complimentary crispy yams with the beers which were deliciously crunchy which just the right amount of salt.The "Burgah" Boy burger was good. Especially the bacon on top of it which was decadent and delicious, think thick juicy candied bacon (not the crunchy kind). I think the bacon is their signature ingredient, seems like you can get it on a bunch of different dishes or by itself.Also tried the Dancing Queen which is essentially steak slices on top of ginger flavored brown rice and green beans. The steak was pretty good, the sauce and the rice add extra interesting to it, the most fun part is the 151 they pour on top and _light on fire_ when they serve it to you! Note to all restaurants: I'm a sucker for food lit on fire.Finished things off with the coffee gelato desert. Basically a ball of coffee gelato with sweetened semi-liquid espresso in the middle and coffee grounds shavings sprinkled on top. I love coffee and coffee flavored deserts so this one really hit the spot! First of all this is not a 5 stars restaurant with table cloth that you pay $35+ a dish so I didn't expect their service would knock my sock off. Cut them some slack,people! I never had a bad meals or bad service here! The food is well priced. Grilled KOBE beef for only $20??? The service is as good as you can get for a new restaurant that has just been open. I just appreciated that they brought something new and decent to the area so we have more choices to choose from. I heard their brunch is really good too. Can't wait to try it! I normally don't like to write bad reviews of restaurants, but I just can't help myself with regard to Kitchen Story. What is the story with Kitchen Story? We walked in and the place was almost empty when we arrived, and we were asked whether we had a reservation. Wishful thinking! The food was just awful. My wife and I tried the Castro Tower and the Ahi and other ingredients were awash in some sort of sugary syrup. My wife thinks she had the beef salad, but wasn't really sure because it was drowning in dressing. I ordered a curried salmon, and it came out deep fried like fish and chips. It was overcooked and I had to scrape off the greasy battered coating which was thick and hard, soaked through with oil. What a waste of a perfectly good fish. It was sitting on a bed of some Asian vegetables that were slathered in a greasy sweet sauce. I asked for additional vegetables in lieu of rice, and they offered a salad. They actually brought out a bowl of salad greens with no dressing - someone literally grabbed some greens out of a bucket and through it in the bowl. Forget about getting some ground pepper on the salad! When I was finally able to get the waiter's attention and ask whether I could have some dressing, he said he would "check and see." I wasn't given an option and he eventually brought out a dressing that he claimed was a vinaigrette. It was so loaded with sugar, I couldn't eat it. The waiter then tried to pour my wife a second glass of beer without asking - which we sent away, and then he snatched away her plate without asking whether we were done - I guess he already knew the answer to that question. With both of our stomachs growling and acid reflux jumping up our throats, we finally made our exit after paying a five star bill for a one star meal. Please don't waste your time or money or risk your intestinal health by dining here.  We have been to at two other restaurants located in this same location; sadly, Kitchen Story is destined to be just another flash in the pan on this great corner. How do I know when I tasted something truly delectable? I usually dream about it afterwards.Yup, there you have it, I had a dream this weekend...the main character was that beautifully smoked (looked it), mouth-watering, thick and chewy Millionaire's Bacon all wrapped in a slight caramelized sweetness. I woke up with a dire craving.Needless to say, my Friday night dinner was delicious! Had Millionaire's Bacon for appetizer; had scallop wrapped in Millionaire's Bacon (a.k.a Big Hug) for main course. In between, also tasted Ahi Scoops (yum!) and Spicy Kobe Rolls (so-so). I finished off the night with a big mug of Thai Ice Tea.Total satisfaction. I wanted to like this place more than I actually did. Everything was just a little bit off. I went for dinner two weekends ago and for brunch this past weekend. We'll just go dish by dish.We had the Ahi Scoops, which were pretty delicious, and I liked the different textures, but they were just too big and awkward to eat.My boyfriend had the Big Hug, which was pretty delicious. The Millionaire's Bacon was as delicious as everyone says it is. I had the short rib tacos, which were not that impressive. The meat was pretty dry, but the guac was pretty good. For breakfast, my boyfriend just had two eggs over easy with the millionaire's bacon, which were delicious. I had the Athenian Omelette, which I really did not like at all. The olives made me feel sick, and the cheese was just too creamy.I liked the rainbow potatoes, but I think I'll stick to our other spots for brunch. love it!!!... food, service, ambience. awesome!!!i will go back for those yummy ricotta pancakes. :) BREAKFAST BREAKFAST BREAKTAST.  Some of the best breakfast in the city.  The millionaire's bacon is like pork candy.  The Ricotta hot cakes have ruined all other types of hot cakes for me. Great neighborhood spot. I'm not a huge fan of the name but the food is outstanding!  Get the ahi scoops & the ahi salad! Mmmmmm..P.S. They are very accommodating to people with dietary restrictions (e.g. gluten-free) Let me just start by saying that I'm a server and I eat out all the time. Nonetheless, I'm not very picky about food or service. I'm not haughty about being a server so I can critique the service of others; on the contrary, I'm very empathetic.So I came here for brunch at around 2pm on a Saturday. It wasn't busy. There was no wait. I was a single party and I got a seat outside right away, which was nice. The bottom line with their product, in my experience, is that it looks nice but tastes bad. The Bloody Mary had a beautiful garnish, but tasted horrible. I've had many Soju cocktails, so it wasn't the absence of vodka that bothered me, it was the fact that the "mix" basically tasted like straight tomato juice with some slightly spicy element. It was nothing tasty or creative. There were chunks of something in the drink which made it annoyingly impossible to drink from the straw. There wasn't a lot of ice and it clearly wasn't shaken so it was warm. I couldn't finish it.I got an egg white scramble with white cheddar and spinach. The menu says that no substitutions are allowed, which I totally understand, but I asked if I could add a couple things and my server said I could. I asked for avocado and mushrooms. She blurted out a noise that basically implied I was asking too much and pointed to the part of the menu that said no substitutions. I'm not substituting anything I'm adding a couple things which you just said was fine, but if it's difficult for the kitchen I do not have to do it. They did it. Thank you. I don't want to be difficult.The food came 30 minutes later (which I didn't complain about because I understand what it's like to work with a small kitchen) only after another server who brought my drink earlier said himself that he was surprised my food hadn't arrived and went to get it for me. It looked nice. They use different colored potatoes and serve their breakfast dishes with a cute croissant. I expected roasted breakfast potatoes like the ones that are served at most restaurants, but they were fried. I couldn't have known because they're just called "rainbow potatoes." I think that's gross but that's only my personal opinion. The croissant looked great, but was dense and hard. The scramble was bland and the spinach hadn't been properly drained so the whole thing was wet and runny. Very underwhelming and really kind of surprising.Now for the service, if you want to call it that. You don't have to be a server to know that the first thing you say when you approach a table is, "Hi. How are you?" It's very easy. Instead I got, "Are you ready?" Whatever, I'm not sensitive so it's not a big deal. I'm here to eat. She took my order. That was the last time I ever saw her again. Someone else brought my food, which is totally fine, but no one ever checked back. You ALWAYS check back! "How is everything?" That's all you have to say! Then finally, quite awhile after I finished eating (and I'm not a very fast eater), the guy drops off my check without saying a word to me. I don't think he meant to be rude, he just didn't know what he was doing. "How was everything (yes, once more at the end)? Anything else for you today?" It's not difficult! He dropped off a check presenter with nothing in it. I told him and he brought the check and I handed him cash. He brought my change back, but not the check, and dropped it on the table without saying a word. I asked for the check and he asked, "Oh, you want your receipt?" Um, yeah! At this point I called him back and, as nicely as I could, told him that the service was horrific and basically told him how to do his job. He sat down at the table and listened and was very receptive. He apologized and invited me back saying things would be different. I really was nice about it. Then I tipped him 40% because I kinda felt bad. They're not bad people, just bad servers. And with bad food to boot, I will not be coming back here, even it happened to be a fluke thing. We went here for dinner on a Friday evening with friends & two toddlers. We called 15mins ahead and when we walked in our table was ready. The food was so good! A very nice fusion of Thai & American. They can make their dishes mild to spicy you just have to ask. I thought Mom's Coconut Soup was the best I've ever had! The Mango Salad w/Prawns tasted like an American version of Som Tum Thai. The kids order of Fried Chicken w/steamed Rice had the largest chicken breast I have ever seen served off a children's menu. The whole table had to "help" finish the plate. Everyone raved about the crispy batter, juicy chicken & perfectly cooked rice. One suggestion: skip their mango sticky rice and order the Tri-O gelato. Yum! Also, their wine selections were good & wait staff was friendly, professional & efficient. We are definitely going back!!! Oh, The Millionaire's Bacon is so worth it! Tried Kitchen Story for the first time with friends last night and we all loved it. The food flavors were very good and interesting, the menu had a lot to offer, and the service was friendly. Every dish we ordered we each enjoyed. We had just been drinking, so we didn't explore the wine/beer offering. I definitely will be back and recommend this place to others. This place was good. Service was attentive, nice atmosphere. Food was slightly overpriced for what it is, but not particularly memorable. Especially the curry was nothing spectacular. We went for dinner. I would consider going back for brunch. The bacon seemed overhyped to me. I'm not a big review writer, but my first visit to KS for brunch was a HIT!  I had the mango chicken benedict and it was superb.  I don't know what they do to their potatoes, but they're the best I've had anywhere.  Multi-colored and super savory and cooked to perfection! The other items on the lunch & dinner menus sounded SO good, that we're going back for dinner tonight with friends.  YUMMY : ) We found this place on a list of what's hot in the foodie scene. A friend was visiting so we decided to try it out and are so glad we did. The food was really delicious and creative.We had:1) Kobe Beef spicy rolls-this was a bite of amazing. A big bite and you need the whole bite to get all the flavors in!2) Millionaires bacon-this was featured on some TV show and I know why-it was very good3) Eggplant-yummy. Fried crispy4) Short Rib Tacos-these were good. Good portion, good flavors. The tortillas could have been done a little better, a little more creatively5) Pad Thai-this was god Pad Thai6) Mango and sticky rice dish-this was my least favorite dish of the night- I didn't like itOverall the food was creative, fusion done well, priced right. I will go back soon, there were lots of things on the menu I want to try, so when I do I'll update my review.Nice food, nice people, good atmosphere, worth a visit! We dined at Kitchen Story on a Monday night. The service was lackluster at best. Our server was friendly, but largely inattentive. The food was outrageously overpriced - an appetizer with two strips of their famous bacon and two spears of asparagus was $12. The hamburger is $18, and doesn't even hold a candle to the burger at Nopa (which I think is less expensive).In a nutshell, if you're going to spend $50/person on dinner, go someplace with excellent service and better food. I love the ambiance and the food is good enough that it's one of the restaurants that I keep on my list.   Service is good too.  It's a nice casual restaurant where you can relax with your friends.  I definitely recommend. Yelp did it again! I don't know what I would do without Yelp now. Like how would I know that this place exists?Well my Adam found this place actually. But thru Yelp and his Yelp friends recommendation. We were both very happy with our first visit. I took in the decor and observed the staff while waiting for my order. Five stars for both!My deep fried mascarpone stuffed French Toast was unique and surprisingly not overly sweet. I like it but the toast was too hard for my taste. It is still good. This place is next door to Ike's Sandwich. So don't let the long line fool you. It's for them not for the Kitchen Story. In a further attempt to brunch the hell out of this town, I stumble into Kitchen Story. It had decent reviews on yelp, and I'm becoming more discerning in my brunch selections. Well...mostly being nicer because I realized I was being too picky with the yelp stars. =) Came here and got their KS omelet with millionaires bacon on the side. I tried the millionaires bacon at Sweet Maple and found it disappointing....and after this one, I realized I just don't like millionaires bacon as much as regular bacon. Or bacon at MBC. My omelet looked like it was prepared on one of those infomercial omelet plans - strangely perfectly half-circle, with rounded edges. Perfect scramble. The taste was fine, but I'm not as impressed with the cooking method. It came with rainbow potatoes that were cooked very well, and a mini croissant that was buttery and flaky...but didn't seemed to be baked in-house.The service was very attentive. A waitress came by to greet me on entry, and each of the guests at my table as they arrived. They were prompt to come by to help, but didn't seem pushy for us to leave. The owner (I think?) ate with his family there, and said bye to us as we left. How nice! I gotta say I was devastated when Kitchen Story replaced Tangerine.  I had great brunch memories there.  But...I guess good things were to come because brunch at Kitchen Story was even better.Our biggest worries about our visit to Kitchen Story: It's Sunday brunch in the Castro - EASTER SUNDAY - and we had a party of 5 without reservation.  We braced ourselves for the worst (hour+ wait), but were surprised when we were invited in with less than 15 minutes wait time!  BLESS THIS PLACE.Eggs and savory dishes highlighted the menu, perfect for the hungover.  There were even some intriguing, tempting Asian fusion brunch items like okonomiyake and ribeye omurice.Our group ordered:- Ribeye omurice (x2)!- Millionaire bacon- Ricotta pancakes- Marscapone stuffed deep fried french toast- Frisco benedictTaste:I was EXTREMELY impressed with the poached eggs on my Frisco benedict - poached to perfection!  My inner chef is jealous of their skill.  The ingredients for this benedict were impressive as well - crunchy (not soggy) toast, chicken mango sausage, avocado, cherry pepper, and that hollandaise sauce...creamy, but not too heavy.  The side of rainbow potatoes are also worth ranting about.  They're good. I gobbled everything up!  My friends were a little underwhelmed by the ribeye omurice, which they described as a PF Changs brunch remake. However, the ricotta pancakes and stuffed french toast were divine - loved the colorful arrangement of fruit toppings.  Millionaire bacon is worth trying to see what the hype is about.  But let's be real here - my eggs benedict was too good to share.Food presentation:  Probably some of the most beautifully presented brunch items I've ever seen.Service:  Our server was friendly and attentive!  She helped us out with menu items and made sure we were well taken care of.Speed:  Again, we were prepared for the worst, but our food came out in no time at all!I saw that there were bottomless mimosas ($16) here and might just have to come back.  Reasonable prices, beautifully presented and delicious food items, friendly servers, efficient service, and a comfortable setting to enjoy brunch with your friends.  Kitchen Story is on the map! This place has got to be my favorite eggs benedict restaurant in the city.  They do this unique thing where they place two poached eggs on top of one thick slab of toasted bread.  It's SO good!  The eggs were perfectly poached, with the yolk running down the avocado and bread once they were sliced.  The potato hash is delicious!  The hash seems to have a couple of different starches in it. It has different types of potatoes and sweet potatoes.  Perfectly seasoned.  I cleaned the plate even though I could have very well stopped at poached egg #1.  This place was busy for a Sunday brunch but my friend and I only waited for 10-15 minutes max.  I would totally come back to try their other breakfast items like their omelet.  This may very well be the best breakfast place in town for me. Just had a brunch here today to try out a different place.So I ordered the eggs benedict and my friend had some omelet. The reason i'm giving this place a 3 stars was because of my eggs benedict. I was expecting my pouched egg to be perfectly cooked but it wasn't. The egg yolk was cooked all the way instead of being runny :( and i think the bread was too crunchy. if the pouched egg was cooked perfectly it would have been better. that was a true disappointment. I actually could have asked for another plate, not because of the pouched egg not being cooked properly, because i found a little piece of aluminum foil mixed into my potatoes. I just didn't wanna deal with it because i was hungry. The omelet my friend has was actually better than mines :( Though the food was a bit disappointing, at least the service was good. The servers were nice and attentive service. I would give this place another try but i will definitely not get eggs benedict. Fried Chicken with curry sauce... millionaire's bacon... Kitchen Story is officially in my rotation now. The five stars are for the magical combination of three things that are hard to come by in San Francisco:1. They can handle large parties (think 10) without a problem.2. They have lots of delicious options for around $20!3. Fried chicken that is truly finger lickin' just like the menu says.I had to scour the city for a restaurant that was well-rated and would accept a reservation for our giant party, so I was ecstatic when I discovered Kitchen Story. In addition to the large party, the menu is so reasonably priced for SF. When we arrived our table was ready to go, and our server was on top of things. We brought in three bottles of vino ($15/bottle corkage fee), and he took care of getting those chilled and poured as needed without nary a complaint. Throughout the dinner, you couldn't even tell we were being served because everything came and went so seamlessly. For my entree I ordered the Finger-Lickin' ($18) fried chicken breasts, extra crispy with russet wedges, coconut Yellow curry dipping sauce, and cucumber salad. It's like my Southern aunt and Indian mom from a past life birthed a magical culinary baby. I couldn't shovel it into my mouth fast enough or get enough of the delicious curry sauce onto each bite. It is truly a must-try dish. Yes, there's also the burger and the amazing bacon, but don't snooze on the chicken! Cute place and decor.Friendly and attentive service.Typical brunch food.No wait for bar seating.This place is worth checking out if you're in the area.  And don't be deterred by the line you see outside, it's actually for Ike's. I know all the foodie brunchers in SF are into millionaire's bacon at the moment, but doesn't it get to be too sweet? That's diabetes and a heart attack waiting to happen. Fortunately, I exercise and am in excellent shape so I'm allowed to eat it as much as I want. It still gets to be too sweet for me though, but stick it in a BLT panini and it's perfect. French toast was good. Mango salad was good. Omelet was good.JONASAPPROVED! Brunch here was good but not great.  The bread under my eggs benedict was too crunchy for the dish.  The flavors were all good but didn't leave a strong impression together.  Millionaire's bacon was delicious, service was good. So far I have been to this place three times. I have to say ever time I have been greeted by the friendliest staff. The service has been great. My favorite dish is on the lunch menu during the week. "Mom's Hotpot". It is very tasty. Presentation is great, however not a dish for a youngster. The Hotpot is really hot and could burn little fingers. I have been to Kitchen Story 4 times now and it's absolutely my favorite restaurant in the city. Asian fusion at it's very best. They won my over with the finger lickin fried chicken on my very first visit. The burger was amazing. Every side they put on your plate has meaning and is full of flavor. I love the attention to detail. I just learned that they have omurice and I nearly fell out of my chair. I cannot wait to visit again. KS was part of the DishCrawl via airbnb.com! Had a great time in the rustic space. The sampling of the veg food was really good! The tofu was well flavored and interestingly presented. Very tasty. I will definitely go back for a full meal. two words: millionaire's bacontwo more words: bottomless mimosas i've been here for brunch three times in the last month, and i've recommended it at least 5 times to others. so, do your mouth a favor and try this great new addition to the castro brunch scene. Great service and food! San Francisco does food right, and Kitchen story is a prime example.  Wanting a dish that wasn't too heavy, I got the pan seared tilapia with mango salad.  The fish was served over ginger rice and topped with a cilantro-lime sauce.  The sauce of thick and packed a hard, flavorful punch.  For my taste, this menu item was perfect.Everyone talks about the "burgah boy" bacon cheeseburger, so it's what over half of my party ordered.  Lucky for me, there where leftovers that I was able to try.  The burger lived up to the hype.  While I haven't been everywhere in the city, Kitchen Story stands out as my favorite eatery in San Francisco. Asian fusion done RIGHT!For dinner I had:Kobe Beef Rolls: 4 stars: good flavor and bundled up in cucumber and spices, the mix of flavors were great and jumpstarted my palette well. East feeds west: 5 stars: tender organic pork shank with just the right sauce. I'm not a huge carnivore but this was SO GOOD. The lotus wrapped yellow curry rice was a nice complement and reminded me of the rice in the green leaves they serve at dim sum. Add on the cucumber salad and this dish is a winner and welll worth the $22!! Highly recommended!Millionaire's bacon: 5 stars: 2 slices of deliciously thick bacon doused in maple syrup and made to perfection. A little expensive at $12, but you can't leave here without trying it! No need to be a bacon lover (I'm not), you'll still like the dish!! My mouth is watering as I think about it... yum! First I should say, I am totally obsessed. I've been here 5 or 6 times now and every time I go it's a wonderful experience. I always get the Finger Lickin' (fried chicken with the most incredible curry sauce) and the Burgah Boy, which is probably one of my favorite burgers of all time. Their millionaire's bacon is ridiculously good, so anything you can get with it is a good choice. Their salads are also wonderfully tasty and a bit spicy. Really, you can't really go wrong with anything on their menu - everything I've ever gotten has been outstanding. I also love how cheerful and attentive everyone there is and I love the little touches (they seem to always bring a little something like biscuits or homemade sweet potato chips while you wait). All in all, it's a wonderful experience! I've been several times - brunch is typically mobbed. The brunch food is good, but not as creative as their standard menu.Incredible food, with great presentation. I love the ambiance - especially after dark - the lighting would make this nice for a romantic evening.Recommendations: the ahi scoops, any of their soups, and of course the bacon. Went here just after they opened.  As a gluten-free person, it's almost always the first thing I ask about. I was excited that they accommodate by using gluten-free soy sauce so that i didn't have to completely change up what i wanted. I ordered the fried rice, my wife ordered a vegetarian dish.Then...we waited...and waited...and waited.  When we arrived there was only 2 other tables that had been seated.  About 45 min after we ordered and noticed that the tables had filled up, my wife's entree came out. She said it was really good.  But we waited for mine.  We noticed several more people's food and our server assured us mine was on it's way.  About 20 min later, I asked again and the server came back and said that they had a mix up but it was coming out now.  When it arrived, it had two long vermicellie noodles sticking out of it.  I asked, "is this gluten-free?" and she said "oh...no.  oops.  I'll have to have yours remade."  Bottom line, they forgot about mine and tried to just make one real quick.  I asked them to make it to go as we were done and leaving.  The next day, when i had my food for lunch, i was amazed at how good it was.  It was very flavorful and i really liked it.Sadly, the experience tainted the restaurant for us and i don't know that we will return. (See pics) Review #1345. The lunch menu is happily filled with eggs on almost all dishes! And this is definitely fast moving to become my favourite eatery!Ribeye omurice is my favourite. It was with ground beef was mixed with rice and covered with scrambled eggs, and poured with some delicious glaze. It also came with a house made biscuit that was also very tasty. It also came with crispy small potato bites that were fresh and nice crunchy.The one thing was the scrambled egg did not seem to have egg white in it?Egg pancakes was also pretty good and not as substantial quantity.Each dish is beautifully presented. It's like edible art. And the portion was not small with some actually were quite big. My colleagues all liked their burger dishes and classic benedict on thick toast.The house made raspberry sauce was also quite good as a condiment.Apparently the raspberry lemonade was refillable.The place has a nice setting and even had red pepper plants on the table (rather than flowers.) Service was very sweet friendly. Will definitely have to check out the dinner menu as it is quite different. quite impressed!  Brunch was fun, inventive and delicious.  The wait staff was somewhat indifferent, but the host was funny and welcoming.  Food came out quick enough and was as good as it sounded. Cute place next to Ike's Place.  We stopped here for breakfast and were excited to try the millionaire's bacon that all the yelp reviewers were raving about, but they said they ran out.. (but it was only Tuesday?!)  I ordered the two eggs, with chicken mango sausage, and rainbow potatoes.  Eggs are eggs, the potatoes had good texture, and the chicken mango sausage was decent, but overall this dish is probably something I could have cooked on my own.  On the other hand, great service, clean restaurant, cute location on the corner next to Ike's Place, i HATE being the person who drags a review down...i think small businesses are great and deserved to be recognized. however, i also try to be an "honest yelper" and my honest opinion is that this place wasn't anything that special.our waitress was nice and attentive, which was really nice. the seating is cute with a lot of outdoor lighting, which is exactly what you want for a hangover brunch (lets be real, everyone in their is hungover!). there is even seating outside for those hooligans that are so hungover they need some fresh air.what really brought the score down for me was the food. i just didnt think it was anything special. i will say this with an asterisk* that i really liked my friends' omelets. those were yummy! unfortunately, the ordered the tilapia burger and the sheer size of the bread overpowered any texture or flavor you could taste from the tuna. i ultimately just ended up removed the bread and eating the tuna on its own, which of course was a pitiful size. that was yummy, but once again, was not how it was meant to be ordered.i would actually want to go this place a 3.5 but hey, you gotta choose a whole number and i was overall unimpressed. i do want to come back and give it another chance, because the overall environment was cool. a lot of cuties in the restaurant :) 06-March, WednesdayBy the time we had plated ourselves to a small helping of each of our dishes -one would have thought we had just attended an international pot-luck, although everything was cooked quite well, each dish was such an odd and ineffective pairing of flavors.  1. The Finger-licking is probably a pseudonym for a stomach ache with its batter fried chicken breasts, russet potato wedges, coconut yellow curry as the dipping sauce. This dish comes with a light cucumber side-salad to make up for everything else you're about to clog your arteries with.. but I guess similarly this appears to be a deconstructed, and reconstituted take on the traditional Thai yellow curry with chicken and potatoes.  2. Big Hug: thick slab of bacon wrapped around a bay scallop, grilled eggplant drenched in sauce, cilantro sauce, and garlic egg noodle on the side.  This dish appears to be an inverted type of burger void of a bun, whereas the alternative for the carb comes as a side of flat noodles.. hrrm, something seems off.I don't miss Tangerine one bit, but it would have been nicer if something else would have filled this space other than just another ill-conceived Asian fusion restaurant. Kitchen definitely gets 5 stars for presentation and their lavish interiors, but somewhere along the way the story gets very convoluted and lost. I heard this place is great for brunch, but I only came here for dinner. This place is very cute and nicely decorated. The service is terrific! I got a pad thai and it was really good, but I won't give  the full 4 stars because I have had better pad thai. The presentation is really nice though! The portions are really big, so come here with an appetite or share a plate. I'd come here again if I am in the area! A nice restaurant in Castro. The menu is not that long, but there was a fantastic variety. I was going for Dad's Spicy & Sour Soup with Tiger prawns, three mushrooms, Galangal, Kaffir lime leaves, lemongrass. For 8 a good choice. Really yummie and frehs but also really spicy. ;-) I found the small portion quite big. As mains Kitchen Story offers Pad Thai noddles with a choice of tofu, chicken, pork or beef or prawns starting from 10 to 14 $ (prawns). And you shouldn' miss the selection of different Curries served with Roti bread or Rice again with your choice of tofu, chicken, pork or beef or prawns. The curry varies from Red Curry with bell pepper, bamboo shoots and basil to Panang Curry with avocado, peanut, bell pepper, basil, crispy yam to Pumpkin Curry with bell pepper, basil, crispy yam. Most of my colleagues were going for the Burgah" Boy with Maple Syrup Wagyu Patty, Millionaire's Bacon, Vermont White Cheddar, a rugula super crispy russet wedges and housemade pickle for $18. This one is supposed to be really yummie! The service was really good and the food was served very quickly after ordering. I would definitively come back! This place is phenomenal. Honestly. A MUST TRY. **Best Burger in SF IMHO**My sister and I went for a Monday holiday brunch meal and it was great.  I had the California Burger and it was out of this world. The candied bacon, oh my god. So good.My sister had the beef salad and felt similarly as I did. ExcellentI cannot wait to go back and try more of their food. I really loved this place!  All dishes were amazing and there was a fantastic variety.  I would definitely go back! We've been here at least a half dozen times. The food is tasty and the service is very good but  the noise level is so high you literally can't hear the person across the table from you. With wood surfaces everywhere sounds ricochet. I'm not sure we will return. We had three dishes and shared.  Everything was good.  My favorite was the crispy tofu and peanut salad!  Fresh and tasty!   The Castro seafood curry was just a tad too spicey, but the tacos and East Feeds West pork were amazing.  It is definitely worth a return. Despite the description, this place is GREAT for kids! We took our 2 year old here for dinner tonight. The waiter stored our stroller, brought out a cup of water with a lid and straw immediately, and gave her a small bowl of rice without us even asking! We had mom's coconut soup (piping hot and yummy), pumpkin curry with pork (slightly spicy, liked the avocado slices on top) and a "burgah boy" (awesome burger). We'll definitely be back, I hope this place makes it becasue I don't think the location is ideal for foot traffic. I heard it had great thai food so I went here for lunch. THERE WAS NO THAI FOOD. It's almost like two different restaurants depending on the time you go. If you go for dinner: Expect Thai food. If you go for breakfast or lunch: expect California Cuisine. The brunch food was good but again, I went there for the thai. Loved that they remodeled the restaurant nicely after Tangerine left as one must do these days when taking over another restaurant.  While their service is only so-so, the food, especially for brunch was excellent.  Their Millionaires Bacon was simply amazing and both entrees we ordered were very good as well.  It is rare that I would say how good a restaurant is based on brunch.  I am interested in seeing what dinners there are like... This is my new favorite brunch spot.  Do yourself a favor and go for the crack/cocaine I mean millionaires bacon.  I'm not a connoisseur, but I can't imagine pancakes better than the ones here ok fine i admit I think about them more than what is probably considered "healthy" by most medical professionals DON'TJUDGEME go to kitchen story/ All I can say is yum.  Been here for brunch and dinner.  Excellent comfort food done creatively  and deliciously.  Man, I wish I'd found this place earlier! Kitchen Story has amazing food, but for the type of foodie I am it's absolutely inappropriate. I'm much more a cheap eats sort of guy than a fancy California cuisine. I LOVED their sweet potato chips, I loved the feeling of the restaurant decor (nice tables), the staff was professional and courteous. We ordered the Ahi Scoops, Short Rip Tacos, and the Big Hug. My only complaint is portion size (but for all you SF skinnies this might be perfect) especially for the price of the food. But i understand because it's a totally very nice upscale restaurant, while my tastebuds are very plainclothes. Everything was delicious and that Millionaire's Bacon will kill ya! This place is pretty awesome -- and the 'millionaire bacon' is definitely worth the extra four bucks.  This review is based only on breakfast, but what was especially interesting for me was the wider choice of not-sweet breakfast items, like the okonomiyaki pancake.  I am definitely going to try the salt & pepper French Toast next time.  The sweet things are great too -- the lemon ricotta pancake was fantastic.  and the coffee was really good, as you'd expect. Last night I randomly stopped to eat at this restaurant, and was incredibly pleasantly surprised. The customer service was great. The ambiance was nice. Most importantly, the food was absolutely fantastic! I was a big fan of Tangerine (former restaurant in Kitchen Story's location), so was bummed it closed. I sort of was boycotting this new place. My mistake, as this is hands down one of my best dining experiences in a bit. Every dish we ordered was so good; in fact we ordered one of the dishes twice. This dish is called "Millionaire Bacon". Can I just say..."OMG"?! Succulent, tasty from the very first bite and leaves a very nice lingering taste on the pallet. Highly recommend this new place! Kudos to the chef and the staff. So my first experience here was on New Years. We started with a group of 14 people and KS was one of the only places that would let us make a reservation without a charge for canceling, which was a huge relief since, naturally, our number shrank down to about 10 a few hours before. It's so super cozy in there and everyone is so friendly! Really great vibe and the food that night was tasty.BUT THEN!!! I went there for brunch. Listen: out of control. The ricotta pancakes were mind blowing, as was the millionaire's bacon. I was spying on everyone's food around me and it all looked equally amazing. Can't wait to go back!! I went there last night for the first time. I was happy to find a place that would serve us at 9pm in the Castro. The food and service were excellent. The decor of the place is also very nice, a departure from the usual cheap Castro look.Highlights: chicken coconut milk soup (really a Tom ka gai), one of the best I have had, and the pad see ew, so yummy I would have licked the plate.I'll definitely go back on a regular basis. The ambiance and style of this California Cuisine restaurant is amazing. The food is so good and presented so artfully you almost dont want to break into your dish and change the way it looks. Spicy blends of California and Thai or Southeast Asian style foods give this place a unique menu. The decor and ambiance is lovely and is suited for couples and larger groups. Service is fantastic. Not sure about other meals, but brunch here paints a pretty picture. I got the 2 eggs with one of their signature dishes, the millionaire's bacon, which is thick cut bacon marinated in syrup for hours and basically tastes like sweetened beef jerky and is somehow simultaneously crispy and soft at the same time. A fun and unique offering to be sure, but I wasn't over the moon about it. The rainbow potatoes that come with it are perfectly crispy and not greasy, yet soft on the inside. My eggs over easy were cooked perfectly, with the yolk runny but not stampeding all over my plate, and I delighted in dipping my butter croissant in the gooey eggs and then using the strawberry jam provided on the table to deliver myself a sweet crunch. I also ordered a latte which was made with the perfect milk/foam/espresso ratio. Overall I was happy with the food.Note: They don't allow substitutions on their entrees for some reasonI really love the rustic atmosphere of this place, with the driftwood tables, open facing kitchen, and wide windows facing the street on two sides. There's an extra home-y feel added to it by the books stacked on shelves on one wall, as if you were just sitting in someone's extra fancy kitchen. Service was quick and non-invasive, and because of its close proximity to Dolores Park I would definitely come back here for a brunch/park day combo on a lazy afternoon. Been here twice for breakfast only and essentially it's Sweet Maple: Castro.  The eggs were fluffy and light, and although I didn't get the Millionaire's Bacon,  the regular bacon is pretty solid.  Service is pleasant and the interior is bright and chill.  The butter that comes with the croissant is super tasty too and the potatoes are just right.  Definitely will be another go to brunch spot in my hood! Gee, I didn't even get a chance to try Tangerine, but it sounds like it was in the same culinary ballpark as this new-fangled Asian-fusion brunch spot in the Castro. My friend Carlos was out from New York, so I was trying to think what would be new and hip that we could try for Sunday brunch. 'Brunch' is our euphemism for not being morning people and eating breakfast at noon. I had never heard of Kitchen Story before, but Carlos was told by his local buddy that we had to try the Millionaire's Bacon, the best thing on the menu.For some reason, I was thinking this would be a more basic-looking space, maybe because I inexplicably kept playing word association in my head with "Tokyo Story", the classic movie that was all about self-sacrifice and living simply. But this is the Castro, for Harvey's sake. Of course a new eatery there has to offer fashion-forward breakfast plates like an omelette with pork wine sausage and lemongrass and a deep-fried French toast stuffed with mascarpone. You can still find bacon and eggs, it's just that you have to look harder to find it.Carlos decided to try the $11 Classic Benedict, a pair of tightly poached eggs sitting atop a pork wine sausage patty, which in turn, sat atop a slice of levain toast. The Meyer lemon hollandaise sauce was poured liberally over the tower with multi-colored potatoes completing the plate (see photo). He liked his more than I liked mine, the $12 Red and Green Benedict, a vegetarian take with wilted spinach, roasted tomato, mushrooms, and instead of the hollandaise sauce, a fresh mango salsa mixed with some bean sprouts.I also received the same lukewarm potatoes, but without the lubrication of a sauce, it came across as dry and rather bland (see photo). That was a bit of a shame since the ingredients were quite fresh and the dramatic presentation befitting of the Castro in its theatricality. But I do have to say the aforementioned Millionaire's Bacon, which we ordered as a shared side dish, did live up to its hype - a couple of strips, thickly cut and candied in maple syrup, chiles and honey (see photo). It was indeed the best thing on the menu. And my coffee cup was never empty.FOOD - 3 stars...pretty presentation but blandness prevails with their benedict dishesAMBIANCE - 3 stars...busy but not too hecticSERVICE - 3 stars...attentive but bordered on intrusive with plates being picked up prematurelyTOTAL - 3 stars...a bit more spice and a mite less strain on the service might elevate my rating the next time Their "signature" bacon appetizer was basically was just really spicy bacon that's drenched in syrup.  We ordered the "Dancing Queen" which was merely a few stingy pieces of steak over this big bowl of rice carbs.  My "Fingers licked" better from going to Jack in the Box last night.  Average Food trying to be unique by pulling a few stunts that is not worthy of mentioning. The "purgatory" dish is unreal . So delicious 5 stars for breakfast/brunch! 4 stars for dinner.  I first came here for brunch, ordered the steak with rice and gravy (forgot the name of the actual dish, but I believe it's the most expensive breakfast dish on the top left corner of the menu) and it was so freaking good! Had a nice mimosa to go with that as well.  Came back recently for dinner, and ordered 3 appetizers: Castro tower, Crispy Calamari, and the Kobe rolls. All three appetizers were delicious and very yummy!  However, when I ordered the main course, "Big Hug" and tried my date's "Dancing Queen", I was a bit disappointed. The "Big Hug" had their famous millionaire bacon with it, but for me it was just too sweet. It's tasty, but just too much. And when I tried the "Dancing Queen", it looks nice and flashy, the steak was cooked perfectly, but the alcohol they use to pour over the rice to light it on fire made the rice taste disgusting. If you like alcohol (i think its' Bacardi 151 rum) flavored rice then be my guest and try ordering it, but I personally thought it tasted nasty.  Had dessert as well and was disappointed again that they have "Choco Cake" on the menu, but later informed us after we ordered it that they were "out", and this was around 630-7pm.   Overall, appetizers and service was great, not outstanding, but good. I'd highly recommend the appetizers here. No thank you to the main courses. But definitely would love to come back here for breakfast/brunch. On my first visit I was taken back by the price of the millionaires bacon (quantity versus price ratio) and the dry biscuits. However, I've returned many times and have been impressed every time. I've developed a fondness for their Thai fried rice with prawns,  amaze-balls! Also, the biscuits have been fresh every time I've returned, I'm guessing the first experience was a rarity. The service has always been top notch and unfortunately word must be getting out about this restaurant. Dinner time, especially on the weekends, is extremely busy. Increased my rating from 3 star to 5 star I'm not quite sure how this happened, but at like 9:30 this morning, me and the boy walked in the door to Kitchen Story and were seated immediately. On a Sunday. For brunch. Whaaaa?Though, to be honest, I had never heard of the place, so it's mostly the boy's incredulity I'm channelling because apparently there was a line out the door when he had been there the last time.Anyway, the food was super yummy, and for a pretty great price, especially for the area. I had the Mom's Benedict, which was super flavorful, and I really have no complaints (eggs cooked perfectly, hollandaise not glumpy, bread not too chewy, potatoes [loved that they were rainbow] crispy without being dry), except that it could have used a smidge more acid. That could just be personal preference though since I tend to prefer my hollandaise super lemony. Also, I wish my plate had been a tad smaller. Like the actual plate. The potatoes were pushed to the far edge so it looked like two different dishes. Empty space on a plate that is just set in front of you is just a little offputting, in my opinion. Or I'm being weird.Either way, I would return. Just after I hit all the other great brunch spots in SF Initially bummed to discover Tangerine gone tonight, we dined at its replacement, Kitchen Story, by default; the menu looked promising, the decor inviting and the vibe intimate and comfortable.  Overall, we were both pleased with our experience tonight.  We were seated at a table for two without much of a wait, and our server was extremely attentive and friendly throughout despite the busy Saturday evening.  We ordered the Millionaire's Way to start, which was an organic asparagus, crispy bacon and maple syrup sauce concoction.  It was pretty good, but the intensity of the bacon and sweetness of the maple sauce needed more than three small, thin sprigs of asparagus to make it a total winner (5 stars in the originality department, though)  Our mains were a medium spice red chicken curry (which was actually really, really spicy but still good) and the Finder Lickin', which was the night's clear victor: perfectly battered fried chicken, expertly prepared potato wedges, a nice cucumber salad and innovative coconut dipping "sauce".  The portions were also generous and everything came out at just the right temperature. Minor annoyances: No refills on soda, and a $3 price tag for a 12 oz. can. Kinda ridiculous.Feels slightly overpriced in general, actually. No alcohol and we paid $70 with tip.Again, medium spice= mouth lavaDespite the mild hiccups, I'm a fan of this Castro newcomer (someone finally broke the neighborhood's bad eats curse); with its friendly, efficient service, tasty food, and warm, cozy ambiance, I would definitely return for another page out of the Kitchen Story. I am a huge fan of this place. The menu has a unique Asian flair that is delicious and always interesting. The portions are very generous for the prices and the atmosphere is homey and cozy.  The staff are all very nice and give incredible service (I don't think my glass was every half empty for more than a minute).I came for dinner the week it opened and we ordered the Dancing Queen and East Feeds West. The presentation was impeccable (complete with flames!) and the dishes were absolutely divine.I've also come in for brunch with people that have completely different kinds of tastes (Including a vegetarian. I, on the other hand, eat most everything) and they were throughly impressed as well. On the brunch menu, I've had the Chicken Mango Melt, Franciscan Scramble and the Ribeye Omurice. All were delicious, although the Omurice could have had sliiiiiiggghty more ribeye :)I brought a group of 13 for brunch on an extremely busy Saturday- not an easy task to handle. However, they served our group with precision- orders were all correct and timely and their service was still on point. I will be coming back many times over. I live in the neighborhood so I would be thrilled to see this place thriving for many, many years to come. Go check it out! Bravo Kitchen Story! Thanks for the wonderful evening last night. Sorry we stayed past close. We just couldn't get enough. We really enjoyed every dish. The Pad Thai, the Green Curry, the Fried Calamari, the Hot & Sour Soup, the Short Rib Tacos, the Chocolate Cake - all we delicious and I will order each and every one again next time. It was so nice to meet the chef and talk to your servers who care so much about good food. You didn't just do a great job with the food and service you also did a remarkable job with the design of the restaurant. I really cannot wait to come back again. Next time I must come for brunch. See you soon. xoxo Overall: Pretty good food, but prices a bit steep for what's offered.Chicken Satay: Wonderful.
