Wagyu beef burger was expensive as hell and was about en par with Super Duper across the street on Market. Beef shank was nice, moist and flavorful, and crunchy on the outside. Great rice with spices as well. 3.5 stars for now - I think this place has the potential to be 4 or even 5 stars, and I do plan to give it a second chance in a few months, especially since I still have to try the millionaire's bacon.I'd been hearing rave reviews about this place from foodie friends, so I decided to check it out solo during a rare free Sunday afternoon.  I ordered the Franciscan scramble and a Bloody Mary (my first time trying it with soju, as they don't have a full liquor license).  The food was pretty good (would have earned 4 stars) - in particular, I found the chicken mango sausage in the scramble delightful and slightly unusual, and the potatoes were delicious. I usually don't eat the potatoes that come with a scramble at all, and here I finished the entire side.  On the other hand, the bloody mary was not quite what I was looking for.  I like my bloodies to have an even consistency, where thick, spicy tomato juice is the heart of the drink, accented by a punch from the (ideally) vodka.  KS's drink lacked the spicy kick I was hoping for and tasted a bit watery.  As I've never had it before with soju, I'm not sure if this was the fault of the soju or the fault of the tomato juice that they used.  It also seemed to have a lot of particles in it - I think celery, but I wouldn't swear to it.  The additional 0.5 star deduction is for a couple of snafus that occurred with my food.  My scramble originally came out unevenly heated - the outside of the meal was warm, but the inside was unpleasantly cold.  I let the waitress know, and she took it back to warm it up - and then when it was returned to me, it was missing the side of fruit, which I had to ask for.  I could tell that the staff had been trained in response to previous Yelp comments.  They definitely were sure to check in with me regularly to make sure everything was going well, and they did address my concerns when I shared them.  I like that this restaurant seems responsive to constructive feedback, and I hope my comments in this paragraph are taken in that light.I also liked the post-Tangerine remodeling of the place.  Looking forward to giving this restaurant a second shot for brunch in a few months, and I'll update the star rating if warranted. I was delaying coming to visit here for awhile since it seemed like the menu was all over the place (California-Asia-Breakfast-Burger). I live a couple of blocks away and I'm glad I finally came. This place is great! I went at dinner time and the menu seemed pretty consistently Cal-Asian. My Panang Curry was super flavorful and the fried chicken and chicken noodles were terrific according to the rest of our party. They've done a really good job of remodeling from what used to be Tangerine. Service was friendly, efficient and fast. I can't wait to try other items in the menu. Came for brunch on a late Monday morning. Place was relatively empty...I guess everyone else has a job or something. :) :/ : The food was pretty good. I liked my "KS's own omelet", and opted for the berries mix instead of the potatoes. The $2 extra was definitely worth it for a berry addict like myself. I also love that every entree I see come out had this crispy stick thing poking out of it skyward. It was edible but mostly for decorative purposes. I just appreciate that they put in that little bit of extra effort to spruce things up.The servers were very attentive and gave us the semi-pro-tip of putting the jam on the cheese biscuit. Sweet and savory and best.Will definitely come back again! I was super impressed with both the food and the service.  Great comfy vibe with food that has extra flavor than average.  Staff is nice and wait is short.  Doesn't disappoint. Short wait (~15 mins around 12pm), great service, delicious food, cute decor. I decided to get the artichoke watercress pesto benedict with bacon, which was so good-- one of the best eggs benedicts I've ever had. The dish also comes with mixed potatoes and a couple pieces of fruit. My boyfriend and I also decided to order a side of their MIllionaire's bacon after seeing pictures on Yelp. If you're wondering what it is, imagine regular bacon twice as big, coated in maple syrup of some sort. Amazing. I definitely recommend this place and wouldn't mind going again. A solid 4 star breakfast experience, and I will be back for dinner. I went here after Yoga with 2 others and we were all happy. The service was very friendly and fast. We had standard breakfast items but they were all above average, and my breakfast potatoes with fried onions and cheese were OUTSTANDING. I want to try the millionaire's bacon next time which is apparently slow cooked for 4 hours. We just beat the Sunday rush and judging by the lines and how full the place was, our experience was not out of the ordinary. Recommended. Get the French Toast.  Don't regret it.  Drink bottomless mimosas :)  Service was great. A "asian-fusion" restaurant that was not pretentious, FINALLY! Oh yes the prices were super affordable, minus the side order of "millionaire's bacon" which is approximately $6.50, yikes.  I opted for the BLT Panini instead which comes with the bacon, and the most delicious rosemary fries EVER. I dear not lie. They were the most addicting wedge cut rosemary fries too. The oil was fresh. The fries were perfect, each wedge. How do they do it? Golden and crispy on the outside, pillowy and hot on the inside. Not greasy at all!The BFF ordered the ribeye omurice, and whoa was it hearty but super delicious. The egg omelet was fluffy and the whole dish came with home fries and this wonderful chive cheese biscuit with their homemade jam. I think I found a new favorite brunch place in SF. Yes parking can be difficult here, but I like who it's not hipstery/pretentious. The menu provided lots of options which was great too. I'm not going to lie, I was pretty disappointed in Kitchen Story.  My company was excellent, but the food was not worth the cost.  I had the Finger Lickin' and while I enjoyed the fried chicken, the potatoes were crispy but tasteless.  The side of yellow curry, which is what most excited me about the dish, was unbelievably bland.  I dipped everything on my plate into it hoping that eventually I would be rewarded with a modicum of flavor, but was deterred at every depression of my fork.  The introductory salad was forgettable.  I was also not impressed with the Pinot Grigio they serve.  Our server was prompt, but awkward.  Had I paid $6 less for my meal this would be three stars, but given the hype, I just don't see the reward for indulging in a Kitchen Story. Newly opened in November, but Kitchen Story reeks of the space's previous tenants, Tangerine; Asian fusion, mediocre brunch...I'm experiencing déjà vu. Every portion of my brunch plate underwhelmed me. Biscuit--dry, chewy, undercooked? Rainbow potatoes--like the concept of three different potatoes, but these were dried out & overcooked. Athenian omelet--arugula, goat cheese, olives, mushrooms...eggs could have stood to be fluffier. I tried to make an open table reservation, but no tables were available. Funny, between 10-11am when we brunched, the restaurant was only half full, so what's up with that drama?Dishes were served quickly. Our waiter had a good sense of humor. But, dull food & so-so quality does not make me want to spend my brunch bucks here a second time. Maybe I'm destined to not like any restaurant in this particular space. It was winter break of my final semester of school ever (maybe) which meant bottomless mimosas on monday at 3pm. Bottomless mimosas for 18? Excellent. Lucky for us, a reporter was on hand to capture the moment and publish it in the WSJ. (Yes, I'm that awkward red head holding her fork like a gremlin.)Entrees? Also excellent. I ordered the pork bibimbap and holy hell it was fantastic! Like really really good! And the portion was huge, I definitely enjoyed the left overs for dinner. I thought it might need sriracha but no, it was great and flavorful as presented. Looking forward to many a boozy brunch here with my mancat and my girls. Cute Asian Fusion place. Came here on a sunday night. Ordered their chicken satay which was so good with the roti and their cucumber and carrots. For entree I ordered their pad sew which was very flavorful. This place i heard has great brunch. Still need to come here for their brunches. Really cute place near the castro, yet parking was a bit hard to find. My new favorite restaurant!!The food was EXCELLENT as was the service, environment, speed at getting food to the table, cleanliness, and given all of that so was the price.  A friend took me there to dinner during the week so we were seated immediately and the start of our food was at the table 10 minutes after ordering.  It is probably more crowded on the weekends at for brunch.  The best was the bacon which was more like smoked, crisped, sweet pork belly.  The french fries were fresh and crisp and by far the best in the Castro.  Hmmmm, maybe the hamburger was too ... and the bacon ... and the soup ... and the samosas.   'nuff said.  TRY IT!! Food is amazing! You have to try the millionaire bacon, it's the kind of thing you cannot get just anywhere.They have a fresh take on brunch. I would've given a perfect score, but my potatoes were charred and inedible, nobody came by to check on us after we got the food. The rest was so amazing I will definitely go back!!!!! PERFECT spot for a friday night dinner date.My boyfriend and I were trying to find a spot to eat in the mission/castro area, and I happen to use yelps "new and hot" filter. Kitchen Story popped up and we were a couple blocks away so decided to give it a try.We got there at about 8:30pm, and expected a wait and were really surprised when we were seated immediately. The decor is adorable and our server was fantastic. He was the best server Ive had eating out in the bay area actually. After hearing his suggestions we ordered the MILLIONAIRES WAY BACON, lady prawns,  Ceviche, Yellow Curry, and the Pad See Ew.The bacon... oh I didn't know bacon could be so magical. It should be the first thing in your mouth at this restaurant. I would skip the Lady Prawns, they were meh and not noteworthy.The Ceviche was done PERFECTLY. The acid balance was perfect and seafood wasn't gummy at all, which is a rarity. I was really impressed!The Yellow Curry was also perfect. The fried potatoes in the curry was a surprising complement to the curry, and frankly I will never look at yellow curry the same way again.Last is the Pad Sew Ew, which took me back to the fiery street stalls on Thailand. This is the best and most authentic version I've had in the US. In fact it is on par with I've had in Thailand.  We also had the desert Pancake, though it was WAY too sweet. Also the comp biscuits are great without the honey butter. The honey butter was also too sweet. I would have given a five star review if it wasn't for that.Im definitely coming back again. Perfect for friends that are in town, and esp now because its new and not to crowed yet :) Great place for breakfast. Not crowded on weekdays, so you can hang out and work. Food is awesome.. potatoes are great and they have millionaire's bacon which has syrup and spice and awesome. They have WiFi from Xfinity, so if you have Comcast at home you can login with your comcast account (the one you use to pay your bill and stuff) for free. I don't know what happens if you don't have comcast.They let me hang out as long as I want, lots of coffee.. full menu. Just a nice place overall. The best bacon, ever. When your review starts with "The best bacon, ever." There's not really far to go. I think this bacon is even better than Mission Beach, which was my previous "Best Bacon, Ever."How do you like this:The best breakfast potatos, too--ever.  Seriously, they're that good. I usually order extra crispy. I'm glad I didn't because they were crispy on the outside and light-hot-fluffy on the inside. I think they're lightly batter coated. Yum. The main egg dish I had was great, too. This place opened near my friend's house and she went there 5 days in a row. Go. That is all. This place still isn't a great place-- sorry Kitchen Story is wonderful for those folks that only remember that they want brunch milliseconds after they enter frothing and ravenous fugue states of hunger. Like me! Though it's always been bustling when I've been (twice now), there is virtually no wait to sit down -- unlike Ike's Place next door. Bonus!The menu declares "California Cuisine" which I guess means "normal" food alongside Asian-inspired touches like a lemongrass omelette or a Okonomiyaki egg pancake. At brunch you can choose from egg dishes, breakfast melts, bennies, scrambles, and something called "sensible breakfast" for the self-hating wusses out there. (Don't order a sensible breakfast, ya dummy.)Because I'm baller as fuck, I definitely added a side order of Millionaire's Bacon to my salt and pepper French toast with spicy ketchup. I also upgraded my dish to a "complete meal" by adding two eggs and meat for $4. Not a bad deal if you're hungry, but it turned out to be overkill. Millionaire's Bacon is not for the faint of wallet ($6.50) nor those on the verge of a heart attack. It's two long hefty strips of coated caramelized bacon with a smoky and spicy kick. It's rich and tasty, though I will never get it again. The French toast, on the other hand, is a definite standout and I really can't get enough of that spicy ketchup. I've ordered it twice now, and will have trouble coaxing myself off it.Great choice for brunch.Obligatory Title Pun: This STORY has a happy ending. (Wait--)Menu Readability: Two column card in no-nonsense sans-serif. Probably made in Pages. Looks fine.Need to mention: Bottomless mimosas are $16.What this place teaches me about myself: Not every breakfast comes with a handjob. This is a wonderful restaurant. I love that there are lots of different options for types of food and for eating a really good, cheaper meal (tasty, fresh $12 pad thai) or a great, more up-scale meal ($20 Waygu steak "Dancing Queen" which was ridiculously good!).The service was very friendly and attentive. Food arrived promptly but well-timed.The decor is well-thought out, feels modern but cozy.Also, the "Castro Tower" app is fantastic, and the Millionaire's Bacon is as good as advertised, enough to make this mostly-vegetarian drool.Highly recommended - we have been many times, both eating in and taking out. Service was a bit shaky but overall the experience was a very good one.  I will definitely go back.The menu is very flexible and interesting, which I like to see.The Millionaire's Bacon is essentially candy.  Deep-fried ricotta stuffed french toast?  Make no mistake, this isn't health food. Two words: Millionaire's BaconThat is all. I haven't gotten a meal here that I didn't like. I eat here at least once a week, if not more. Try The Millionaires Bacon. I don't even like bacon and it was delicious. I went here a couple of days ago with 4 other people for a late breakfast/early lunch.  The place was crowded and buzzing.  Wait time was around 20 minutes and there is a counter to sit at while waiting.  The new owners did a great job remodeling the place...very clean and inviting; complete makeover of the previous Tangerine which I always liked.  I really wanted to like this place; the menu items are very appealing and a good mixture of egg dishes and hamburgers.  I saw plates coming out of the kitchen and they looked pretty fabulous.  While not what I'd call expensive, it is a couple of dollars over most breakfast/lunch restaurants.  We all found service to be polite but very spotty.  Our dishes came out one at a time over the course of 20 minutes.  Water came well after we'd been served.  Finally, tasting what we had been waiting for was a huge disappointment.  The flavors were bland and definitely not worth the price; I could have gotten this meal anywhere.  The Millionaires Bacon, at $6.00 for two medium size pieces was tasty but definitely not worth the price.  I wanted to get up and go into the kitchen and show them how to make a cheddar biscuit and spice up their egg dishes.  That being said, there are not a lot of places in the Castro that look this nice  for breakfast.  I wouldn't go here again unless the really up the quality of what they are serving and get better wait staff where English is not a barrier to good service. Went there last night with a group of 4. Service was timely and the food was phenomenal. Ahi tuna salad was one of the best I've had and "Dad's Spicy Soup" was aptly named--very spicy indeed.They take reservations and are extremely reasonably priced for the area ($12 entrees). I expect to be returning here many times. Had dinner here for NYE and it was a good experience. We ordered the Finger Lickin (fried chicken), Big Hug (scallops and millionaire bacon), Lady Prawns, Da'Da cake (molten chocolate cake with ice cream), and Belly Candy. The fried chicken was good and different with the curry dip, Big Hug was delicious, prawns were average, cake was disappointing (no molten), and Belly Candy (more millionaire bacon) was a great dessert to end our dinner! The server was attentive. If you love bacon, you gotta try this place! I ate here only once but it is enough for me to noticed that the employees and owners put in a lot of time and efforts in getting this place up and running. Everything was superb from food, presentation, flavor, quality, and service. I can assure that in no time this place will become a landmark in the Castro. I had always wondered what they would do with this space once Tangerine closed... I stopped in twice over the past two days (once for a quick, late breakfast and another time for dinner). Service was quite friendly and attentive (as should be expected for the first few months), and the food was tasty. As it's located 1.5 blocks from me, I will likely go again. A bit more than I was hoping to pay given the menu, location, and quality of the fare, however. Everything is better with bacon ... but Millionaires Bacon ... YES PLEASE!The owners of Sweet Maple have nailed it again. Went for dinner last night (Friday) on a last minute Open Table reservation. The place was full but not too full.The Food: Started out with Mama's soup for 2. Perfect size for 2 people. It was light but flavorful. Good for a rainy night!I had the flank steak which was tasty. It had a fresh lime and Bacardi 151 sauce which they poured on and lit on fire table side. 151 and fuego ... count me in!My better half had the Tilapia. It was also yummy. The ginger rice that came with both of our entrees was delish and plentiful.Didn't make it to dessert, but they all looked awesome.The only downside was that we had to wait quite some time for our food. Not a huge deal as we weren't in any rush. The manager and waiter felt quite bad and gave me a free beer. Free beer solves all problems in my book!!!Overall, we'd definitely come back for dinner and can't wait to try it out for brunch. I was excited about going here and I really wanted this place to work. The owner obviously invested a lot of money into the space. The menu, at least at first glance, appears to be creative and well put together. There's a lot of potential here, but something went wrong with the execution.SERVICE - For the caliber of restaurant that this place is trying to be, the staff is not up to the task. The communication issues are a problem. The staff that we dealt with were oblivious to our needs and the natural flow of the dining experience.  Basic things like when to order and how to check on a table, handle refills, etc. - all handled very awkwardly and with much difficulty. All in all, they came off as untrained. With the higher end prices that this restaurant offers, they need to be a little better at servicing that kind of clientele. FOOD - Lots of promise but did not deliver. We came for brunch. I'm big on omelettes and was excited to try theirs. Here's what we got:K.S.'s Own Omelette: The menu description sounded amazing. In reality, it was not that great. It was more of a scramble than an omelette. The lemongrass flavor was overpowering to the point of tasting like an herbal soap. I would not order again nor recommend.Ribeye Omurice: Again, the menu description sounded amazing. This one actually had some delicious, savory flavors, but the description was still misleading. I thought the ribeye was going to be a more prominent element to this dish. Instead, it was egg and spinach over a bed of rice, topped with a gravy that had bits of meat in it. Tasted good, but for the price ($13) it was a letdown. Also, the rice was cold, which took away from the enjoyment.  The cheddar and rosemary biscuits were almost inedible. They were extremely dense and leeched the moisture right out of my mouth. So much promise!    Unfortunately, with so many options in the area, I think its unlikely that I will ever return to give Kitchen Story another shot. This is a tough review to write as I really wanted to like this place as I do love breakfast and there aren't too many fab options in this area... but I just can't.Went in with my two friends and their newborn (in a stroller) and rambunctious 3 year old. Needed a highchair for her and was told they only have one and it was in use. Odd but true.We then get our menu's and I request a cup of coffee... 30 minutes later, after ordering and my friends had gotten their latte's, I then re-ask for my simple black coffee to the woman who had brought the drinks. She says "ok" and walks into the back aka opposite of where the coffee is without telling anyone (I later figured out she doesn't speak much English). I then flagged down our waiter who, after checking the coffee pot, informs me from across the room that they have to brew some... I coulda gone down the block, gotten some and of returned in less time!Another 30 minutes and our food arrives. I had asked for scrambled egg whites and got regular eggs; this is when I found out the server didn't understand English as when I asked her if they were "whites only" she replied "yes" and smiled. When I asked the waiter, he then asked the cook who said they weren't (good news: they recooked my eggs and were all whites!). My eggs were accompanied by frozen potatoes with cheddar cheese on top (how hard is it to cook fresh?) and a raw in the center biscuit. I can't speak for my friends meals as they were starving after an hour of waiting and gobbled theirs up so fast all I heard were grunts.Did I mention that they forgot the 3 year olds meal and it arrived 10 minutes later? That is forever to a little kid, and even longer to the adults with her...After all these mis-steps. the bill for 3 adults and a kid for a simple breakfast came out to just over $70 with tip... that's a bit much for what we got in terms of service and food. I really hope that Kitchen Story steps up, cooks fresh and can make the space work as they did a very cute remodel and seem like nice people who are just in a bit over their heads. 3.5 starsService: 5 starsEnvironment: 5 stars. Clean and modernSalmon: 3 stars. Too fried.Fried chicken: 4 stars. Overall, it's Thai food, with American dishes that have a Thai twist. I am really torn about this review. I do want to give this new restaurant more stars, as we did have a nice dinner here and there were several excellent aspects to our meal, however, overall, I wasn't overwhelmingly impressed. I'd say our experience was a 3.5 star one for now.  I must say I love the atmosphere and the space...the open design and large windows, as well as bookshelves that add coziness to the place.  The service was great, very attentive.  Our wine glass stayed full throughout the meal. We did not have to wait long for anything.  And when my boyfriend wanted to order the fried chicken dinner, but did not want the curry sauce that it came with, the manager brought out three other dipping sauces for him to try.  I must say there was one thing that turned us off a bit.  The server tried to refill our wine glasses so often that after a little while it began to feel overbearing.  Mind you, we would only take a few sips each and the glasses would be still full, but he'd be back to our table pouring even more into the glass.  We even joked about it, like, "ok mofos, chug the damn wine bottle you brought with you and make a goddamn purchase from us". That's what it felt like.  After refill number two, we politely told the waiter that we were ok on wine and will refill the glasses ourselves in a little while.  He let us be after that :-)My favorite dish was the Millionaire's Bacon appetizer.  It was fantastic.  I could have eaten this slow cooked bacon and asparagus with maple syrup sauce all night long. Im craving it right now.  The prawn appetizer was good, but nothing that stood out.The dishes we ordered were The Dancing Queen and Finger-licking' fried chicken. They were fine, good even, but again, nothing that stood out or was fantastic.  I have had better fried chicken at a couple of other SF spots.  I would return, however, as I really did like the restaurant itself and a few other items on their menu looked very intriguing.  The Kobe Beef appetizer that the table next to us ordered really did look amazing. I am hoping to revise the rating to 4-5 stars upon my return. First visit, everything was very good. We will go back before giving the 5th star! Mediocre egg and bacon "melt", my bf thought the CA burger was good.  So loud you can barely hear yourself think much less hear anyone across the table. A friend suggested we meet at Kitchen Story for lunch. He made reservations (a total plus for me) and we met there. We didn't need reservations, as it was a Thursday, and it was quiet inside, but glad we had them just in case. I loved the feel of the place, very cozy and inviting. I was instantly greeted and seated. I had a chai latte and it was delicious. I got a mushroom, red onion and cheddar melt. It was amazing. It came with greens. It was so yummy and really filling. Only $10.00. It was very well priced. We sat and talked forever and no one gave us the stink eye. The staff was very attentive and the food was great and the decor very cute. I will come here again for sure! I'm already dreaming of the mushroom melt again! Went there with a friend on Sunday for lunch. We went there because of the great reviews and the food really was great!  We had the New England Burger with fries and were not disappointed. However, the place doesn't seem to be air conditioned and was quite warm and for being listed as $$, the food seemed expensive. For two burgers and coffee the bill was $50 with tip. Leave it to this cute little hot spot to draw me out of my yelp slumber. Went here a week or two ago, here are my two cents:Food - Delicious. We ordered the fried chicken, garlic asparagus, papaya salad, ahi tuna and cheesecake. Every dish was absolutely delicious. With the exception of the tuna, the chips were great but the fish itself was a bit mushy. Otherwise, food was fabulous. Service - almost annoyingly attentive but overall endearing. You can tell they're new because we had 3 different folks ask us if we needed anything and made sure we were taken care of.Decor - comfy sleek. Don't ask me how they accomplished that combo but you'll get it when you see it. Overall, definitely worth checking out. My boyfriend and I stumbled upon this place on a Saturday night.  We were walking by and after quickly scanning Yelp, decided to give it a try.  Since we didn't have a reservation, they asked if we'd mind sitting at the bar and we were promptly seated.  From our first interaction with the staff, it was clear that everyone was very happy to be working there and wanted to see the place succeed.  From where we were sitting, we could clearly see all the food that was coming out of the kitchen, and our mouths began to water.  We ordered a coconut chicken soup, a tuna tartare with mango and two entree-sized salads.  Including the bread and dessert, everything we ate was 100% delicious.  This is the first 5-star restaurant review I've written in ages, but well worth it.  Our meal and service were so good, we decided to return the following morning to give brunch a shot.  The menu was inventive and we really enjoyed our food, but perhaps only a tad less than dinner the night before. We'll be adding this restaurant to our regular rotation and cannot recommend it enough. Kitchen Story, only open since the end of November, is a great place for brunch and they actually take reservations - brilliant!  The Castro needed more brunch options - confirmed by the amount of people with no reservations willing to wait for a table or the bar.If you come for the brunch, you must get or share the millionaire's bacon, which is two slices of thick-cut bacon with perfectly rendered fat candied in what tasted like brown sugar, maple syrup, chili flakes and maybe even soy sauce. Amazing. It is worth the $6.50 for a side, but you can get it for $2.00 when added to another dish (but only specific breakfast dishes all this addition).Also a must to get or share is the mascarpone stuffed deep-fried french toast. Decadent. The egg dishes were better than average with fresh & interesting ingredients, the potato wedges were extra crispy and seasoned perfectly. I have a recommendation for the New England burger, which I hear oozes maple syrup goodness, so I must try it on my return... and I will return. I was desperate to like this place. The menu tries pretty hard to be good, but the staff just aren't up to it. They don't seem to be able to communicate effectively with customers. I might give it another go if I'm feeling brave. KS's own omelet with pork wine sausage, lemon grass, asparagus, bell peps and soy sauce was so fresh and delicious! Ribeye omurice had a wonderful savory flavor. Millionaire's bacon was sweet and unique. Service was great and atmosphere for brunch was perfect. Hip, casual, trendy, fun!  Definitely coming back. I REALLY wanted to like this place! I've been to 3 of the previous restaurants in this seemingly cursed location, and the mediocrity continues!7x7 Magazine has this place on their list of date spots, which is great if you're speed dating (more on that later).Negatives:- Even though they only had 2 reservations a 6pm, they couldn't confirm my reservation. I had to point out my own name on their reservation list! Sad.- Even though there were only 3 tables occupied, we were seated at the most dreary, cave-like table possible (check out my food pic for proof!). The people a couple tables over were even using their cell phone lights to read the menu.- Less than an hour into dinner, we ordered another round of wine and declined dessert. They QUICKLY brought our check, had us sign and took it away. This is normally fine, but they also set the 2-top table next to us for three people while the waiting party breathed on top of us from the bar. I swear they must have pushed the other table closer to ours because the third menu was practically touching our table! Omg, we get the hint! We are no longer customers and should leave! That's just wrong. That's what I meant about speed dating above, this place seems to care more about volume than service. Even the table on the other side us felt it. I overheard when they sat down, whispering that they needed to eat quickly because their table was reserved soon. Sheesh! If you can't fit a party in for a decent dinner, please don't seat them and rush them! We had a reservation and STILL felt rushed! Last time I checked, an hour isn't a long seating for dinner.- Don't order anything with garlic egg noodles! This side is an absolute embarrassment! They tasted like cardboard with dry rot!Positives:- The workers are really sweet when they're not trying to kick you out of your table.- The portions are decent. - My Three Buddies short ribs weren't overly salty. On an even more positive note, thanks Kitchen Story for bringing me back on Yelp!

name: Kitchen Story 3
category: Breakfast & Brunch in San Francisco, CA
review_text: My friend took me here for a weekday birthday brunch. I really like that they're open at 8am so if I ever wanted to have a nice morning breakfast before work (or even just grabbing something to go)DecorReally quaint, and well designed. Muted wood and metal accents, looks really clean. There's a really fun bookshelf wall divider between the main room and the kitchen, and it's filled with accent pieces and books. Any place that provides interesting reading material gets a gold star in my book.ServiceThe waiter was a really nice guy. He seemed like he was really aiming to please and serve us. Really accommodating with the food orders too (substitutions and stuff). A lot of the orders come with a cheddar basil biscuit and potatoes (berries subs for $2 extra), but they let me have a side salad instead of the potatoes so that was fantastic! Checked up on us enough without being overbearing. The food wait time was good too, fairly quick but not blazing.FoodWe ordered the Red & Green Benedict (spinach, mushrooms, tomatoes, mango salsa) and the Franciscan scramble (chicken mango, avocado, pimento, mushroom, celery, jack) The reason why the food wasn't blazing fast for what we ordered was because of the presentation. For a neighborhood brunch spot, their food presentation was incredible. Really gorgeous colorings and arrangements, I could taste the presentation.The food quality was good, but it wasn't out of this world. It's a really solid brunch spot, not too expensive for what you get. I will definitely come back to try their other dishes. Each category of dish has one or two Asian fusion style plates that I really want to try. The Okonomiyaki, Ribeye omurice, Bulgolgi Burger and the Banmi Panini. Good range of choices.I will be back for more! Lovely dinner with my hubby. Service was attentive and knowledgeable without being in the way. The food was delicious- satay, millionaire asparagus, waygu salad and mom's salmon. We'll return for another date night- yum. We all have different experiences an ours was fantastic! People judging a space from what it used to be before is so wrong but many people do it. Tangerine is gone and lets move on. This place the staff so friendly, right on me to see what we wanted, and the food OMG fantastic . The Maple hamburger was off the chart!  The shrimp and bacon we had as starters ...YUMMM.  The bartender even came out an ask us if we were satisfied with our drinks ! thats rare!  But over all I was very impressed and would go back many times and bring lots of friends. It was on the more expensive side but u also get what u pay for . Look at  Frances its very expensive but people love the place and its always booked. so again 2 thumbs up on this new place.. Pluses : delicious food. The Millionaires Bacon was fantastic - the bacon is sweet and spicy and the asparagus was fresh and tender. Thai Fried Rice: the portion was plentiful, the flavor was good just a bit salty. Wild King Salmon: portion was good,  the curry was just right level of spice. Ambiance: the lighting was too bright. They should go for more of the lighting like at Beretta. I asked them to dim the lights but they didn't really dim them very much. For dinner patrons like a different ambiance. They should lower the lights and add candles to the table. Also they brought the can of soda, I think they should pre-pour it. Seemed a bit tacky. I REALLY want this place to do well. Would be 5 stars if they fixed the ambiance. My boyfriend and I tried this place just two days after they had their "soft opening", prepared for some rough edges. There were no rough edges to be found... in fact, this was one of the best dining experiences I've had in months.The restaurant is located in the space formerly occupied by Tangerine. They've redecorated aggressively, and the results are really nice... simultaneously comfortable and cozy. I particularly liked the little pepper plants used as table decorations. They bill their menu as "California cuisine", but it's really mostly Thai fusion.The first surprise was the quick arrival of what would have been the bread basket in most restaurants. They offer biscuits instead of bread (or, rather, instead of nothing, compared to most Thai places). They were good. A bit on the cold side but they were free and had potential.We split a "Millionaire's Bacon" appetizer. While it wasn't quite as fabulous as the menu implied, it was still excellent... thick slices of high-quality bacon, tasting strongly of maple syrup and smoke, together with perfect little asparagus stalks. Highly recommended.I ordered the "Dancing Queen", a flank steak with garlic long beans and a rice and rum sauce. The menu didn't mention one feature of the dish - after setting it on the table the waiter set the high-proof sauce on fire (intentionally). I don't know if the flambée thing enhanced the flavor, but the results were excellent; one of the best steaks I've had recently. My boyfriend had the "Finger Lickin'", a boneless fried chicken breast made with the sort of Thai breading that you would usually see on calamari and some potato wedges. It wasn't  at all greasy, and was cooked just right. They didn't set his on fire but it would have been cool if they did. Service was prompt, professional and friendly, and the prices are surprisingly reasonable (at least by Castro standards). We'll be back! Outstanding new gem in the Castro.I went with my handsome boyfriend the first week they were open. We were politely greeted and seated right away with no reservation. The decor is clean and has a university professor's office who's hipster child decorated it from Pottery Barn and your neighbor's garage sale. The menu has many options. It's not really Californian but more heavily Thai inspired American food or American food inspired by thai, depending on what you order. They have booze. Order some. Freebies: We got some biscuits! They were pretty good. A bit on the cold side. I'm sure they batch make them. I would too. But it's free and who doesn't love carbs. For the appetizer, we got their Millionaire bacon. On the plate we found a few thick slabs of mapely bacon with asparagus in a thick maple sauce. It was quite yummy. It seem to have been featured on a show that I obviously don't watch but it was really good. It shows up in some other dishes that I didn't order so there are a few ways to get a taste of it.I ordered the fried chicken. It had some cute name to it  (finger-lickin') It was a boneless fried a la thai chicken breast. The same style of breading they seem to make fried calamari with at regular thai places. It all came with some potato wedges and some curry dipping sauce. It was all quite good. Crispy and not greasy. Kids would love it too.The sexy boyfriend ordered the flank stake. It was inappropriately named dancing queen as the boyfriend doesn't dance . But his steak came sliced on a bed of garlic rice. And wait there is more! They poured some alcohol on  it and set it on fire. (the steak not the boyfriend). It was quite cool. We didn't catch that in the menu. A nice perk. It was cooked just right. Very yummy. I'm definitely ordering that the next time we go. There were some long beans on the plate for colon health but who really cares about that part. We skipped dessert 'cause we had obicular figures to maintain but they have some.The service was prompt and fast. They checked in on us and made sure we had beverages refilled. My food came out a few minutes ahead of his but no big deal. They had just opened so I'm sure the minor flaws will be worked out at some point.  Prices were very reasonable for the location and the meal. Would definitely go back there with my majestic boyfriend. It's seldom a new eatery gets such consistently good reviews in the first weeks of opening and as such, I was excited to stop by Kitchen Story for weekend brunch. Occupying the former space of Tangerine, a former brunch fave of mine with their zucchini latkes, Kitchen Story has updated the space to give it a more contemporary feel. We arrived around 2pm without a reservation and were seated right away. Note: seating is pretty tight here and you will be quite close to diners on either side. Nothing better than starting out brunch with adult beverages and my bloody mary (yelp.com/biz_photos/kitc…), while not Zeitgeist-good, was very welcomed indeed. They also have bottomless mimosas for $18 if you feel like imbibing more liberally. I was going to order the benedict at first but ended up choosing the KS's own omelet (yelp.com/biz_photos/kitc…) because it came with a side of their cheddar basil biscuit. Unfortunately, said biscuit was nowhere to be found when my plate arrived. When asked about it, the server simply said they ran out and substituted it with bread. Well some heads up when ordering would have been nice; so would an apology or some mention of it when serving the plate. It's a pity because from what I saw from the diners next to us, those biscuits looked good! But with all things said and done, the food was pretty good. Plate presentation is definitely one of Kitchen Story's fortes. Every plate that left the kitchen looked really appetizing. My omelet was light and fluffy and every bite had a nice balance of pork sausage, asparagus, and bell peppers. I was glad they obliged my request to sub out potatoes for a side salad because the salad was perfectly dressed lightly. My friend has the millionaire BLT and from the bite I had of the millionaire bacon, you might want to consider getting a side of these thick cut slices of bacon slow baked with a generous brown sugar rub.   Biscuit fiasco aside, I really enjoyed my food and can't wait to be back for brunch again. On that note, the dinner menu looked really good too. I mean come on... millionaire bacon wrapped scallop? Kitchen Story is a welcomed new eatery to the neighborhood. Had a really great dinner at Kitchen Story during its first week of being open. At some restaurants that would translate into glitches in service, but Kitchen Story is off to a running start. The Millionaire's Way and Tuna Cevice appetizers were amazing, would order both again next time. The short ribs were very good, but the green curry stole the show in the main course. Can't wait to try brunch! Nice remodel.I found the menu a little odd.I did like my side of eggs.They refilled my coffee constantly. Excellent!!!!! Stumbled upon this place while roaming around the Castro district. The food is nothing short of delicious. From the appetizer of the Castro tower to the the Uncle Thai dessert and everything in between. The service was great and the prices are very reasonable. Will definitely recommend this place to friends and family and will dine here again when I'm in town. Stumbled upon kitchen story on Saturday night 12/1/12 and boy was I impressed! Our meal was phenomenal from start to finish! Our server Mita (who was amazing) recommended the Castro Tower for an appetizer. It was delicious! Ahi was fresh & won tons were fried to perfection and packed the perfect kick. For dinner the dancing queen was absolutely amazing and the finger lickin chicken was nothing short of. The perfectly cooked and delicately breaded chicken was served with a curry sauce that was tasty and delicious! Both chicken and combo Pad Thai was exceptional. We also ordered the burger topped with the millionaire bacon which if taste lives up to its name without factoring in price this is it. The best burger in town. For dessert we ordered the uncle tai which is totally unconventional but AMAZING. We will most definitely be back and will recommend Kitchen Story to all our friends and family!! The perfect dinner in the perfect city! Went here for Brunch on a rainy Sunday and was blown away.  I had the Frisco Benedict - it was delicious.    The Millionaire's bacon was fantastic.   We will definitely be coming back! Went here for a weekday breakfast. Got seated immediately and had very friendly, attentive service throughout. We got our breakfast within 15 minutes of ordering and everything came hot and very well presented. Every dish was delicious, and everyone in the party was more than satisfied. Will definitely return here again. I went to the newly opened Kitchen Story with two friends the other night before heading to the Castro Theatre. It's an excellent place. The decor is warm, homey, casual, and stylish. The food was tasty and well-prepared. I had the "Dancing Queen" of wagyu beef ontop of ginger rice served with some spicy garlic thai long beans that were great. My friends enjoyed their Pad See You and wagyu noodle bowls as well. The service was courteous, but the dishes did come out at different times. I think they'll be working out those kinks as they go along. Definitely worth returning and a good new addition to the Castro. Ate there last night and everything was delicious.   I will definitely be going back.  Service was good and courteous. Great good! Good service! One dish came out a little earlier than everyone else's. The potato wedges are a must! Date & Time:  Tuesday November 20, 2012 @ 1:30pm Opening DayDining Companion:  The HusbandScene:  Gay & Straight Couples in Michael Kors Sweaters w/ Armloads of MK Rose Gold Bracelets + WatchMusic:  Afrojack, Deadmau 5, SkrillexDecor:  Urban Rustic.  Marais AC Chair + Stools in GunMetal Grey w/ Recycled Wood  Tables for Two & Small Groups.  Open-Kitchen Counter-Seating & Built-In Book ShelvesService:  Sweet & FriendlyImbibe:  Fruit Punch & Coconut Cream LatteDevour: Cheddar Biscuits, Eggs w/ Cheddar Potatoes, Sausage & Millionaires BaconTotal:  $39.98Note:  Brought to You by The People of Sweet Maple & Blackwood Well marinated rib-eye omurice topped w demi-glaze omg very delicious, wedges are super crunch,  homemade biscuit, fresh oj, friendly service, and clean and comfortable ambience. Thank you. I will try for dinner tonight.
